And there his sorrow ended.
title: Ellen Irwin
explanation: The Knight spent several days, months, and even years attempting to achieve the death he sought, but his efforts were in vain. Eventually, he was left heartbroken and turned to Ellen's grave for his final salvation. He lay down on her grave, and his sorrow finally came to an end.

stanza:
Now ye, who willingly have heard
The tale I have been telling,
May in Kirkconnel churchyard view
The grave of lovely Ellen:
By Ellen's side the Bruce is laid;
And, for the stone upon his head,
May no rude hand deface it,
And its forlorn "Hie jacet"!
title: Ellen Irwin
explanation: After listening to the story, those who are interested can visit Kirkconnel churchyard to see the grave of Ellen, who is buried next to Bruce. The speaker hopes that no one will deface the stone on Bruce's head or disturb the "Hie jacet" inscription.

title: O Nightingale! Thou Surely Art
explanation: The Nightingale is admired for having a passionate spirit as demonstrated by its fiery heart. Its powerful and intense singing pierces through the air with a tumultuous harmony that seems almost fierce. The bird sings with such fervor that it is as though it was blessed by the God of wine for Valentine's Day.

stanza:
A song in mockery and despite
Of shades, and dews, and silent night;
And steady bliss, and all the loves
Now sleeping in these peaceful groves.
title: O Nightingale! Thou Surely Art
explanation: This song is mocking the peaceful night, the calmness of the trees and the love that sleeps. Despite the beauty of the surroundings, the song is full of contempt and hatred.

title: O Nightingale! Thou Surely Art
explanation: Today, I heard a Stock-dove singing its story in a hidden place among the trees. Although its voice was muffled, the sound was carried by the wind. The bird didn't stop singing, repeatedly cooing its tune.

title: O Nightingale! Thou Surely Art
explanation: He courted her thoughtfully, singing of love with a gentle mix of seriousness and joy that seemed to never cease. His song spoke of commitment and deep happiness, and it was the perfect song for her.

stanza:
SMILE of the Moon!---for I so name
That silent greeting from above;
A gentle flash of light that came
From her whom drooping captives love;
Or art thou of still higher birth?
Thou that didst part the clouds of earth,
My torpor to reprove!
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker addresses the moon, referring to its gentle light as a "smile" and wonders if it is a message from a higher power. The light is a reminder to the speaker to shake off their lethargy and to be more active. The moon is likened to a compassionate captor who provides comfort to those who are feeling down. The speaker is moved by the moon's light and seems to feel that it has a profound effect on them.

stanza:
Bright boon of pitying Heaven!---alas,
I may not trust thy placid cheer!
Pondering that Time tonight will pass
The threshold of another year;
For years to me are sad and dull;
My very moments are too full
Of hopelessness and fear.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker in this poem laments the arrival of a new year, despite the idea of a "bright boon of pitying Heaven." The speaker cannot trust the idea of a peaceful or cheerful year, as they are constantly filled with sadness and fear. For years, life has been dreary and hopeless, and even the moments are too full of these negative emotions. The speaker seems to be struggling with a deep sense of despair and cannot find any solace in the idea of a new year.

stanza:
And yet, the soul-awakening gleam,
That struck perchance the farthest cone
Of Scotland's rocky wilds, did seem
To visit me, and me alone;
Me, unapproached by any friend,
Save those who to my sorrow lend
Tears due unto their own.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: Although I was alone and had no friends near me, I felt a spark of enlightenment that may have reached even the most distant parts of Scotland's rugged terrain. The only companions I had were those who shared in my grief and shed tears alongside me.

title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: Tonight, the bells of the church tower will ring out in celebration across the wide realms, welcoming the new year with a joyful peal. It is a tuneful offering for the welfare of millions who are happy and content in their slumber, but for me, it is a painful reminder of my wounds that refuse to heal, leaving me to watch and weep in sorrow.

stanza:
Born all too high, by wedlock raised
Still higherto be cast thus low!
Would that mine eyes had never gazed
On aught of more ambitious show
Than the sweet flowerets of the fields
---It is my royal state that yields
This bitterness of woe.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: I was born into a high position and raised even higher through marriage, but now I have fallen to a low state. I wish I had never seen anything more ambitious than the simple flowers in the fields. My royal status is the reason for my current sorrow.

stanza:
Yet how?---for I, if there be truth
In the world's voice, was passing fair;
And beauty, for confiding youth,
Those shocks of passion can prepare
That kill the bloom before its time;
And blanch, without the owner's crime,
The most resplendent hair.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker wonders how they have lost their beauty at a young age, despite being considered attractive in their youth. The speaker notes that beauty can lead to intense emotions that can harm one's appearance prematurely. The speaker suggests that their hair has lost its shine without any fault of their own.

stanza:
Unblest distinction! showered on me
To bind a lingering life in chains:
All that could quit my grasp, or flee,
Is gone;---but not the subtle stains
Fixed in the spirit; for even here
Can I be proud that jealous fear
Of what I was remains.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: What a cursed fate bestowed upon me, trapping me in an endless existence. Everything I once held dear has slipped away, leaving only the indelible marks on my soul. Yet, amidst this despair, I can still find solace in the knowledge that the fear of what I once was remains.

stanza:
A Woman rules my prison's key;
A sister Queen, against the bent
O law and holiest sympathy,
Detains me, doubtful of the event;
Great God, who feel'st for my distress,
My thoughts are all that I possess,
O keep them innocent!
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The key to my prison is controlled by a woman who acts as a powerful queen, going against the laws and natural compassion. She keeps me detained, unsure of what the outcome will be. I pray to God to help me through this difficult time, as my only possession is my thoughts, which I hope to keep pure and innocent.

stanza:
Farewell desire of human aid,
Which abject mortals vainly court!
By friends deceived, by foes betrayed,
Of fears the prey, of hopes the sport;
Nought but the world-redeeming Cross
Is able to support my loss,
My burthen to support.
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The author bids farewell to the desire for human help, which is something that many people seek but ultimately find disappointing. They are often let down by friends and betrayed by enemies, and are left to be preyed upon by fear and teased by hope. The only thing that can truly support the author's burdensome losses is the world-redeeming Cross.

stanza:
Hark! the death-note of the year
Sounded by the castle-clock!
From her sunk eyes a stagnant tear
Stole forth, unsettled by the shock;
But oft the woods renewed their green,
Ere the tired head of Scotland's Queen
Reposed upon the block!
title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The year is ending and the castle clock is striking, announcing its death. The Queen of Scotland sheds a tear from her sunken eyes, disturbed by the sound. However, the woods will bloom anew before the Queen's tired head rests on the execution block.

stanza:
Oh! what's the matter? what's the matter?
What is't that ails young Harry Gill?
That evermore his teeth they chatter,
Chatter, chatter, chatter still!
Of waistcoats Harry has no lack,
Good duffle grey, and flannel fine;
He has a blanket on his back,
And coats enough to smother nine.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: The speaker is curious about the reason why Harry Gill is constantly chattering his teeth. Despite having an abundance of clothes, including waistcoats, blankets, and coats, Harry cannot seem to shake the shivering.

stanza:
In March, December, and in July,
'Tis all the same with Harry Gill;
The neighbours tell, and tell you truly,
His teeth they chatter, chatter still.
At night, at morning, and at noon,
'Tis all the same with Harry Gill;
Beneath the sun, beneath the moon,
His teeth they chatter, chatter still!
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Harry Gill is known for his incessant teeth chattering, which occurs in March, December, and July, as reported by his neighbors. This condition persists throughout the day and night, regardless of the weather or time of day.

title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Harry was a young and strong cattle driver, unmatched in his physical ability. He had a rosy complexion and a powerful voice. In contrast, Goody Blake was an elderly woman who lived in poverty. She was undernourished and barely had enough clothing to cover herself. Anyone who walked past her humble dwelling could see the dire circumstances she was living in.

stanza:
All day she spun in her poor dwelling:
And then her three hours' work at night,
Alas! 'twas hardly worth the telling,
It would not pay for candle-light.
Remote from sheltered village-green,
On a hill's northern side she dwelt,
Where from sea-blasts the hawthorns lean,
And hoary dews are slow to melt.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: She spent her entire day spinning in her humble abode, and even though she worked for three hours at night, it was hardly worth mentioning as the money earned wouldn't be enough to cover the cost of the candle. She lived in a place far from the protected village-green, on the north side of a hill where the hawthorn trees leaned due to the strong sea-blasts, and the dew took a long time to disappear.

stanza:
By the same fire to boil their pottage,
Two poor old Dames, as I have known,
Will often live in one small cottage;
But she, poor Woman! housed alone.
'Twas well enough when summer came,
The long, warm, lightsome summer-day,
Then at her door the 'canty' Dame
Would sit, as any linnet, gay.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Two elderly women often share a small cottage and cook together over the same fire, but one of them lives alone. During the warm summer days, the cheerful woman would sit outside her door like a happy bird.

stanza:
But when the ice our streams did fetter,
Oh then how her old bones would shake!
You would have said, if you had met her,
'Twas a hard time for Goody Blake.
Her evenings then were dull and dead:
Sad case it was, as you may think,
For very cold to go to bed;
And then for cold not sleep a wink.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: When the streams froze over with ice, Goody Blake's old bones would shake uncontrollably. Her evenings became dull and lifeless, as it was too cold to go to bed and she was unable to sleep due to the freezing temperatures. It was a sad and difficult time for Goody Blake.

stanza:
O joy for her! whene'er in winter
The winds at night had made a rout;
And scattered many a lusty splinter
And many a rotten bough about.
Yet never had she, well or sick,
As every man who knew her says,
A pile beforehand, turf or stick,
Enough to warm her for three days.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Despite the harsh winter winds that often scattered branches and debris throughout the night, the woman found joy in the chaos. However, those who knew her noted that she never had enough firewood or fuel to keep her warm for more than three days.

stanza:
Now, when the frost was past enduring,
And made her poor old bones to ache,
Could any thing be more alluring
Than an old hedge to Goody Blake?
And, now and then, it must be said,
When her old bones were cold and chill,
She left her fire, or left her bed,
To seek the hedge of Harry Gill.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: As the frost became unbearable and caused Goody Blake's old bones to ache, she found comfort in the allure of an old hedge. Despite the occasional need to leave her warm bed or fireplace, she would seek solace in the hedge of Harry Gill.

stanza:
Now Harry he had long suspected
This trespass of old Goody Blake;
And vowed that she should be detected--
That he on her would vengeance take.
And oft from his warm fire he'd go,
And to the fields his road would take;
And there, at night, in frost and snow,
He watched to seize old Goody Blake.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Harry had a strong suspicion that Goody Blake had trespassed and was determined to catch her and seek revenge. He frequently left his warm fire to go to the fields, where he would wait in the cold and snow to catch her at night.

stanza:
And once, behind a rick of barley,
Thus looking out did Harry stand:
The moon was full and shining clearly,
And crisp with frost the stubble land.
--He hears a noise--he's all awake--
Again?--on tip-toe down the hill
He softly creeps--'tis Goody Blake;
She's at the hedge of Harry Gill!
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Harry was standing behind a stack of barley when he noticed the full moon shining brightly and the land covered in frost. Suddenly, he heard a noise and became alert. He tiptoed down the hill and saw Goody Blake at the hedge of Harry Gill.

stanza:
Right glad was he when he beheld her:
Stick after stick did Goody pull:
He stood behind a bush of elder,
Till she had filled her apron full.
When with her load she turned about,
The by-way back again to take;
He started forward, with a shout,
And sprang upon poor Goody Blake.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: He was very happy when he saw her. Goody kept pulling stick after stick and he watched from behind an elder bush until she had filled her apron. When she turned to head back, he shouted and jumped on her.

stanza:
And fiercely by the arm he took her,
And by the arm he held her fast,
And fiercely by the arm he shook her,
And cried, "I've caught you then at last!"--
Then Goody, who had nothing said,
Her bundle from her lap let fall;
And, kneeling on the sticks, she prayed
To God that is the judge of all.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: He grabbed her arm tightly and shook her, exclaiming that he had finally caught her. Goody, who had been silent up until this point, dropped her bundle and fell to her knees on the sticks. She prayed to God, the ultimate judge.

stanza:
She prayed, her withered hand uprearing,
While Harry held her by the arm--
"God! who art never out of hearing,
O may he never more be warm!" 0
The cold, cold moon above her head,
Thus on her knees did Goody pray;
Young Harry heard what she had said:
And icy cold he turned away.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: An elderly woman raised her withered hand in prayer while Harry supported her. She prayed to God, asking that someone she was referring to never feel warmth again. As she knelt, the chilly moon shone above her. Harry overheard her words and felt a coldness within him, causing him to turn away.

stanza:
He went complaining all the morrow
That he was cold and very chill:
His face was gloom, his heart was sorrow,
Alas! that day for Harry Gill!
That day he wore a riding-coat,
But not a whit the warmer he:
Another was on Thursday brought,
And ere the Sabbath he had three.
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Harry Gill spent the whole next day complaining about how cold and chilly he was. He was very unhappy, and his face showed it. He wore a riding-coat that day, but it didn't seem to make him any warmer. He got another one on Thursday, but still he was cold. By the time the Sabbath came around, he had three riding-coats, but he was still complaining about the cold.

title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: Despite being covered in blankets, Harry's teeth continued to chatter uncontrollably, reminiscent of a window shaking in the wind. His body was wasting away, and those who saw him knew that he would never be warm again, even if he lived for a long time. It was a futile effort to try and warm him up.

stanza:
No word to any man he utters,
A-bed or up, to young or old;
But ever to himself he mutters,
"Poor Harry Gill is very cold."
A-bed or up, by night or day;
His teeth they chatter, chatter still.
Now think, ye farmers all, I pray,
Of Goody Blake and Harry Gill!
title: Goody Blake And Harry Gill
explanation: The speaker of the poem keeps to himself the knowledge that Harry Gill is always cold, whether he is in bed or up, regardless of his age. The only thing he does is mutter to himself that Harry Gill is cold. Harry Gill's teeth still chatter even if he is in bed or out during the night or day. The speaker urges farmers to remember the story of Goody Blake and Harry Gill.

stanza:
THE post-boy drove with fierce career,
For threatening clouds the moon had drowned;
When, as we hurried on, my ear
Was smitten with a startling sound.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The postman drove quickly as dark clouds covered the moon. Suddenly, I heard a loud and surprising noise as we rushed forward.

stanza:
As if the wind blew many ways,
I heard the sound,-and more and more;
It seemed to follow with the chaise,
And still I heard it as before.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: I heard the sound of the wind blowing in different directions while I was traveling in a chaise. The sound continued to follow me as I went along.

stanza:
At length I to the boy called out;
He stopped his horses at the word,
But neither cry, nor voice, nor shout,
Nor aught else like it, could be heard.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: Eventually, I yelled out to the boy and he halted his horses upon hearing me. However, despite my efforts, no sound or noise was audible in response.

stanza:
The boy then smacked his whip, and fast
The horses scampered through the rain;
But, hearing soon upon the blast
The cry, I bade him halt again.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The boy cracked his whip and the horses ran quickly through the rain, but when he heard a cry on the wind, the speaker instructed him to stop once more.

stanza:
Forthwith alighting on the ground,
'Whence comes,' said I, 'this piteous moan?'
And there a little Girl I found,
Sitting behind the chaise, alone.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: Immediately descending to the earth, I inquired, "From where does this sorrowful wail emanate?" Then, I came across a young female child, who was sitting by herself at the back of the carriage.

stanza:
My cloak!' no other word she spake,
But loud and bitterly she wept,
As if her innocent heart would break;
And down from off her seat she leapt.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The woman cried out for her cloak and wept bitterly, her heart seemingly on the brink of shattering. She did not utter any other words but leapt from her seat in distress.

stanza:
What ails you, child?'-she sobbed 'Look here!'
I saw it in the wheel entangled,
A weather-beaten rag as e'er
From any garden scare-crow dangled.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The woman asked the child what was wrong and started crying. She showed the child a rag that was tangled in the wheel, which looked old and ragged like a scarecrow in a garden.

stanza:
There, twisted between nave and spoke,
It hung, nor could at once be freed;
But our joint pains unloosed the cloak,
A miserable rag indeed!
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The cloak was stuck between the nave and spoke and could not be removed easily. However, our combined efforts eventually led to its removal, revealing a sorry state of the cloak.

stanza:
And whither are you going, child,
To-night alone these lonesome ways?'
'To Durham,' answered she, half wild-
'Then come with me into the chaise.'
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The speaker asks a young person where they are going alone at night. The young person responds that they are going to Durham and the speaker invites them to ride in the carriage with them.

stanza:
Insensible to all relief
Sat the poor girl, and forth did send
Sob after sob, as if her grief
Could never, never have an end.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The girl was completely unaware of any comfort and remained seated, sending out a series of sobs that seemed to indicate her sorrow would never cease.

stanza:
My child, in Durham do you dwell?'
She checked herself in her distress,
And said, 'My name is Alice Fell;
I'm fatherless and motherless.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: "Do you live in Durham?" the speaker asked the girl. The girl paused, then responded with her name, Alice Fell, and the fact that she has no parents.

stanza:
And I to Durham, Sir, belong.'
Again, as if the thought would choke
Her very heart, her grief grew strong;
And all was for her tattered cloak!
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The speaker says that they belong to Durham, but the woman they are speaking to is so overwhelmed with grief that she can barely speak. She is upset because her cloak is torn and in disrepair.

stanza:
The chaise drove on; our journey's end
Was nigh; and, sitting by my side,
As if she had lost her only friend
She wept, nor would be pacified.
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: As we approached the end of our journey, the chaise continued to move forward. Next to me, there was a woman who was crying uncontrollably, as if she had lost her dearest companion. Despite my attempts to calm her down, she refused to be comforted.

title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: We arrived at the tavern and I shared Alice's story of sorrow. I then provided funds to the tavern owner for the purpose of purchasing a new cloak for her.

stanza:
And let it be of duffil grey,
As warm a cloak as man can sell!'
Proud creature was she the next day,
The little orphan, Alice Fell!
title: Alice Fell, Or Poverty
explanation: The little orphan, Alice Fell, wanted a warm cloak and requested it to be made of duffel grey. She was proud when she received the cloak the next day.

stanza:
At the corner of Wood Street, when daylight appears,
Hangs a Thrush that sings loud, it has sung for three years:
Poor Susan has passed by the spot, and has heard
In the silence of morning the song of the Bird.
title: The Reverie Of Poor Susan
explanation: On the corner of Wood Street, there is a Thrush that sings loudly at daylight for the past three years. Poor Susan has passed by and has heard the Bird's song in the quiet of the morning.

stanza:
Tis a note of enchantment; what ails her? She sees
A mountain ascending, a vision of trees;
Bright volumes of vapour through Lothbury glide,
And a river flows on through the vale of Cheapside.
title: The Reverie Of Poor Susan
explanation: There is a sense of magic in the air, but what is causing it? The woman sees a mountain rising up and a forest of trees. She notices clouds of mist floating through Lothbury, while a river flows through the valley of Cheapside.

stanza:
Green pastures she views in the midst of the dale,
Down which she so often has tripped with her pail;
And a single small cottage, a nest like a dove's,
The one only dwelling on earth that she loves.
title: The Reverie Of Poor Susan
explanation: She sees lush meadows in the valley where she has walked many times before with her bucket. There is only one small house, resembling a bird's nest, that she truly cherishes and is the only home she has ever loved.

stanza:
She looks, and her heart is in heaven: but they fade,
The mist and the river, the hill and the shade:
The stream will not flow, and the hill will not rise,
And the colours have all passed away from her eyes!
title: The Reverie Of Poor Susan
explanation: The sight before her fills her with joy, but it quickly disappears. The mist, river, hill, and shade all fade away. The stream stops flowing and the hill no longer rises. The colors that once brought her happiness have vanished from her sight.

stanza:
That is work of waste and ruin--
Do as Charles and I are doing!
Strawberry-blossoms, one and all,
We must spare them--here are many:
Look at it--the flower is small,
Small and low, though fair as any:
Do not touch it! summers two
I am older, Anne, than you.
title: Foresight
explanation: Charles and I are sparing the strawberry blossoms, which are small but beautiful. Anne is being told not to touch them, as they are important and must be preserved. The speaker, who is older than Anne, believes that destroying the blossoms would be a waste and lead to ruin.

title: Foresight
explanation: Sister Anne is asked to pull as many primroses as she can, while also being offered daisies, pansies, cuckoo-flowers, and daffodils to make a bed or bower with. She is encouraged to fill her lap and bosom with the flowers, but to spare the strawberry blossom.

stanza:
Primroses, the Spring may love them--
Summer knows but little of them:
Violets, a barren kind,
Withered on the ground must lie;
Daisies leave no fruit behind
When the pretty flowerets die;
Pluck them, and another year
As many will be blowing here.
title: Foresight
explanation: Spring adores primroses, but they are not well-known in the summer. Violets are a fruitless plant that wither on the ground when they die, and daisies do not produce any fruit once their flowers fall off. However, if you pluck them, the next year will bring just as many blooming flowers.

stanza:
God has given a kindlier power
To the favoured strawberry-flower.
Hither soon as spring is fled
You and Charles and I will walk;
Lurking berries, ripe and red,
Then will hang on every stalk,
Each within its leafy bower;
And for that promise spare the flower!
title: Foresight
explanation: The strawberry flower has been blessed by God with a gentle power. When spring has ended, the speaker and two others will go for a walk to find the ripe, red berries hidden among the leaves. The speaker urges them to spare the flower and enjoy the promise of the sweet fruit.

stanza:
FROM low to high doth dissolution climb,
And sink from high to low, along a scale
Of awful notes, whose concord shall not fail;
A musical but melancholy chime,
Which they can hear who meddle not with crime,
Nor avarice, nor over-anxious care.
title: Mutability
explanation: Dissolution moves in an ascending and descending manner, following a scale of notes that create a melancholy but harmonious sound. Those who avoid crime, greed, and excessive worry can hear this musical scale.

stanza:
Truth fails not; but her outward forms that bear
The longest date do melt like frosty rime,
That in the morning whiten'd hill and plain
And is no more; drop like the tower sublime
Of yesterday, which royally did wear
His crown of weeds, but could not even sustain
Some casual shout that broke the silent air,
Or the unimaginable touch of Time.
title: Mutability
explanation: The truth never fails, but the physical manifestations of truth, which seem to last the longest, eventually disappear like frost melting in the morning sun or a majestic tower that could not even withstand a casual shout or the passage of time.

stanza:
And is this -Yarrow? -This the stream
Of which my fancy cherished
So faithfully, a waking dream,
An image that hath perished?
O that some minstrel's harp were near
To utter notes of gladness
And chase this silence from the air,
That fills my heart with sadness!
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The speaker questions if the location they are at is Yarrow and the stream they see is the same one they used to dream about. They feel sad that their previous image of the stream has disappeared and wish a musician could be nearby to bring happiness to the silence that surrounds them.

stanza:
Yet why? -a silvery current flows
With uncontrolled meanderings;
Nor have these eyes by greener hills
Been soothed, in all my wanderings.
And, through her depths, Saint Mary's Lake
Is visibly delighted;
For not a feature of those hills
Is in the mirror slighted.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The speaker wonders why a shimmering stream flows so unpredictably, and despite having traveled to greener hills, they have not been as calming as this sight. The speaker notes that even Saint Mary's Lake seems to be pleased with the reflection of the hills, not missing a single detail.

stanza:
A blue sky bends o'er Yarrow Vale,
Save where that pearly whiteness
Is round the rising sun diffused,
A tender hazy brightness;
Mild dawn of promise! that excludes
All profitless dejection;
Though not unwilling here to admit
A pensive recollection.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The Yarrow Vale is covered by a blue sky, except for the area where the rising sun is spreading a gentle hazy whiteness. This dawn promises a positive future, eliminating any unnecessary sadness, although it is open to a melancholic reflection.

stanza:
Where was it that the famous Flower
Of Yarrow Vale lay bleeding?
His bed perchance was yon smooth mound
On which the herd is feeding:
And haply from this crystal pool,
Now peaceful as the morning,
The Water-wraith ascended thrice,
And gave his doleful warning.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The poem asks where the famous Flower of Yarrow Vale was bleeding. It suggests that his bed may have been the smooth mound where the herd is currently grazing. The poem also mentions a crystal pool, which may have been the location where the Water-wraith appeared three times to give his warning.

stanza:
Delicious is the Lay that sings
The haunts of happy lovers,
The path that leads them to the grove,
The leafy grove that covers:
And pity sanctifies the verse
That paints, by strength of sorrow,
The unconquerable strength of love;
Bear witness, rueful Yarrow!
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The Lay is delightful when it sings about the places where happy lovers meet and the path that leads them to the leafy grove. The verse is made even more poignant when it portrays the strength of love through the lens of sorrow, and pity adds a sacred element to it. The Yarrow serves as a witness to the unconquerable strength of love.

stanza:
But thou that didst appear so fair
To fond imagination,
Dost rival in the light of day
Her delicate creation:
Meek loveliness is round thee spread,
A softness still and holy:
The grace of forest charms decayed,
And pastoral melancholy.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: You, who were once so beautiful to my imagination, now rival the delicate creations of reality. Your appearance is surrounded by a gentle and pure loveliness, exuding a softness that is both graceful and holy. The charm of the forest and the melancholy of pastoral life are embodied in your presence.

stanza:
That region left, the vale unfolds
Rich groves of lofty stature,
With Yarrow winding through the pomp
Of cultivated nature;
And rising from those lofty groves
Behold a ruin hoary,
The shattered front of Newark's Towers,
Renowned in Border story.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: Leaving that area, the valley reveals lush forests with tall trees and the Yarrow river flowing through the cultivated land. Above the forests stands a ruined tower, the front of Newark's Towers, famous in the tales of the Border region.

stanza:
Fair scenes for childhood's opening bloom,
For sportive youth to stray in,
For manhood to enjoy his strength,
And age to wear away in!
Yon cottage seems a bower of bliss,
A covert for protection
Of tender thoughts, that nestle there -
The brood of chaste affection.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: These surroundings are perfect for the beginning of childhood, a place for playful youth to explore, for grown men to revel in their strength, and for the elderly to live out their remaining days. That cottage appears to be a haven of happiness, a safe haven for pure thoughts that reside within - the offspring of innocent love.

stanza:
How sweeet on this autumnal day
The wild-wood fruits to gather,
And on my true-love's forehead plant
A crest of blooming heather!
And what if I enwreathed my own?
'Twere no offence to reason;
The sober hills thus deck their brows
To meet the wintry season.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: On this beautiful autumn day, it is lovely to collect fruits from the forest and place a heather crown on my beloved's forehead. Even if I were to wear one myself, it would not be unreasonable, as the hills also adorn themselves to prepare for winter.

stanza:
I see -but not by sight alone,
Loved Yarrow, have I won thee;
A ray of Fancy still survives -
Her sunshine plays upon thee!
Thy ever-youthful waters keep
A course of lively pleasure;
And gladsome notes my lips can breathe
Accordant to the measure.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: I have won your love, dear Yarrow, not just by seeing you with my eyes, but through my imagination, which still shines upon you like the sun. Your waters are always full of life and joy, and I can't help but sing along with the melodies they inspire within me.

stanza:
The vapours linger round the heights,
They melt, and soon must vanish;
One hour is theirs, nor more is mine -
Sad thought! which I would banish,
But that I know, where'er I go,
Thy genuine image, Yarrow!
Will dwell with me -to heighten joy,
And cheer my mind in sorrow.
title: Yarrow Visited
explanation: The mist hovers over the mountains and eventually dissipates, leaving only an hour of its presence. This thought saddens the speaker, but they find solace knowing that wherever they go, the true image of Yarrow will remain with them. This image will bring them happiness and comfort during both joyful and sorrowful times.

stanza:
AH! where is Palafox? Nor tongue no pen
Reports of him, his dwelling or his grave!
Does yet the unheard-of vessel ride the wave?
Or is she swallowed up, remote from ken
Of pitying human nature? Once again
Methinks that we shall hail thee, Champion brave,
Redeemed to baffle that imperial Slave,
And through all Europe cheer desponding men
With new-born hope. Unbounded is the might
Of martyrdom, and fortitude, and right.
title: Ah! Where Is Palafox? Nor Tongue Nor Pen
explanation: The speaker is wondering about the whereabouts of Palafox and has no information about his dwelling or grave. The speaker wonders if the vessel carrying Palafox is lost at sea or if he is dead and buried in an unknown location. The speaker hopes that Palafox will return as a brave champion to defeat the imperial Slave and bring new hope to Europe. The speaker believes that the power of martyrdom, fortitude, and righteousness is limitless.

stanza:
Hark, how thy Country triumphs!-Smilingly
The Eternal looks upon her sword that gleams,
Like his own lightning, over mountains high,
On rampart, and the banks of all her streams.
title: Ah! Where Is Palafox? Nor Tongue Nor Pen
explanation: Listen to the sounds of your country's triumph! The Eternal, with a smile, gazes upon the shining sword, which is comparable to his own lightning, that towers over the mountains, fortresses, and the shores of all the rivers.

title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: For three years, she flourished under the sun and rain, until Nature decided that she was the most beautiful flower that had ever existed on earth. Nature then decided to take her and transform her into a Lady of her own, claiming her as her own creation.

stanza:
"Myself will to my darling be
Both law and impulse: and with me
The Girl, in rock and plain
In earth and heaven, in glade and bower,
Shall feel an overseeing power
To kindle or restrain.
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: I will be both the law and the impulse for my beloved, and together we will feel the power to inspire or control in every aspect of nature, be it on rocks or plains, in the earth or sky, in forests or gardens."

stanza:
"She shall be sportive as the fawn
That wild with glee across the lawn
Or up the mountain springs;
And her's shall be the breathing balm,
And her's the silence and the calm
Of mute insensate things.
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: She will be playful like a fawn prancing across the lawn or leaping up the mountain springs. She will bring a calming presence and tranquility, much like the stillness and peacefulness of inanimate objects.

stanza:
"The floating clouds their state shall lend
To her; for her the willow bend;
Nor shall she fail to see
Even in the motions of the Storm
Grace that shall mold the Maiden's form
By silent sympathy.
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: The clouds in the sky will take on the same state as the woman, and the willow tree will also bend towards her. Even in the midst of a storm, she will be able to see beauty and grace that will shape her form through a connection of understanding without words.

stanza:
"The stars of midnight shall be dear
To her; and she shall lean her ear
In many a secret place
Where rivulets dance their wayward round,
And beauty born of murmuring sound
Shall pass into her face.
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: She will cherish the stars that shine in the night sky, and listen intently to the sounds of trickling streams in hidden locations, where the beauty of the gentle murmurs will reflect on her countenance."

stanza:
"And vital feelings of delight
Shall rear her form to stately height,
Her virgin bosom swell;
Such thoughts to Lucy I will give
While she and I together live
Here in this happy dell."
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: I will impart to Lucy joyful and uplifting emotions that will enhance her beauty and make her appear more majestic. Her purity and grace will be accentuated by these feelings, which I will share with her while we remain in this blissful valley.

stanza:
Thus Nature spake---The work was done---
How soon my Lucy's race was run!
She died, and left to me
This heath, this calm, and quiet scene;
The memory of what has been,
And never more will be.
title: Three Years She Grew In Sun And Shower,
explanation: Nature spoke and expressed sadness that Lucy's life had ended so quickly. Lucy passed away and left behind a serene heath and calm environment. The memories of the past will never return.

stanza:
When Ruth was left half desolate,
Her Father took another Mate;
And Ruth, not seven years old,
A slighted child, at her own will
Went wandering over dale and hill,
In thoughtless freedom, bold.
title: Ruth
explanation: Ruth's father remarried, leaving her feeling abandoned and alone. At just seven years old, she was a neglected child who took to wandering aimlessly in the countryside, enjoying the freedom of being able to do as she pleased without any supervision or restrictions.

stanza:
And she had made a pipe of straw,
And music from that pipe could draw
Like sounds of winds and floods;
Had built a bower upon the green,
As if she from her birth had been
An infant of the woods.
title: Ruth
explanation: She had fashioned a straw pipe that emitted melodious tunes akin to the sounds of nature. Alongside this, she had erected a shelter in the verdant surrounds, evoking the impression that she was always meant to dwell amidst the trees and foliage from the moment she was born.

title: Ruth
explanation: Living under her father's roof, she appeared to be solitary, with her thoughts kept to herself. She found pleasure in her own company, not experiencing either sadness or joy, and while away the entire day, she matured into a woman.

title: Ruth
explanation: A young man arrived from the coast of Georgia wearing a military helmet adorned with magnificent feathers. These feathers were obtained from the Cherokees and added a grand touch to his headpiece as they swayed in the wind.

stanza:
From Indian blood you deem him sprung:
But no! he spake the English tongue,
And bore a soldier's name;
And, when America was free
From battle and from jeopardy,
He 'cross the ocean came.
title: Ruth
explanation: Although you may assume that he has Indian ancestry, he actually spoke English and had an English name. He arrived in America after the war and when the country was no longer in danger.

stanza:
With hues of genius on his cheek
In finest tones the Youth could speak:
--While he was yet a boy,
The moon, the glory of the sun,
And streams that murmur as they run,
Had been his dearest joy.
title: Ruth
explanation: The Youth had a natural talent for speaking and his face was marked with intelligence. Even when he was young, he found great pleasure in the moon, the sun's radiance, and the sounds of running streams.

stanza:
He was a lovely Youth! I guess
The panther in the wilderness
Was not so fair as he;
And, when he chose to sport and play,
No dolphin ever was so gay
Upon the tropic sea.
title: Ruth
explanation: The young man was very beautiful, perhaps more so than a panther in the wild. He was playful and lively, like a dolphin in the tropical sea.

stanza:
Among the Indians he had fought,
And with him many tales he brought
Of pleasure and of fear;
Such tales as told to any maid
By such a Youth, in the green shade,
Were perilous to hear.
title: Ruth
explanation: He had fought with Indians and had many stories to tell of both joy and terror. These stories were dangerous to hear if told by a young man in a secluded area to a young woman.

stanza:
He told of girls--a happy rout!
Who quit their fold with dance and shout,
Their pleasant Indian town,
To gather strawberries all day long;
Returning with a choral song
When daylight is gone down.
title: Ruth
explanation: He spoke of a group of girls who joyfully left their village, dancing and shouting, to spend the day picking strawberries. They returned at sunset, singing together in harmony.

stanza:
He spake of plants that hourly change
Their blossoms, through a boundless range
Of intermingling hues;
With budding, fading, faded flowers
They stand the wonder of the bowers
From morn to evening dews.
title: Ruth
explanation: He talked about how plants constantly transform their blooms, displaying an endless variety of colors that blend together. Their flowers bud, fade, and eventually wither away, but they remain a marvel of nature from morning until the dewy evening.

stanza:
He told of the magnolia, spread
High as a cloud, high over head!
The cypress and her spire;
--Of flowers that with one scarlet gleam
Cover a hundred leagues, and seem
To set the hills on fire.
title: Ruth
explanation: He spoke about the magnolia tree that stretched high into the clouds and the cypress with its tall spire. He also mentioned the flowers that shone bright scarlet and covered a vast distance, making the hills appear as if they were ablaze.

stanza:
The Youth of green savannahs spake,
And many an endless, endless lake,
With all its fairy crowds
Of islands, that together lie
As quietly as spots of sky
Among the evening clouds.
title: Ruth
explanation: The young people of the green savannahs spoke of the many vast and infinite lakes, surrounded by fairy-like islands that sit together peacefully like spots of sky among the evening clouds.

stanza:
"How pleasant," then he said, "it were
A fisher or a hunter there,
In sunshine or in shade
To wander with an easy mind;
And build a household fire, and find
A home in every glade!
title: Ruth
explanation: He expressed his admiration for the tranquil setting and imagined the delightful experience of being a fisherman or hunter, strolling through the area with ease, regardless of whether it was sunny or shaded. He envisioned constructing a fire and finding a comfortable place to settle in each clearing, making it his home.

stanza:
"What days and what bright years! Ah me!
Our life were life indeed, with thee
So passed in quiet bliss,
And all the while," said he, "to know
That we were in a world of woe,
On such an earth as this!"
title: Ruth
explanation: The speaker reflects on the past and expresses how wonderful life was during those days and bright years spent with their loved one. They long for a life of peaceful happiness with that person, but are saddened by the knowledge that they live in a world of suffering on Earth.

stanza:
And then he sometimes interwove
Fond thoughts about a father's love
"For there," said he, "are spun
Around the heart such tender ties,
That our own children to our eyes
Are dearer than the sun.
title: Ruth
explanation: He would occasionally blend affectionate musings about paternal love into his thoughts. He believed that the connections between a father and their children are so delicate and heartfelt that their offspring become more beloved than anything else.

stanza:
"Sweet Ruth! and could you go with me
My helpmate in the woods to be,
Our shed at night to rear;
Or run, my own adopted bride,
A sylvan huntress at my side,
And drive the flying deer!
title: Ruth
explanation: The speaker is addressing someone named Ruth and asking if she would accompany him into the woods to help build a shelter or go on a hunt together. He refers to her as his "adopted bride" and suggests they could be like a pair of "sylvan huntresses" chasing after deer.

stanza:
"Beloved Ruth!"--No more he said,
The wakeful Ruth at midnight shed
A solitary tear:
She thought again--and did agree 0
With him to sail across the sea,
And drive the flying deer.
title: Ruth
explanation: The speaker addresses a person named Ruth with affection. Ruth is awake at midnight and sheds a tear in solitude. She thinks about what the speaker said and ultimately agrees to sail across the sea with him and hunt deer.

stanza:
"And now, as fitting is and right,
We in the church our faith will plight,
A husband and a wife."
Even so they did; and I may say
That to sweet Ruth that happy day
Was more than human life.
title: Ruth
explanation: The couple is getting married in a church and pledging their faith to each other. The speaker comments that Ruth is overjoyed on her wedding day, more so than anything else in life.

stanza:
Through dream and vision did she sink,
Delighted all the while to think
That on those lonesome floods,
And green savannahs, she should share
His board with lawful joy, and bear
His name in the wild woods.
title: Ruth
explanation: She dreamed and envisioned herself happily joining him on the lonely waters and green plains, where they would share meals and joyfully bear his name in the wilderness.

stanza:
But, as you have before been told,
This Stripling, sportive, gay, and bold,
And, with his dancing crest,
So beautiful, through savage lands
Had roamed about, with vagrant bands
Of Indians in the West.
title: Ruth
explanation: This young man, who is lively, cheerful, and daring, has been mentioned previously, and with his impressive head of hair, he travelled through rough terrain with various groups of Native Americans in the western parts of the country.

stanza:
The wind, the tempest roaring high,
The tumult of a tropic sky,
Might well be dangerous food
For him, a Youth to whom was given
So much of earth--so much of heaven,
And such impetuous blood.
title: Ruth
explanation: The raging wind and stormy weather of a tropical sky could pose a threat to a young man who was blessed with both earthly and heavenly gifts, as well as a fiery spirit.

stanza:
Whatever in those climes he found
Irregular in sight or sound
Did to his mind impart
A kindred impulse, seemed allied
To his own powers, and justified
The workings of his heart.
title: Ruth
explanation: He found a connection with anything out of the ordinary in those regions, whether it was in appearance or sound. It gave him a sense of familiarity and seemed to be in line with his own abilities, validating his emotions and actions.

title: Ruth
explanation: The beauty of nature, such as the lovely trees and stunning flowers, were used to indulge in pleasure-filled thoughts. The gentle breezes added to the atmosphere of relaxation, while even the stars seemed to have their own emotions that were imparted onto the enchanting gardens.

stanza:
Yet, in his worst pursuits, I ween
That sometimes there did intervene
Pure hopes of high intent:
For passions linked to forms so fair
And stately, needs must have their share
Of noble sentiment.
title: Ruth
explanation: Despite his questionable actions, it is possible that the person being discussed occasionally had genuine aspirations for noble endeavors. This could be attributed to the allure of being associated with beautiful and dignified individuals, which naturally evokes a sense of high-mindedness.

stanza:
But ill he lived, much evil saw,
With men to whom no better law
Nor better life was known;
Deliberately, and undeceived,
Those wild men's vices he received,
And gave them back his own.
title: Ruth
explanation: The man lived a sickly life and witnessed a great deal of wrongdoing among those who had no knowledge or experience of a better way of living. He consciously and without any illusions embraced the immoral behavior of these untamed individuals and reflected it back to them.

stanza:
His genius and his moral frame
Were thus impaired, and he became
The slave of low desires:
A Man who without self-control
Would seek what the degraded soul
Unworthily admires.
title: Ruth
explanation: His intellectual brilliance and ethical principles were compromised, causing him to succumb to base instincts. He became a person who lacked discipline and pursued things that were beneath his dignity, indulging in activities that wouldn't be considered appropriate for a respectable person.

stanza:
And yet he with no feigned delight
Had wooed the Maiden, day and night
Had loved her, night and morn:
What could he less than love a Maid
Whose heart with so much nature played?
So kind and so forlorn!
title: Ruth
explanation: He genuinely enjoyed wooing the Maiden and had been expressing his love for her consistently, both during the day and at night. He had fallen in love with her and felt that he couldn't have done anything less, especially because she had such a natural and kind heart, yet seemed to be in a state of despair.

stanza:
Sometimes, most earnestly, he said,
"O Ruth! I have been worse than dead;
False thoughts, thoughts bold and vain,
Encompassed me on every side
When I, in confidence and pride,
Had crossed the Atlantic main.
title: Ruth
explanation: He would often tell Ruth that he had been in a worse state than death, consumed by untrue and arrogant thoughts that surrounded him on all sides when he had confidently and arrogantly crossed the Atlantic Ocean.

stanza:
"Before me shone a glorious world--
Fresh as a banner bright, unfurled
To music suddenly:
I looked upon those hills and plains,
And seemed as if let loose from chains,
To live at liberty.
title: Ruth
explanation: I saw a magnificent world before me, as if a bright banner had been unfurled to the sound of sudden music. The hills and plains lay out before me, and I felt as though I had been released from captivity and was now free to live my life to the fullest.

stanza:
"No more of this; for now, by thee
Dear Ruth! more happily set free
With nobler zeal I burn;
My soul from darkness is released,
Like the whole sky when to the east
The morning doth return."
title: Ruth
explanation: I'm done with this topic, Ruth. I feel a new sense of purpose and passion. My spirit is liberated from the darkness, like the sky brightening when the sun rises in the east.

title: Ruth
explanation: Quickly, his improved state of mind disappeared, leaving behind no hope or desire. He was no longer moved by his former motivations. Instead, he found pleasure in new things and reverted back to his previous reckless behavior, wanting to live without rules once again.

stanza:
Meanwhile, as thus with him it fared,
They for the voyage were prepared,
And went to the sea-shore,
But, when they thither came the Youth
Deserted his poor Bride, and Ruth
Could never find him more.
title: Ruth
explanation: While this was happening to him, the others were getting ready for their journey and headed to the beach. However, when they arrived there, the young man abandoned his bride and Ruth was unable to locate him again.

stanza:
God help thee, Ruth!--Such pains she had,
That she in half a year was mad,
And in a prison housed;
And there, with many a doleful song
Made of wild words, her cup of wrong
She fearfully caroused.
title: Ruth
explanation: Ruth suffered greatly and became insane within six months, leading to her imprisonment. In her despair, she sang sorrowful songs filled with nonsensical words and drank from her cup of suffering.

title: Ruth
explanation: Sometimes she experienced gentler moments, where she didn't require the warmth of the sun, the freshness of the rain or the nourishment of the dew. She also didn't miss the joyful activities of May because they were all present with her in her confinement. Additionally, there was a lively brook nearby that created a pleasant sound as it flowed over the pebbles.

title: Ruth
explanation: Ruth had been suffering for three seasons, but finally, she found relief from her pain and managed to escape from her prison. However, no one cared about the homeless and she had to fend for herself, finding shelter and food wherever she could.

stanza:
Among the fields she breathed again:
The master-current of her brain
Ran permanent and free;
And, coming to the Banks of Tone,
There did she rest; and dwell alone
Under the greenwood tree.
title: Ruth
explanation: She breathed anew as she walked among the fields, her mind completely clear and unobstructed. The flow of her thoughts ran smoothly and unhindered, ultimately leading her to the banks of the Tone river where she found solace and chose to remain in solitude beneath the shade of a tree.

stanza:
The engines of her pain, the tools
That shaped her sorrow, rocks and pools,
And airs that gently stir
The vernal leaves--she loved them still;
Nor ever taxed them with the ill
Which had been done to her.
title: Ruth
explanation: Despite the pain and sorrow she experienced, she still cherished the things that caused it, such as rocks, pools, and the breeze rustling through the leaves. She did not blame them for the harm they had caused her.

stanza:
A Barn her 'winter' bed supplies;
But, till the warmth of summer skies
And summer days is gone,
(And all do in this tale agree)
She sleeps beneath the greenwood tree,
And other home hath none.
title: Ruth
explanation: During the winter, a barn provides the protagonist with a place to sleep. However, once summer arrives and the weather is warm, she sleeps outside under a tree. It is agreed among all involved in the story that the tree is her only home.

stanza:
An innocent life, yet far astray!
And Ruth will, long before her day,
Be broken down and old:
Sore aches she needs must have! but less
Of mind, than body's wretchedness,
From damp, and rain, and cold.
title: Ruth
explanation: Ruth's life has been derailed despite her innocence. She will experience physical suffering and become prematurely old due to the harsh conditions she endures, including dampness, rain, and cold. Her mind may not be as affected as her body, but she will still face significant mental distress.

stanza:
If she is prest by want of food,
She from her dwelling in the wood
Repairs to a road-side;
And there she begs at one steep place
Where up and down with easy pace
The horsemen-travellers ride.
title: Ruth
explanation: When she is hungry and lacks food, she leaves her home in the forest and goes to a nearby road. She begs for food at a steep spot where horseback travelers pass by at a leisurely pace.

stanza:
That oaten pipe of hers is mute,
Or thrown away; but with a flute
Her loneliness she cheers:
This flute, made of a hemlock stalk,
At evening in his homeward walk
The Quantock woodman hears.
title: Ruth
explanation: The woman's traditional musical instrument made of oat has either been discarded or silenced, however, she now finds solace in playing a flute made from a hemlock stalk. The woodman who passes by the Quantock forest in the evening hears her playing the instrument.

stanza:
I, too, have passed her on the hills
Setting her little water-mills
By spouts and fountains wild--
Such small machinery as she turned
Ere she had wept, ere she had mourned,
A young and happy Child!
title: Ruth
explanation: I have also seen her on the hills, placing her small water mills by streams and natural springs. She created these machines when she was a young and joyful child, before she experienced sadness and grief.

stanza:
Farewell! and when thy days are told,
Ill-fated Ruth, in hallowed mould
Thy corpse shall buried be,
For thee a funeral bell shall ring,
And all the congregation sing
A Christian psalm for thee.
title: Ruth
explanation: Goodbye! And when your life has ended, unfortunate Ruth, your body will be buried in consecrated ground. A funeral bell will toll for you and the entire congregation will sing a Christian hymn in your honor.

stanza:
Surprised by joy  impatient as the Wind
I turned to share the transport--Oh! with whom
But Thee, deep buried in the silent tomb,
That spot which no vicissitude can find?
Love, faithful love, recalled thee to my mind--
But how could I forget thee? Through what power,
Even for the least division of an hour,
Have I been so beguiled as to be blind
To my most grievous loss?--That thought's return
Was the worst pang that sorrow ever bore,
Save one, one only, when I stood forlorn,
Knowing my heart's best treasure was no more;
That neither present time, nor years unborn
Could to my sight that heavenly face restore.
title: Surprised By Joy
explanation: I was filled with joy and wanted to share it with someone, but the only person who came to mind was you, who is buried in a silent tomb that never changes. I remembered you because of our faithful love, but how could I have ever forgotten you? I must have been foolishly blinded for a moment to have forgotten the pain of your loss. The thought of never being able to see your heavenly face again was the worst pain I ever felt, second only to the moment when I realized that my heart's greatest treasure was gone forever and no amount of time could bring it back.

stanza:
Between two sister moorland rills
There is a spot that seems to lie
Sacred to flowerets of the hills,
And sacred to the sky.
And in this smooth and open dell
There is a tempest-stricken tree;
A corner-stone by lightning cut,
The last stone of a lonely hut;
And in this dell you see
A thing no storm can e'er destroy,
The shadow of a Danish Boy.
title: The Danish Boy: A Fragment
explanation: There is a special place between two streams on the moorlands that is respected by both the flowers and the sky. In this peaceful spot, there is a tree that has been struck by lightning, the last remnant of a long-gone hut. Despite the harsh winds and storms that rage through the moorlands, there is one thing that remains unscathed: the shadow of a Danish Boy.

stanza:
In clouds above, the lark is heard,
But drops not here to earth for rest;
Within this lonesome nook the bird
Did never build her nest.
No beast, no bird hath here his home;
Bees, wafted on the breezy air,
Pass high above those fragrant bells
To other flowers:--to other dells
Their burthens do they bear;
The Danish Boy walks here alone:
The lovely dell is all his own.
title: The Danish Boy: A Fragment
explanation: The lark can be heard singing in the clouds above, but it never comes down to rest in this secluded spot where it has never built a nest. No animals or birds make this place their home, and even bees pass by on the breeze without stopping to gather nectar from the fragrant flowers. The Danish Boy is the only one who walks in this lovely dell, surrounded by its beauty and peacefulness.

title: The Danish Boy: A Fragment
explanation: He appears as a human being, but with a supernatural quality. He is not a shepherd or a herdsman. He wears a fur coat that is as dark as a raven's wing, which is impervious to rain, wind, and dew. In the midst of a storm, it remains fresh and blue like the first buds of spring. His helmet is adorned with a spring-like grace that matches his youthful and blooming face.

stanza:
A harp is from his shoulder slung;
Resting the harp upon his knee,
To words of a forgotten tongue
He suits its melody.
Of flocks upon the neighbouring hill
He is the darling and the joy;
And often, when no cause appears,
The mountain-ponies prick their ears,
--They hear the Danish Boy,
While in the dell he sings alone
Beside the tree and corner-stone.
title: The Danish Boy: A Fragment
explanation: The Danish Boy carries a harp slung from his shoulder and rests it on his knee to play a melody in a forgotten language. He is beloved by the nearby flocks and even mountain-ponies seem to perk up and listen when he sings in the valley beside a tree and corner-stone.

stanza:
There sits he; in his face you spy
No trace of a ferocious air,
Nor ever was a cloudless sky
So steady or so fair.
The lovely Danish Boy is blest
And happy in his flowery cove:
From bloody deeds his thoughts are far;
And yet he warbles songs of war,
That seem like songs of love,
For calm and gentle is his mien;
Like a dead Boy he is serene.
title: The Danish Boy: A Fragment
explanation: The Danish Boy appears peaceful and content, lacking any signs of aggression or violence in his demeanor. He resides in a picturesque environment surrounded by flowers and seems to have no desire for bloodshed. However, his songs of war sound surprisingly similar to love songs. Despite his apparent tranquility, the Danish Boy's behavior resembles that of a lifeless corpse, exhibiting a serene and detached disposition.

stanza:
There's something in a flying horse,
There's something in a huge balloon;
But through the clouds I'll never float
Until I have a little Boat,
Shaped like the crescent-moon.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The speaker expresses the appeal of various means of transportation, such as a flying horse or a huge balloon, but ultimately desires a boat shaped like a crescent-moon to sail through the clouds. This desire suggests a sense of adventure and a longing to explore new heights.

stanza:
And now I 'have' a little Boat,
In shape a very crescent-moon
Fast through the clouds my boat can sail;
But if perchance your faith should fail,
Look up--and you shall see me soon!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I have a small boat that looks like a crescent moon and can swiftly sail through the clouds. However, if you happen to lose faith in me, just look up and I will soon appear before you.

stanza:
The woods, my Friends, are round you roaring,
Rocking and roaring like a sea;
The noise of danger's in your ears,
And ye have all a thousand fears
Both for my little Boat and me!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The woods are making a loud and threatening noise like a rough sea around us, my friends. You are filled with fear for both me and my small boat.

stanza:
Meanwhile untroubled I admire
The pointed horns of my canoe;
And, did not pity touch my breast,
To see how ye are all distrest,
Till my ribs ached, I'd laugh at you!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: As I observe the sharp horns of my canoe without any worries, I cannot help but notice the distress among all of you. However, I cannot bring myself to feel sorry for you as I find it amusing and it even causes my ribs to ache from laughter.

stanza:
Away we go, my Boat and I--
Frail man ne'er sate in such another;
Whether among the winds we strive,
Or deep into the clouds we dive,
Each is contented with the other.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The speaker is expressing their contentment with their boat and the experiences they have shared together. They feel that no other person could handle the boat's fragility as well as they can. The speaker is satisfied with the bond they share with their boat, as they navigate through various weather conditions and reach great heights.

stanza:
Away we go--and what care we
For treasons, tumults, and for wars?
We are as calm in our delight
As is the crescent-moon so bright
Among the scattered stars.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: We are unconcerned with political unrest and conflicts as we embark on our journey. Our joy is unwavering, just like the shining crescent-moon amidst the twinkling stars.

stanza:
Up goes my Boat among the stars
Through many a breathless field of light,
Through many a long blue field of ether,
Leaving ten thousand stars beneath her:
Up goes my little Boat so bright!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: My boat ascends into the vast expanse of the universe, passing through countless fields of shining stars and ethereal blue. With each passing moment, it leaves behind a trail of ten thousand stars below. Despite its small size, my boat shines brilliantly as it journeys upward among the stars.

stanza:
The Crab, the Scorpion, and the Bull--
We pry among them all; have shot
High o'er the red-haired race of Mars,
Covered from top to toe with scars;
Such company I like it not!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I do not enjoy being among the Crab, Scorpion, and Bull. We have investigated them all and have even surpassed the red-haired people of Mars in our endeavors. However, we are now covered in scars from our ventures. I am not fond of this company.

stanza:
The towns in Saturn are decayed,
And melancholy Spectres throng them;--
The Pleiads, that appear to kiss
Each other in the vast abyss,
With joy I sail among them.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The towns on Saturn are in ruins, and there are sad ghosts that inhabit them. However, the speaker finds joy in sailing among the Pleiads, a group of stars that appear to be intimately close to each other in the vastness of space.

stanza:
Swift Mercury resounds with mirth,
Great Jove is full of stately bowers;
But these, and all that they contain,
What are they to that tiny grain,
That little Earth of ours?
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Mercury and Jupiter may have their own charms, but they are nothing compared to the small, unassuming Earth. Despite its size, Earth holds all the wonders of life and nature that make it truly remarkable. The poem suggests that we should not overlook the significance of our planet, and instead take time to appreciate and care for it.

stanza:
Then back to Earth, the dear green Earth:--
Whole ages if I here should roam,
The world for my remarks and me
Would not a whit the better be;
I've left my heart at home.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Returning to Earth, the beautiful green planet, after spending a considerable amount of time away, the speaker reflects that even if they were to explore for countless years, their observations and opinions would not contribute anything significant to the world, as their heart remains in their home.

stanza:
See! there she is, the matchless Earth!
There spreads the famed Pacific Ocean!
Old Andes thrusts yon craggy spear
Through the grey clouds; the Alps are here,
Like waters in commotion!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Look at the Earth, there she is, incomparable! The renowned Pacific Ocean lies before us. The ancient Andes mountain range stands tall with its rocky peak piercing through the grey clouds. The Alps are also present, resembling waves in motion.

title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The tawny slip represents the sands of Libya, while the silver thread symbolizes the river Dnieper. Additionally, there is a beautiful green island that is the Queen of all the other isles. The speaker addresses the fairies, asking them to protect this island from any harm.

stanza:
And see the town where I was born!
Around those happy fields we span
In boyish gambols;--I was lost
Where I have been, but on this coast
I feel I am a man.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Come and visit the town of my birth and witness the fields where I had joyous times as a boy. I may have lost my way at times, but being on this coast makes me feel like a grown man.

stanza:
Never did fifty things at once
Appear so lovely, never, never;--
How tunefully the forests ring!
To hear the earth's soft murmuring
Thus could I hang for ever!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I have never seen fifty things happening at once that were so beautiful. The forests sound so harmonious and peaceful that I could listen to them forever. The gentle murmur of the earth is so soothing that I would love to stay and listen to it for eternity.

stanza:
"Shame on you!" cried my little Boat,
"Was ever such a homesick Loon,
Within a living Boat to sit,
And make no better use of it;
A Boat twin-sister of the crescent-moon!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: My little boat scolded me for being a homesick loon who didn't take advantage of the opportunity to explore while inside a living boat. The boat was like a twin to the crescent moon and it was a shame that I didn't appreciate its beauty and potential.

stanza:
"Ne'er in the breast of full-grown Poet
Fluttered so faint a heart before;--
Was it the music of the spheres
That overpowered your mortal ears?
--Such din shall trouble them no more.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The poet's heart has never been so weak and feeble before. It's uncertain whether the overwhelming music of the spheres was the cause. However, this noise will no longer bother them.

title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: These lower regions have their own attractions, so join me and become my companion. I am willing to do anything for you and show you everything that is here."

stanza:
"Haste! and above Siberian snows
We'll sport amid the boreal morning;
Will mingle with her lustres gliding
Among the stars, the stars now hiding,
And now the stars adorning.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Let us hurry and adventure over the snowy terrain of Siberia, where we can enjoy the beauty of the northern morning. We will immerse ourselves in the radiance of the stars as they glide across the sky, sometimes hidden and sometimes shining brightly."

stanza:
"I know the secrets of a land
Where human foot did never stray;
Fair is that land as evening skies,
And cool, though in the depth it lies
Of burning Africa. 0
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I am aware of the mysteries held within an unexplored territory, untouched by human presence. This land is beautiful, resembling the colors of a sunset, and surprisingly refreshing despite its location in the scorching continent of Africa.

stanza:
"Or we'll into the realm of Faery,
Among the lovely shades of things;
The shadowy forms of mountains bare,
And streams, and bowers, and ladies fair,
The shades of palaces and kings!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: We may venture into the magical world of Faery where we will encounter the enchanting beauty of mountains, streams, bowers and fair ladies, as well as the shadows of grand palaces and monarchs."

stanza:
"Or, if you thirst with hardy zeal
Less quiet regions to explore,
Prompt voyage shall to you reveal
How earth and heaven are taught to feel
The might of magic lore!"
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: If you have a strong desire to explore more adventurous areas, then embarking on a journey will unveil the power of magic in both the natural world and the skies above.

stanza:
"My little vagrant Form of light,
My gay and beautiful Canoe,
Well have you played your friendly part;
As kindly take what from my heart
Experience forces--then adieu!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Dear canoe, you have been a great companion and have served me well. I appreciate all the good times we've had together, but I must now say goodbye to you. I have learned a lot from our experiences, and I hope you take with you the gratitude from my heart.

stanza:
"Temptation lurks among your words;
But, while these pleasures you're pursuing
Without impediment or let,
No wonder if you quite forget
What on the earth is doing.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The speaker warns that temptation is present in the words being spoken. However, if one indulges in these pleasures without restraint, it is not surprising if they become completely oblivious to what is happening in the world around them.

stanza:
"There was a time when all mankind
Did listen with a faith sincere
To tuneful tongues in mystery versed;
'Then' Poets fearlessly rehearsed
The wonders of a wild career.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: In the past, humanity had a genuine belief in the words of poets who spoke in mysterious verses. These poets fearlessly recounted tales of extraordinary experiences and adventures."

stanza:
"Go--(but the world's a sleepy world,
And 'tis, I fear, an age too late)
Take with you some ambitious Youth!
For, restless Wanderer! I, in truth,
Am all unfit to be your mate.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The speaker is urging someone to leave and take an ambitious youth with them. They acknowledge that the world is lethargic and that it may be too late for the youth to make a difference. The speaker considers themselves unsuitable to accompany the restless wanderer on their journey.

stanza:
"Long have I loved what I behold,
The night that calms, the day that cheers;
The common growth of mother-earth
Suffices me--her tears, her mirth,
Her humblest mirth and tears.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: For a long time, I have had a deep affection for everything I see around me, whether it be the peaceful night or the joyful day. The natural beauty of the earth and its simple wonders are enough to satisfy me. The tears and laughter of the earth, even in its humblest form, are enough to bring me joy.

stanza:
"The dragon's wing, the magic ring,
I shall not covet for my dower,
If I along that lowly way
With sympathetic heart may stray,
And with a soul of power.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I do not desire the dragon's wing or the magic ring as my possessions. Instead, I hope to walk the humble path with a compassionate heart and a strong spirit."

stanza:
"These given, what more need I desire
To stir, to soothe, or elevate?
What nobler marvels than the mind
May in life's daily prospect find,
May find or there create?
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: With these things in mind, what else could I possibly want to inspire, calm, or uplift me? There are no greater wonders than those that can be discovered or invented within the mind through the course of everyday life.

title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Sorrow has a powerful influence over people, its impact on the mind and soul is unparalleled. Guilty fear is one of the strongest spells cast by it. Repentance, on the other hand, is a delicate and gentle entity. It possesses divine power, which is evident in the tears it sheds.

stanza:
"But grant my wishes,--let us now
Descend from this ethereal height;
Then take thy way, adventurous Skiff,
More daring far than Hippogriff,
And be thy own delight!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Grant my request and let us leave this lofty place. Then navigate your vessel, which is even more daring than a mythical creature like the Hippogriff, and find joy in your own journey.

stanza:
"To the stone-table in my garden,
Loved haunt of many a summer hour,
The Squire is come: his daughter Bess
Beside him in the cool recess
Sits blooming like a flower.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The Squire and his daughter Bess have arrived at the stone table in my garden, a beloved spot where I have spent many summer hours. Bess is sitting beside her father in the shaded area and looks as lovely as a blooming flower."

stanza:
"With these are many more convened;
They know not I have been so far;--
I see them there, in number nine,
Beneath the spreading Weymouth-pine!
I see them--there they are!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Many others have gathered along with these individuals, and they are unaware of my distant travels. I can see a total of nine people standing underneath the wide Weymouth-pine tree. I am able to clearly see them from my vantage point.

title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The Vicar and his wife sit on one side, and my friend Stephen Otter on the other. As the evening light fades, I must tell them the story of Peter Bell the Potter.

stanza:
Off flew the Boat--away she flees,
Spurning her freight with indignation!
And I, as well as I was able,
On two poor legs, toward my stone-table
Limped on with sore vexation.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The boat quickly departed, leaving behind its cargo with disdain. I, struggling with my own two legs, made my way towards my stone table while feeling frustrated and annoyed.

stanza:
"O, here he is!" cried little Bess--
She saw me at the garden-door;
"We've waited anxiously and long,"
They cried, and all around me throng,
Full nine of them or more!
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Little Bess exclaimed with excitement as she spotted me at the garden door. She and the others had been waiting eagerly for my arrival, and as soon as they saw me, they rushed towards me. There were nine of them or more who had gathered around me.

stanza:
"Reproach me not--your fears be still--
Be thankful we again have met;--
Resume, my Friends! within the shade
Your seats, and quickly shall be paid
The well-remembered debt."
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: Do not blame me for your worries, but instead be grateful that we have reunited. Sit back down in the shade, my friends, and your debts will soon be paid.

stanza:
I spake with faltering voice, like one
Not wholly rescued from the pale
Of a wild dream, or worse illusion;
But, straight, to cover my confusion,
Began the promised Tale.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I spoke with a hesitant tone, feeling as though I had not fully escaped from a strange dream or perhaps an even worse delusion. However, I quickly tried to regain my composure and began to tell the story I had promised.

stanza:
ALL by the moonlight river side
Groaned the poor Beast--alas! in vain;
The staff was raised to loftier height,
And the blows fell with heavier weight
As Peter struck--and struck again.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The Beast was groaning in pain by the river side under the moonlight, but it was all in vain as Peter continued to raise his staff and strike the Beast with even greater force than before.

title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: The Squire interrupted and advised that what was being suggested was against common sense and too risky for everyone. He requested that the story of Peter be told from the beginning before any further actions were taken.

stanza:
----"A Potter, Sir, he was by trade,"
Said I, becoming quite collected;
"And wheresoever he appeared,
Full twenty times was Peter feared
For once that Peter was respected.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: I explained that the man in question was a potter and that he had caused fear on numerous occasions, while only being respected once.

stanza:
"He, two-and-thirty years or more,
Had been a wild and woodland rover;
Had heard the Atlantic surges roar
On farthest Cornwall's rocky shore,
And trod the cliffs of Dover.
title: Peter Bell, A Tale
explanation: For over 32 years, he lived a life of adventure and exploration, wandering through the wilds and woods. He listened to the powerful waves of the Atlantic crashing against the rocky coast of Cornwall and walked along the cliffs of Dover."

stanza:
"And he had seen Caernarvon's towers,
And well he knew the spire of Sarum;
