explanation: If it were up to me, I would have planted this old building in a completely different world, one that is unlike the current world we live in. I would have placed it next to a sea that is always calm and happy, on peaceful land, and under a sky that is always perfect.

stanza:
Thou shouldst have seemed a treasure-house divine
Of peaceful years; a chronicle of heaven;--
Of all the sunbeams that did ever shine
The very sweetest had to thee been given.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: You were supposed to be a holy treasure, filled with years of peace and a record of heaven. Out of all the sunny moments that have ever existed, you were given the most delightful ones.

stanza:
A Picture had it been of lasting ease,
Elysian quiet, without toil or strife;
No motion but the moving tide, a breeze,
Or merely silent Nature's breathing life.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: The ideal picture would be one of tranquility and serenity, where there is no struggle or effort required. The only movement present would be the gentle ebb and flow of the tide or a light breeze, or even just the stillness of nature.

stanza:
Such, in the fond illusion of my heart,
Such Picture would I at that time have made:
And seen the soul of truth in every part,
A steadfast peace that might not be betrayed.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: At that time, I had an idealistic vision in my heart of a picture that would embody unwavering honesty and a sense of tranquility that could not be broken. I wished to see the truth in every corner of this image.

title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Things were once a certain way, but now they have changed. I am now under a new influence and things will never be the same. I have lost something valuable and it cannot be regained. This loss has caused me great pain, but it has also made me more compassionate and empathetic towards others.

stanza:
Not for a moment could I now behold
A smiling sea, and be what I have been:
The feeling of my loss will ne'er be old;
This, which I know, I speak with mind serene.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: I can no longer look at the sea with a happy heart, as I once did, because of the pain I feel inside. This feeling won't go away, but I accept it and speak of it calmly.

stanza:
Then, Beaumont, Friend! who would have been the Friend,
If he had lived, of Him whom I deplore,
This work of thine I blame not, but commend;
This sea in anger, and that dismal shore.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: The speaker addresses Beaumont, who would have been a dear friend to the person they mourn. The speaker praises Beaumont's work and does not blame him for it. They acknowledge the harsh sea and gloomy shore depicted in the work.

stanza:
O 'tis a passionate Work!--yet wise and well,
Well chosen is the spirit that is here;
That Hulk which labours in the deadly swell,
This rueful sky, this pageantry of fear!
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: This is a passionate work that is both wise and well-chosen. The poem describes a ship, or "hulk," laboring in the dangerous waves of the sea while the sky is ominous and foreboding. The language used creates a sense of fear and dread.

stanza:
And this huge Castle, standing here sublime,
I love to see the look with which it braves,
Cased in the unfeeling armour of old time,
The lightning, the fierce wind, the trampling waves.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: I adore this grand Castle, its appearance exudes bravery and strength as it stands tall and unyielding against the harsh elements of nature. Its ancient armor shields it from the lightning strikes, fierce winds, and pounding waves, showcasing its resilience and steadfastness.

stanza:
Farewell, farewell the heart that lives alone,
Housed in a dream, at distance from the Kind!
Such happiness, wherever it be known,
Is to be pitied; for 'tis surely blind.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Goodbye to the heart that chooses to be isolated, existing only in a dream, far away from others. This type of happiness, when found, is a sad thing because it is blind to the joys of human connection.

stanza:
But welcome fortitude, and patient cheer,
And frequent sights of what is to be borne!
Such sights, or worse, as are before me here.--
Not without hope we suffer and we mourn.
title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Let us embrace resilience and a positive attitude, and seek out moments that remind us of the challenges we must face. Even if these challenges seem insurmountable, we must remain hopeful and endure.

title: Laodamia
explanation: The speaker is pleading to the gods to bring back her slain Lord. She has made vows in the hope that her sacrifice will inspire the gods to return him to her. She asks for celestial pity and implores Jove to restore him. The speaker's love gives her faith and she lifts her hands in supplication, her countenance brightening and her stature growing as she waits for the gods' decision.

stanza:
O terror! what hath she perceived?--O joy!
What doth she look on?--whom doth she behold?
Her Hero slain upon the beach of Troy?
His vital presence? his corporeal mould?
It is--if sense deceive her not--'tis He!
And a God leads him, wingd Mercury!
title: Laodamia
explanation: The speaker is experiencing conflicting emotions of terror and joy. They question what the woman they are referring to has perceived and what she is looking at. It becomes clear that she is observing her lover, Hero, who has been killed on the beach of Troy. However, the woman sees his physical form and believes it to be him. She is being led by the god Mercury.

stanza:
Mild Hermes spake--and touched her with his wand
That calms all fear; "Such grace hath crowned thy prayer,
Laodama! that at Jove's command
Thy husband walks the paths of upper air:
He comes to tarry with thee three hours' space;
Accept the gift, behold him face to face!"
title: Laodamia
explanation: Hermes spoke softly to Laodamia and eased her fears by touching her with his wand. He praised her prayer and informed her that Zeus had granted her request, allowing her deceased husband to visit her for three hours. Hermes urged her to accept this gift and to prepare to see her husband once again.

title: Laodamia
explanation: The Queen passionately sprang forward to embrace her Lord once again, attempting to achieve the ultimate connection. However, the ethereal form continually evaded her grasp, causing her to repeatedly reach out in desperation. The apparition would dissipate, only to reform and reappear directly within her line of vision.

stanza:
"Protesilus, lo! thy guide is gone!
Confirm, I pray, the vision with thy voice:
This is our palace,--yonder is thy throne;
Speak, and the floor thou tread'st on will rejoice.
Not to appal me have the gods bestowed
This precious boon; and blest a sad abode."
title: Laodamia
explanation: Protesilus is being informed that his guide has left him and he is being asked to confirm what he sees with his own voice. He is told that the place he is in is their palace and the throne is his. The speaker asks him to speak so that the floor he is standing on will rejoice. The speaker reassures Protesilus that the gods did not give him this vision to frighten him, but to bless his sad abode.

title: Laodamia
explanation: Laodamia should not fear as the ghost before her is not there to frighten or deceive her. The ghost is a reward for her loyalty and her courage has also earned her great rewards. The gifts of Jove are not incomplete as he rewards those who are faithful and virtuous.

title: Laodamia
explanation: The Delphic oracle had prophesized that the first Greek to touch the shore of Troy would die, but the speaker, being a selfless leader, could not be deterred by this warning. He felt that the cause he was fighting for was more important than his own life and willingly sacrificed himself by jumping onto the sandy plain. Despite knowing the risk, he bravely faced his fate and was ultimately killed by Hector.

stanza:
"Supreme of Heroes--bravest, noblest, best!
Thy matchless courage I bewail no more,
Which then, when tens of thousands were deprest
By doubt, propelled thee to the fatal shore;
Thou found'st--and I forgive thee--here thou art--
A nobler counsellor than my poor heart.
title: Laodamia
explanation: You are the greatest hero, possessing unparalleled bravery, nobility, and excellence. I no longer mourn your unmatched courage that drove you to the fatal shore when thousands were filled with uncertainty. You discovered a superior advisor than my limited heart, and I forgive you for your actions.

stanza:
"But thou, though capable of sternest deed,
Wert kind as resolute, and good as brave;
And he, whose power restores thee, hath decreed
Thou should'st elude the malice of the grave:
Redundant are thy locks, thy lips as fair
As when their breath enriched Thessalian air.
title: Laodamia
explanation: Despite your ability to perform harsh actions, you possessed kindness to the same degree as your determination, and goodness to match your bravery. The one who has the authority to bring you back to life has decided that you should escape the cruelty of death. Your hair is abundant and your lips are still as beautiful as when they once enriched the air of Thessaly.

stanza:
"No spectre greets me,--no vain Shadow this;
Come, blooming Hero, place thee by my side!
Give, on this well-known couch, one nuptial kiss
To me, this day a second time thy bride!"
Jove frowned in heaven: the conscious Parc threw
Upon those roseate lips a Stygian hue.
title: Laodamia
explanation: There is no ghost or imaginary apparition that greets the speaker. Instead, they call upon their beloved, who they describe as a blooming hero, to join them on the familiar couch and give them a kiss as they marry for the second time. However, this request doesn't sit well with Jove, who becomes angry, and the Parc, who respond by causing the lover's lips to turn a dark color.

stanza:
"This visage tells thee that my doom is past:
Nor should the change be mourned, even if the joys
Of sense were able to return as fast
And surely as they vanish. Earth destroys
Those raptures duly---Erebus disdains:
Calm pleasures there abide--majestic pains.
title: Laodamia
explanation: My face shows that my fate is sealed, and there is no need to grieve over the loss of earthly pleasures that fade away as quickly as they come. The joys of the senses are inevitably destroyed by time, and even the underworld of Erebus looks down upon them. Instead, serene pleasures and grand pains can be found there."

stanza:
"Be taught, O faithful Consort, to control
Rebellious passion: for the Gods approve
The depth, and not the tumult, of the soul;
A fervent, not ungovernable love.
Thy transports moderate; and meekly mourn
When I depart, for brief is my sojourn--"
title: Laodamia
explanation: The speaker is advising their faithful partner to learn how to control their strong emotions, as the gods prefer a deep and passionate love that is still manageable. They suggest that their partner should try to moderate their intense feelings and show humble sadness when they depart, as their time together is fleeting.

stanza:
"Ah wherefore?--Did not Hercules by force
Wrest from the guardian monster of the tomb
Alcestis, a reanimated corse,
Given back to dwell on earth in vernal bloom?
Medea's spells dispersed the weight of years,
And son stood a youth 'mid youthful peers.
title: Laodamia
explanation: Why not? Hercules had once forcibly taken Alcestis, who had been brought back to life after death by the guardian of the tomb, and returned her to the world as a young woman. And Medea's magic had also reversed the effects of aging, allowing son to appear youthful again among his peers.

stanza:
"The Gods to us are merciful--and they
Yet further may relent: for mightier far
Than strength of nerve and sinew, or the sway
Of magic potent over sun and star,
Is love, though oft to agony distrest,
And though his favourite seat be feeble woman's breast.
title: Laodamia
explanation: The Gods are kind to humans and may continue to be so in the future. Love is more powerful than physical strength or magic and can cause great pain even though it often resides within the weak heart of a woman.

title: Laodamia
explanation: She tells him that she will follow wherever he goes, but he interrupts her and tells her to be quiet. When she looks at him, she feels better, as the pallor has disappeared from his face and he looks beautiful and graceful, with a hint of sadness mixed with happiness.

title: Laodamia
explanation: He spoke of a love that is felt by Spirits in worlds that are peaceful and balanced, with no worries or conflicts to resolve, and where the past is not mourned and the future is certain. He also spoke of the revival of heroic arts, pursued with a more refined sense of harmony.

stanza:
Of all that is most beauteous--imaged there
In happier beauty; more pellucid streams,
An ampler ether, a diviner air,
And fields invested with purpureal gleams;
Climes which the sun, who sheds the brightest day
Earth knows, is all unworthy to survey.
title: Laodamia
explanation: The author describes a place that is more beautiful than anything on earth. This place has clearer streams, a more divine atmosphere, and fields that shimmer with purple light. Even the sun, which lights up the earth, is not worthy enough to shine on this place.

stanza:
Yet there the Soul shall enter which hath earned
That privilege by virtue.--"Ill," said he,
"The end of man's existence I discerned,
Who from ignoble games and revelry
Could draw, when we had parted, vain delight,
While tears were thy best pastime, day and night;
title: Laodamia
explanation: The Soul that has earned the privilege shall enter there, according to the speaker. He states that he had a vision of the end of man's existence, where those who indulged in ignoble games and revelry found only empty pleasure after they parted. Meanwhile, the speaker's companion spent their time in tears, which was the best way to pass the time.

stanza:
"And while my youthful peers before my eyes
(Each hero following his peculiar bent)
Prepared themselves for glorious enterprise
By martial sports,--or, seated in the tent,
Chieftains and kings in council were detained;
What time the fleet at Aulis lay enchained.
title: Laodamia
explanation: As a young person, I observed my peers getting ready for heroic adventures through physical activities or by participating in discussions with leaders. Meanwhile, the fleet at Aulis was held captive and leaders were in meetings, preventing them from embarking on their own quests."

stanza:
"The wished-for wind was given:--I then revolved
The oracle, upon the silent sea;
And, if no worthier led the way, resolved
That, of a thousand vessels, mine should be
The foremost prow in pressing to the strand,--
Mine the first blood that tinged the Trojan sand.
title: Laodamia
explanation: I desired a strong wind and it came. I then consulted the oracle on the calm sea. If no one else was more deserving, I decided that my ship would be the first to land and my crew would spill the first blood on the Trojan sand out of a thousand vessels.

stanza:
"Yet bitter, oft-times bitter, was the pang
When of thy loss I thought, belovd Wife!
On thee too fondly did my memory hang,
And on the joys we shared in mortal life,--
The paths which we had trod--these fountains, flowers:
My new-planned cities, and unfinished towers.
title: Laodamia
explanation: The speaker expresses the pain they felt thinking about the loss of their beloved wife. Memories of their shared joys and experiences in life, such as walking paths, admiring fountains and flowers, planning cities, and building towers, were too fondly held in their memory, causing a bitter pang.

stanza:
"But should suspense permit the Foe to cry,
'Behold they tremble!--haughty their array,
Yet of their numbers no one dares to die?'
In soul I swept the indignity away:
Old frailties then recurred:--but lofty thought,
In act embodied, my deliverance wrought.
title: Laodamia
explanation: The speaker is asking if they should allow the enemy to mock them for being afraid despite having a large army. However, they refuse to let this insult affect them and instead work to overcome their personal weaknesses. Through their determination and action, they are able to overcome their fears and achieve victory.

title: Laodamia
explanation: Although you are powerful in love, you lack reason and self-control. I advise you to seek our reunion in the afterlife through strength and courage. The unseen world has shown empathy towards you, and your emotions should be elevated and made more serious.

stanza:
"Learn, by a mortal yearning, to ascend--
Seeking a higher object. Love was given,
Encouraged, sanctioned, chiefly for that end;
For this the passion to excess was driven--
That self might be annulled: her bondage prove
The fetters of a dream opposed to love.--
title: Laodamia
explanation: Through a desire that is inherent in human nature, strive to rise to greater heights and pursue a noble goal. Love was bestowed upon us for this specific purpose, to encourage and permit us to pursue it. This is why the intensity of love can be overwhelming, as it drives us to surpass ourselves and abandon our ego. It is a test of our commitment to our goal, and our ability to let go of our selfish desires. In this way, love becomes a dreamlike state, where we are bound by the chains of our aspirations rather than our own personal interests.

stanza:
Aloud she shrieked! for Hermes re-appears!
Round the dear Shade she would have clung--'tis vain:
The hours are past--too brief had they been years;
And him no mortal effort can detain:
Swift, toward the realms that know not earthly day,
He through the portal takes his silent way,
And on the palace-floor a lifeless corse She lay.
title: Laodamia
explanation: The woman let out a loud scream as Hermes reappeared. She tried to cling onto the Shade, but it was too late as the hours had passed too quickly. No mortal could stop Hermes from leaving and he quickly made his way towards the other realm. The woman was left lifeless on the palace floor.

stanza:
Thus, all in vain exhorted and reproved,
She perished; and, as for a wilful crime,
By the just Gods whom no weak pity moved,
Was doomed to wear out her appointed time,
Apart from happy Ghosts, that gather flowers
Of blissful quiet 'mid unfading bowers.
title: Laodamia
explanation: Despite being urged and rebuked, she perished in vain. The just Gods, who were not moved by weak pity, deemed her to have committed a willful crime and sentenced her to serve her time alone, away from the happy spirits who enjoy the eternal serenity of unfading gardens.

stanza:
--Yet tears to human suffering are due;
And mortal hopes defeated and o'erthrown
Are mourned by man, and not by man alone,
As fondly he believes.--Upon the side
Of Hellespont (such faith was entertained)
A knot of spiry trees for ages grew
From out the tomb of him for whom she died;
And ever, when such stature they had gained
That Ilium's walls were subject to their view,
The trees' tall summits withered at the sight;
A constant interchange of growth and blight!
title: Laodamia
explanation: Human suffering deserves tears and when hopes are crushed, it is not just humans who mourn but others as well, although humans may believe otherwise. This belief was held by people who thought that a group of tall trees on the side of Hellespont grew out of the tomb of the person for whom someone died. As the trees grew tall enough to see the walls of Ilium, they would wither and die. This was a constant cycle of growth and decay.

stanza:
.   Tax not the royal Saint with vain expense,
With ill-matched aims the Architect who planned--
Albeit labouring for a scanty band
Of white-robed Scholars only--this immense
And glorious Work of fine intelligence!
Give all thou canst; high Heaven rejects the lore
Of nicely-calculated less or more;
title: Inside Of King's College Chapel, Cambridge
explanation: Do not burden the noble scholar with unnecessary expenses, nor should the architect who designed this magnificent work be misguided in their intentions. Although they worked diligently for a small group of scholars, their creation is a grand display of intelligence. Give everything you can, as heaven does not acknowledge the value of precise calculations of excess or lack.

stanza:
So deemed the man who fashioned for the sense
These lofty pillars, spread that branching roof
Self-poised, and scooped into ten thousand cells,
Where light and shade repose, where music dwells
Lingering--and wandering on as loth to die;
Like thoughts whose very sweetness yieldeth proof
That they were born for immortality.
title: Inside Of King's College Chapel, Cambridge
explanation: The man who created the impressive pillars and roof of this structure believed it to be a place of beauty and music, with light and shade in peaceful coexistence. The music lingers and wanders, reluctant to fade away, much like enduring thoughts that prove their own immortality through their sweetness.

stanza:
. From Stirling castle we had seen
The mazy Forth unravelled;
Had trod the banks of Clyde, and Tay,
And with the Tweed had travelled;
And when we came to Clovenford,
Then said my "winsome Marrow ,"
"Whate'er betide, we'll turn aside,
And see the Braes of Yarrow."
"Let Yarrow folk,  frae Selkirk town,
Who have been buying, selling,
Go back to Yarrow, 'tis their own;
Each maiden to her dwelling!
On Yarrow's banks let her herons feed,
Hares couch, and rabbits burrow!
But we will downward with the Tweed
Nor turn aside to Yarrow.
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: After visiting Stirling Castle and exploring the rivers of Clyde, Tay, and Tweed, the speaker and their companion, "winsome Marrow," reach Clovenford. Marrow suggests they visit the Braes of Yarrow, but the speaker disagrees, suggesting that the people of Yarrow should return home and let the herons, hares, and rabbits enjoy the riverbanks. They decide to continue their journey down the Tweed, without turning aside to Yarrow.

stanza:
"There's Galla Water, Leader Haughs,
Both lying right before us;
And Dryborough, where with chiming Tweed
The lintwhites sing in chorus;
There's pleasant Tiviot-dale, a land
Made blithe with plough and harrow:
Why throw away a needful day
To go in search of Yarrow?
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: There are many beautiful places nearby, including Galla Water, Leader Haughs, and Dryborough where the lintwhites sing with the Tweed River. Tiviot-dale is also a pleasant land made lively with farming. With so much to explore, why waste a necessary day searching for Yarrow?

stanza:
"What's Yarrow but a river bare,
That glides the dark hills under?
There are a thousand such elsewhere
As worthy of your wonder."
--Strange words they seemed of slight and scorn;
My True-love sighed for sorrow;
And looked me in the face, to think
I thus could speak of Yarrow!
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: The speaker questions the significance of the Yarrow River, stating that there are many other rivers just like it. However, the speaker's true love is upset by this statement and sees it as disrespectful to the Yarrow River.

stanza:
"Oh! green," said I, "are Yarrow's holms,
And sweet is Yarrow flowing!
Fair hangs the apple frae the rock,
But we will leave it growing.
O'er hilly path, and open Strath,
We'll wander Scotland thorough;
But, though so near, we will not turn
Into the dale of Yarrow.
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: "I find Yarrow's meadows to be green and its flowing river to be sweet," I exclaimed. "Although there is a tempting apple hanging from the rock, we will leave it there. Instead, we will travel through Scotland's hills and valleys, but we will not venture into Yarrow's valley despite its proximity."

stanza:
"Let beeves and home-bred kine partake
The sweets of Burn-mill meadow,
The swan on still St. Mary's Lake
Float double, swan and shadow!
We will not see them; will not go,
To-day, nor yet to-morrow;
Enough if in our hearts we know
There's such a place as Yarrow.
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: Let the cows of the area enjoy the lush meadows of Burn-mill, while the graceful swan glides along the serene St. Mary's Lake, casting a mirrored image. Although we may not witness these sights today or tomorrow, it is sufficient to hold the knowledge of the existence of such a beautiful location as Yarrow in our hearts.

stanza:
"Be Yarrow stream unseen, unknown!
It must, or we shall rue it:
We have a vision of our own;
Ah! why should we undo it?
The treasured dreams of times long past,
We'll keep them, winsome Marrow!
For when we'er there, although 'tis fair,
'Twill be another Yarrow!
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: Let the Yarrow stream remain hidden and undiscovered, for if it is not, we will regret it. We have our own unique vision and it would be a shame to abandon it. We will hold on to the cherished memories of days gone by, my dear friend Marrow. For even if we were to return to Yarrow, it would not be the same as it once was."

stanza:
"If Care with freezing years should come,
And wandering seem but folly,--
Should we be loth to stir from home,
And yet be melancholy;
Should life be dull, and spirits low,
'Twill soothe us in our sorrow,
That earth has something yet to show,
The bonny holms of Yarrow!"
title: Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: If old age and aimless wandering seem pointless, causing us to become reluctant to leave our homes and feel sad, the beauty of the Yarrow valley can offer comfort during our sorrowful times. Even if life seems dull and our spirits are low, the picturesque landscape of the holms of Yarrow can remind us of the beauty that still exists in the world.

stanza:
WHILE from the purpling east departs
The star that led the dawn,
Blithe Flora from her couch upstarts,
For May is on the lawn.
A quickening hope, a freshening glee,
Foreran the expected Power,
Whose first-drawn breath, from bush and tree,
Shakes off that pearly shower.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: As the morning star fades from the eastern sky, Flora awakens with joy as May has arrived. The anticipated power of spring is felt in the form of a renewed sense of hope and happiness. The first breaths of this power cause a shower of dew to fall from the trees and bushes.

title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Nature embraces the presence of a powerful force that moderates the extreme seasons and adds radiance to the sun's heat like the dewy shine of the morning. The lively chirping sounds of the birds and the gentle hum of the air bring joy and excitement to the trembling heart of all living things.

stanza:
Time was, blest Power! when youth and maids
At peep of dawn would rise,
And wander forth, in forest glades
Thy birth to solemnize.
Though mute the song---to grace the rite
Untouched the hawthorn bough,
Thy Spirit triumphs o'er the slight;
Man changes, but not Thou!
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Once upon a time, in the past, young men and women would wake up early in the morning to celebrate your birth by going into the forest. They would not sing, nor use hawthorn branches as decoration, but your spirit still prevails despite the lack of traditional practices. Humans may change over time, but you remain constant.

stanza:
Thy feathered Lieges bill and wings
In love's disport employ;
Warmed by thy influence, creeping things
Awake to silent joy:
Queen art thou still for each gay plant
Where the slim wild deer roves;
And served in depths where fishes haunt
Their own mysterious groves.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The birds are playing and using their beaks and wings because of their love for each other, thanks to your warmth. Even the smallest of creatures are happy and awake because of you. You are the queen of all the beautiful plants, where the deer roam free. You are also served in the depths of the ocean where fish have their own secret places.

stanza:
Cloud-piercing peak, and trackless heath,
Instinctive homage pay;
Nor wants the dim-lit cave a wreath
To honor thee, sweet May!
Where cities fanned by thy brisk airs
Behold a smokeless sky,
Their puniest flower-pot-nursling dares
To open a bright eye.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The majestic mountain and vast wilderness honor the arrival of May without hesitation. Even the dark and unlit cave pays tribute to this lovely month. In cities where the air is fresh and clear thanks to May's breezes, even the smallest potted flowers dare to bloom under her watchful eye.

stanza:
And if, on this thy natal morn,
The pole, from which thy name
Hath not departed, stands forlorn
Of song and dance and game;
Still from the village-green a vow
Aspires to thee addrest,
Wherever peace is on the brow,
Or love within the breast.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: On your birthday, if the pole where your name used to be celebrated is now empty and devoid of festivities, there is still a promise from the village green that is dedicated to you. This promise is sent to you wherever there is peace and love present.

stanza:
Yes! where Love nestles thou canst teach
The soul to love the more;
Hearts also shall thy lessons reach
That never loved before.
Stript is the haughty one of pride,
The bashful freed from fear,
While rising, like the ocean-tide,
In flow the joyous year.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Love has the ability to teach the soul to love more deeply in places where it flourishes. Even those who have never experienced love before can benefit from its teachings. Love has the power to strip away pride from the haughty and release fear from the bashful. As a result, the joyous year will flow like the rising tide of the ocean.

stanza:
Hush, feeble lyre! weak words refuse
The service to prolong!
To yon exulting thrush the Muse
Entrusts the imperfect song;
His voice shall chant, in accents clear,
Throughout the live-long day,
Till the first silver star appear,
The sovereignty of May.
title: Ode Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The lyre is asked to be quiet and not continue with its weak words. Instead, the Muse entrusts the song to a thrush who will sing with clear accents all day until the first silver star appears, proclaiming the sovereignty of May.

stanza:
Rude is this Edifice, and Thou hast seen
Buildings, albeit rude, that have maintained
Proportions more harmonious, and approached
To closer fellowship with ideal grace.
title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: This building is rude and lacks grace, unlike other buildings that may be considered rough but still maintain a sense of harmony and ideal proportions.

stanza:
But take it in good part:--alas! the poor
Vitruvius of our village had no help
From the great City; never, upon leaves
Of red Morocco folio, saw displayed,
In long succession, pre-existing ghosts
Of Beauties yet unborn--the rustic Lodge
Antique, and Cottage with verandah graced,
Nor lacking, for fit company, alcove,
Green-house, shell-grot, and moss-lined hermitage.
title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: Unfortunately, the skilled builder of our small village did not receive any assistance from the city. He did not have access to the luxurious red Morocco folios that displayed the designs of beautiful buildings that were yet to be built. The builder did not have the opportunity to construct charming and ancient lodges, cottages with graceful verandahs, or delightful additions like alcoves, greenhouses, shell-grots, and moss-lined hermitages to accompany them.

stanza:
Thou see'st a homely Pile, yet to these walls
The heifer comes in the snow-storm, and here
The new-dropped lamb finds shelter from the wind.
And hither does one Poet sometimes row
His pinnace, a small vagrant barge, up-piled
With plenteous store of heath and withered fern,
(A lading which he with his sickle cuts,
Among the mountains) and beneath this roof
He makes his summer couch, and here at noon
Spreads out his limbs, while, yet unshorn, the Sheep,
Panting beneath the burthen of their wool,
Lie round him, even as if they were a part
Of his own Household: nor, while from his bed
He looks, through the open door-place, toward the lake
And to the stirring breezes, does he want
Creations lovely as the work of sleep--
Fair sights, and visions of romantic joy!
title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: Despite its humble appearance, this building provides shelter to animals in need, such as heifers during snowstorms and newly born lambs seeking protection from the wind. Occasionally, a poet will arrive in a small barge loaded with heath and fern gathered from the mountains. He will make his bed under the roof and rest during the day, surrounded by unshorn sheep who appear as if they are part of his family. From his bed, the poet can see the lake and feel the breeze, inspiring him with beautiful sights and dreams of romantic bliss.

stanza:
In distant countries have I been,
And yet I have not often seen
A healthy man, a man full grown,
Weep in the public roads, alone.
But such a one, on English ground,
And in the broad highway, I met;
Along the broad highway he came,
His cheeks with tears were wet:
Sturdy he seemed, though he was sad;
And in his arms a Lamb he had.
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: I have traveled to many far-off lands, but I have rarely witnessed a grown, healthy man crying alone in public. However, I did encounter such a sight on English soil, in the middle of a busy road. This man appeared strong, although clearly upset as tears streamed down his face. He held a lamb in his arms as he walked along the road.

stanza:
He saw me, and he turned aside,
As if he wished himself to hide:
And with his coat did then essay
To wipe those briny tears away.
I followed him, and said, 'My friend,
What ails you? wherefore weep you so?'
--'Shame on me, Sir! this lusty Lamb,
He makes my tears to flow.
To-day I fetched him from the rock;
He is the last of all my flock,
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: When he saw me, he looked away, trying to conceal himself from me, and then used his coat to wipe away his tears. I went after him and asked why he was crying. He responded with shame, saying that the young lamb was the cause of his tears. He had brought the lamb back from the rocky terrain, and it was the last remaining member of his flock.

title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: As a young man, I made mistakes but still managed to buy an ewe and raise healthy sheep from her. Later on, I got married and became successful, having a full score of sheep and increasing my flock every year.

title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker had a single ewe that helped them raise a fine flock of fifty sheep. The sheep grazed on the Quantock hills and prospered, leading to the speaker's own prosperity. However, now only one lamb remains from their stock, and the speaker has lost all care for their own survival, willing to succumb to poverty.

stanza:
Six Children, Sir! had I to feed;
Hard labour in a time of need!
My pride was tamed, and in our grief
I of the Parish asked relief.
They said, I was a wealthy man;
My sheep upon the uplands fed,
And it was fit that thence I took
Whereof to buy us bread.
'Do this: how can we give to you,'
They cried, 'what to the poor is due?'
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker, a man with six children to feed, had to endure hard labor during a difficult time. He asked the Parish for help, but they refused, claiming he was a wealthy man due to his sheep on the uplands. The Parish believed he should sell some sheep to provide for his family. However, the speaker argued that he could not do this, as his sheep were his only source of income. The Parish questioned how they could give him aid when there were others who were poorer than him.

stanza:
I sold a sheep, as they had said,
And bought my little children bread,
And they were healthy with their food
For me--it never did me good.
A woeful time it was for me,
To see the end of all my gains,
The pretty flock which I had reared
With all my care and pains,
To see it melt like snow away--
For me it was a woeful day.
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker sold a sheep as instructed and used the money to buy bread for their children who were healthy as a result. However, the speaker did not benefit from the sale and it was a sad time for them to see the end of their hard work in raising the flock as it disappeared quickly.

stanza:
Another still! and still another!
A little lamb, and then its mother!
It was a vein that never stopped--
Like blood-drops from my heart they dropped.
'Till thirty were not left alive
They dwindled, dwindled, one by one
And I may say, that many a time
I wished they all were gone--
Reckless of what might come at last
Were but the bitter struggle past.
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker in the poem describes the continuous loss of their lambs until only thirty were left. Each loss felt like a drop of blood from their heart, but they eventually became indifferent and wished for all the lambs to be gone. The struggle of losing them was so bitter that they didn't care about the consequences that may follow.

title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: I had a strong inclination towards evil deeds, and my thoughts were filled with wickedness. I suspected everyone I came across of having knowledge of my misdeeds. I couldn't find any peace or comfort, whether inside or outside. I went about my work in a state of restlessness and exhaustion. I had the urge to run away from home and seek refuge in the wilderness where wild animals roamed.

title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker laments the loss of his beloved flock, which he valued as much as his own children. He confesses that as he accumulated more resources, he found himself loving his children less and less. He attributes his misfortune to divine punishment, and despite his prayers, he watched as his flock dwindled away week by week and day by day.

stanza:
They dwindled, Sir, sad sight to see!
From ten to five, from five to three,
A lamb, a wether, and a ewe;--
And then at last from three to two;
And, of my fifty, yesterday
I had but only one:
And here it lies upon my arm,
Alas! and I have none;--
To-day I fetched it from the rock;
It is the last of all my flock.'
title: The Last Of The Flock
explanation: The speaker laments the loss of their flock, which has dwindled from ten to just one sheep. They express sadness at the sight of the decreasing numbers, with the last remaining sheep now lying on their arm. The sheep was retrieved from a rock, and the speaker mourns the fact that it is the last of their flock.

stanza:
Send this man to the mine, this to the battle,
Famish an aged beggar at your gates,
And let him die by inches- but for worlds
Lift not your hand against him- Live, live on,
As if this earth owned neither steel nor arsenic,
A rope, a river, or a standing pool.
title: Argument For Suicide
explanation: The speaker is suggesting that instead of harming others, one should send them to work in a mine or to fight in a battle, or even let an elderly beggar starve to death. However, the speaker warns against physically harming others. They encourage individuals to live their lives as if they did not have access to weapons, poison, or other means of violence. Essentially, the speaker is promoting non-violence and peaceful coexistence.

stanza:
Live, if you dread the pains of hell, or think
Your corpse would quarrel with a stake- alas
Has misery then no friend?- if you would die
By license, call the dropsy and the stone
And let them end you- strange it is;
title: Argument For Suicide
explanation: If you fear eternal damnation, or believe that your body would resist being staked, there are still other options. If you wish to die by choice, you can succumb to diseases such as dropsy or kidney stones. It's odd that there are those who would rather suffer in agony than choose a peaceful end.

stanza:
And most fantastic are the magic circles
Drawn round the thing called life- till we have learned
To prize it less, we ne'er shall learn to prize
The things worth living for.-
title: Argument For Suicide
explanation: The magic circles around life are truly amazing, but we must learn to appreciate life less in order to appreciate the truly important things.

stanza:
If thou in the dear love of some one Friend
Hast been so happy that thou know'st what thoughts
Will sometimes in the happiness of love
Make the heart sink, then wilt thou reverence
This quiet spot; and, Stranger! not unmoved
Wilt thou behold this shapeless heap of stones,
The desolate ruins of St. Herbert's Cell.
title: For The Spot Where The Hermitage Stood On St. Herbert's Island, Derwentwater.
explanation: If you have experienced the joy of being deeply loved by a dear friend, you may be familiar with the moments when love can also bring sadness. In those times, you will appreciate the tranquility of this place and understand the emotions that come with it. As a stranger, you will not be indifferent to the sight of the jumbled stones that remain of St. Herbert's Cell, a testament to the desolation it once housed.

stanza:
Here stood his threshold; here was spread the roof
That sheltered him, a self-secluded Man,
After long exercise in social cares
And offices humane, intent to adore
The Deity, with undistracted mind,
And meditate on everlasting things,
In utter solitude.--But he had left
A Fellow-labourer, whom the good Man loved
As his own soul. And, when with eye upraised
To heaven he knelt before the crucifix,
While o'er the lake the cataract of Lodore
Pealed to his orisons, and when he paced
Along the beach of this small isle and thought
Of his Companion, he would pray that both
(Now that their earthly duties were fulfilled)
Might die in the same moment. Nor in vain
So prayed he:--as our chronicles report,
Though here the Hermit numbered his last day
Far from St. Cuthbert his beloved Friend,
Those holy Men both died in the same hour.
title: For The Spot Where The Hermitage Stood On St. Herbert's Island, Derwentwater.
explanation: The threshold of the self-secluded man, who had previously been heavily involved in social duties, was a place of solitude where he could focus on his adoration of the deity and contemplate eternal things. Although he had left his friend, a fellow laborer whom he deeply loved, behind, he prayed that they would both die at the same time after their earthly duties were fulfilled. His prayers were answered as both the man and his friend died at the same hour, despite the fact that the hermit had spent his final days apart from his beloved companion.

stanza:
MILTON! thou shouldst be living at this hour:
England hath need of thee: she is a fen
Of stagnant waters: altar, sword, and pen,
Fireside, the heroic wealth of hall and bower,
Have forfeited their ancient English dower
Of inward happiness. We are selfish men;
title: England Ii
explanation: Oh Milton, if only you were alive today, England needs you. It is a country filled with stagnant waters, lacking in the heroic spirit of its past. The altar, sword, and pen, as well as the fireside and the wealth of its great halls and homes, have all lost their true English heritage of inner happiness. We have become selfish as a people.

stanza:
O raise us up, return to us again,
And give us manners, virtue, freedom, power!
Thy soul was like a Star, and dwelt apart;
Thou hadst a voice whose sound was like the sea:
Pure as the naked heavens, majestic, free,
So didst thou travel on life's common way,
In cheerful godliness; and yet thy heart
The lowliest duties on herself did lay.
title: England Ii
explanation: Please come back to us and elevate us with your presence. Instill in us good behavior, moral principles, independence, and strength. Your spirit was exceptional, shining like a star and distinct from others. Your words were powerful, resonating like the waves of the sea. Your character was pure and magnificent, resembling the vast and open skies. You walked through life with a joyful and pious attitude, while also humbly accepting the most menial tasks.

stanza:
The Knight had ridden down from Wensley Moor
With the slow motion of a summer's cloud,
And now, as he approached a vassal's door,
"Bring forth another horse!" he cried aloud.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Knight came down from Wensley Moor at a leisurely pace reminiscent of a slow-moving cloud in summertime. As he neared the residence of one of his vassals, he called out for another horse to be brought forth.

stanza:
"Another horse!"--That shout the vassal heard
And saddled his best Steed, a comely grey;
Sir Walter mounted him; he was the third
Which he had mounted on that glorious day.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Upon hearing the exclamation of "Another horse!", the servant promptly prepared Sir Walter's finest mount, a handsome grey steed. Sir Walter then mounted the horse, which marked the third horse he had ridden on this momentous day.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The horse and rider are seen as a joyful pair, with the horse's eyes sparkling as they prance. However, despite the rider's ability to move quickly like a falcon, there is a sense of sadness or gloom in the air.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: This morning, there was a commotion at Sir Walter's Hall as a group of horse riders galloped away, causing a loud reverberation through the area. However, they have all disappeared and it seems like no one knows where they have gone. It was an unprecedented race that has never been witnessed before.

stanza:
Sir Walter, restless as a veering wind,
Calls to the few tired dogs that yet remain:
Blanch, Swift, and Music, noblest of their kind,
Follow, and up the weary mountain strain.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter, feeling restless and impulsive, calls out to his few remaining dogs - Blanch, Swift, and Music - who are the finest of their breed. The dogs obediently follow their master, as they climb up the mountain despite their fatigue.

stanza:
The Knight hallooed, he cheered and chid them on
With suppliant gestures and upbraidings stern;
But breath and eyesight fail; and, one by one,
The dogs are stretched among the mountain fern.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Knight encouraged his dogs with both pleading gestures and stern scoldings, but eventually his efforts became futile as he grew tired and his vision weakened. Gradually, the dogs became exhausted and lay down among the ferns on the mountainside one by one.

stanza:
Where is the throng, the tumult of the race?
The bugles that so joyfully were blown?
--This chase it looks not like an earthly chase;
Sir Walter and the Hart are left alone.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter and the Hart are alone in the chase, without the usual crowd and bugle calls. The scene does not appear to be a typical earthly hunt.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Hart, who is poor, is seen struggling to climb up the mountain. The narrator doesn't provide details on how far the Hart ran or how it died. The Knight comes across the lifeless Hart.

stanza:
Dismounting, then, he leaned against a thorn;
He had no follower, dog, nor man, nor boy:
He neither cracked his whip, nor blew his horn,
But gazed upon the spoil with silent joy.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: He got off his horse and leaned against a thorn bush. He was alone, with no followers, dogs or other people with him. He didn't make any noise by cracking his whip or blowing a horn. He simply looked at the things he had acquired and felt happy without saying anything.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter's silent companion stood near the thorn on which he leaned, witnessing their impressive achievement. The creature was as fragile as a lamb just born and its coat was white with foam, resembling the aftermath of a harsh winter storm.

stanza:
Upon his side the Hart was lying stretched:
His nostril touched a spring beneath a hill,
And with the last deep groan his breath had fetched
The waters of the spring were trembling still.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Hart was lying on his side, stretched out, with his nose touching a spring beneath a hill. As he let out his final breath, the water in the spring was still trembling.

stanza:
And now, too happy for repose or rest,
(Never had living man such joyful lot!)
Sir Walter walked all round, north, south, and west,
And gazed and gazed upon that darling spot.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter was unable to contain his happiness and excitement as he walked around in all directions, admiring and exploring every inch of the beloved location. He had never experienced such a blissful moment in his life and felt overjoyed to have the opportunity to witness such a beautiful sight.

stanza:
And climbing up the hill--(it was at least
Four roods of sheer ascent) Sir Walter found
Three several hoof-marks which the hunted Beast
Had left imprinted on the grassy ground.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter climbed a steep hill that was at least four roods high and discovered three distinct marks left by the hunted Beast on the grassy ground.

stanza:
Sir Walter wiped his face, and cried, "Till now
Such sight was never seen by human eyes:
Three leaps have borne him from this lofty brow,
Down to the very fountain where he lies.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter wiped his face and exclaimed that he had never seen such a sight before. The individual he was referring to had taken three leaps from the high cliff and landed at the bottom where he now lay in the fountain.

stanza:
"I'll build a pleasure-house upon this spot,
And a small arbour, made for rural joy;
'Twill be the traveller's shed, the pilgrim's cot,
A place of love for damsels that are coy.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: I plan to construct a delightful dwelling here, along with a cozy shelter designed for countryside delights. This will serve as a haven for travelers and pilgrims, as well as a romantic retreat for shy maidens.

stanza:
"A cunning artist will I have to frame
A basin for that fountain in the dell!
And they who do make mention of the same,
From this day forth, shall call it HART-LEAP WELL.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: I need a skilled artist to create a basin for the fountain in the valley. Once it's done, people will refer to it as Hart-Leap Well.

stanza:
"And, gallant Stag! to make thy praises known,
Another monument shall here be raised;
Three several pillars, each a rough-hewn stone,
And planted where thy hoofs the turf have grazed.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: A tribute will be made to the brave and noble Stag by erecting a monument consisting of three pillars made of rough-hewn stone. These pillars will be placed on the very spot where the Stag's hooves have grazed the turf, commemorating its greatness and valor."

stanza:
"And, in the summer-time when days are long,
I will come hither with my Paramour;
And with the dancers and the minstrel's song
We will make merry in that pleasant bower.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: During the summer when the days are lengthy, I will return to this place with my lover. Together, we will celebrate with the dancers and music in this delightful garden.

stanza:
"Till the foundations of the mountains fail
My mansion with its arbour shall endure;--
The joy of them who till the fields of Swale,
And them who dwell among the woods of Ure!"
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: My home and its garden will persist until the mountains crumble. It will bring happiness to those who cultivate the fields of Swale and those who reside in the forests of Ure.

stanza:
Then home he went, and left the Hart, stone-dead,
With breathless nostrils stretched above the spring.
--Soon did the Knight perform what he had said;
And far and wide the fame thereof did ring.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: He went back home and the Hart was dead, lying with its nostrils stretched above the spring. The Knight kept his promise and news of his accomplishment spread far and wide.

stanza:
Ere thrice the Moon into her port had steered,
A cup of stone received the living well;
Three pillars of rude stone Sir Walter reared,
And built a house of pleasure in the dell.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Before the moon had sailed into its port three times, Sir Walter built a house of pleasure in the valley using three pillars of rough stone and a stone cup to hold the living well.

stanza:
And near the fountain, flowers of stature tall
With trailing plants and trees were intertwined,--
Which soon composed a little sylvan hall,
A leafy shelter from the sun and wind.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: There were tall flowers, trailing plants, and trees intertwined near the fountain, creating a small shelter from the sun and wind. The plants and trees formed a sylvan hall, which provided a leafy refuge for those seeking respite from the elements.

stanza:
And thither, when the summer days were long,
Sir Walter led his wondering Paramour;
And with the dancers and the minstrel's song
Made merriment within that pleasant bower.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: During the extended summer days, Sir Walter would take his amazed lover to the bower where they would join in dancing and listening to the melodious tunes of the minstrels, thus creating a joyous atmosphere.

stanza:
The Knight, Sir Walter, died in course of time,
And his bones lie in his paternal vale.--
But there is matter for a second rhyme,
And I to this would add another tale.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Sir Walter, the knight, passed away and was laid to rest in his family's valley. However, there is still more to his story, and I would like to share another tale to continue his legacy.

stanza:
THE moving accident is not my trade;
To freeze the blood I have no ready arts:
'Tis my delight, alone in summer shade,
To pipe a simple song for thinking hearts. 0
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: I am not skilled in creating thrilling or horrifying stories, nor do I have the ability to make people shiver in fear. Instead, I prefer to sit in the peaceful shade during summertime and play a gentle tune that inspires contemplation and introspection in those who listen.

stanza:
As I from Hawes to Richmond did repair,
It chanced that I saw standing in a dell
Three aspens at three corners of a square;
And one, not four yards distant, near a well.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: While travelling from Hawes to Richmond, I came across a peculiar sight in a valley. Three aspen trees were arranged in a square shape, with one tree standing just a few yards away from a nearby well.

stanza:
What this imported I could ill divine:
And, pulling now the rein my horse to stop,
I saw three pillars standing in a line,--
The last stone-pillar on a dark hill-top.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: I couldn't understand what was imported and pulling on the reins of my horse, I stopped to see three pillars on the horizon, the last one being on a dark hilltop.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The trees were colorless and lacked any form of branches or foliage. The square plot of grass was partially ruined, with a dull, yellow tint. It was evident that humans had once inhabited the area, as I had previously noted.

stanza:
I looked upon the hill both far and near,
More doleful place did never eye survey;
It seemed as if the spring-time came not here,
And Nature here were willing to decay.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: As I gazed at the hill from a distance and up close, it appeared to be a desolate and sorrowful place that I had never seen before. The spring season seemed to have skipped this location, and the natural world around it appeared to be in a state of decline, as if it was ready to wither away.

stanza:
I stood in various thoughts and fancies lost,
When one, who was in shepherd's garb attired,
Came up the hollow:--him did I accost,
And what this place might be I then inquired.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: Lost in my thoughts and daydreams, I was approached by a shepherd who came up the hollow. I asked him about the place we were in. He was dressed in traditional shepherd's clothing.

stanza:
The Shepherd stopped, and that same story told
Which in my former rhyme I have rehearsed.
"A jolly place," said he, "in times of old!
But something ails it now: the spot is curst.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Shepherd paused and recounted a tale I had previously written about in my poetry. He described the location as once being a cheerful place, but now it is plagued with problems and cursed.

stanza:
"You see these lifeless stumps of aspen wood--
Some say that they are beeches, others elms--
These were the bower; and here a mansion stood,
The finest palace of a hundred realms!
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The speaker gestures towards a group of dead aspen trees that some people mistakenly identify as beech or elm trees. The speaker then points out that this area was once a beautiful garden, with a grand palace that was considered the best in a vast area.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The arbour is a reflection of its own condition, evident through the visible stones, fountain and stream. However, the great Lodge is elusive and hidden, akin to searching for a forgotten dream that requires half a day's worth of hunting.

stanza:
"There's neither dog nor heifer, horse nor sheep,
Will wet his lips within that cup of stone;
And oftentimes, when all are fast asleep,
This water doth send forth a dolorous groan.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: No animals will drink from the stone cup, whether they be dogs, heifers, horses, or sheep. Sometimes, when everyone is asleep, the water in the cup makes a sad moaning sound.

stanza:
"Some say that here a murder has been done,
And blood cries out for blood: but, for my part,
I've guessed, when I've been sitting in the sun,
That it was all for that unhappy Hart.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: There are rumors of a murder having taken place and some people are seeking justice for the crime. However, the speaker has a different theory and believes that the situation may have resulted from a tragedy that happened to a deer named Hart. The speaker has come to this conclusion after spending time contemplating the situation while sitting in the sun.

stanza:
"What thoughts must through the creature's brain have past!
Even from the topmost stone, upon the steep,
Are but three bounds--and look, Sir, at this last--
O Master! it has been a cruel leap.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The speaker expresses wonder and concern for a creature that has just made a dangerous leap from a high point. They reflect on the thoughts that must have gone through the creature's mind before making the leap, and note that despite the distance being only three bounds from the top, it was still a cruel and risky jump.

stanza:
"For thirteen hours he ran a desperate race;
And in my simple mind we cannot tell
What cause the Hart might have to love this place,
And come and make his deathbed near the well.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Hart ran for thirteen hours in a desperate race. It's unclear why he had an attachment to this place, where he eventually died near a well.

stanza:
"Here on the grass perhaps asleep he sank,
Lulled by the fountain in the summer-tide;
This water was perhaps the first he drank
When he had wandered from his mother's side.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: He may have fallen asleep on the grass, soothed by the sound of the fountain during the summer season. It's possible that the water from the fountain was the first he tasted after leaving his mother's care.

stanza:
"In April here beneath the flowering thorn
He heard the birds their morning carols sing;
And he, perhaps, for aught we know, was born
Not half a furlong from that self-same spring.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: During April, underneath the blooming thorn, he listened to the birds sing their morning songs. It is possible that he was born near the same spring, only a short distance away.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: There is no grass or shade in this place, and the sun has never shone on a more dismal hollow. This will continue to be the case until everything, including the trees, stones, and fountain, has disappeared.

title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The Grey-headed Shepherd's words are commendable and his beliefs align closely with mine. Nature did not overlook the death of this animal, and its passing was grieved by a divine sense of empathy.

stanza:
"The Being, that is in the clouds and air,
That is in the green leaves among the groves,
Maintains a deep and reverential care
For the unoffending creatures whom he loves.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: There is a higher power that exists within the clouds, air, and green leaves of the forests. This being holds a strong and respectful concern for all innocent creatures that it adores.

stanza:
"The pleasure-house is dust:--behind, before,
This is no common waste, no common gloom;
But Nature, in due course of time, once more
Shall here put on her beauty and her bloom.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The pleasure-house has become dusty and abandoned, with the surrounding area also in disrepair. However, this is not just any ordinary desolation, but rather a natural progression over time. Eventually, nature will reclaim the space and restore its beauty and vibrancy once again.

stanza:
"She leaves these objects to a slow decay,
That what we are, and have been, may be known;
But at the coming of the milder day,
These monuments shall all be overgrown.
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: She allows these objects to deteriorate gradually so that we can understand and appreciate what we are now and what we have been in the past. However, as time passes and the weather becomes milder, these memorials will be covered by overgrowth."

stanza:
"One lesson, Shepherd, let us two divide,
Taught both by what she shows, and what conceals;
Never to blend our pleasure or our pride
With sorrow of the meanest thing that feels."
title: Hart-Leap Well
explanation: The speaker is advising the Shepherd to learn a valuable lesson from the natural world. They should not allow their happiness or sense of self-importance to interfere with the suffering of even the most insignificant creature. This advice is based on the idea that all living things deserve respect and compassion, and that it is important to be mindful of the impact of our actions on others. By paying attention to the world around us and being conscious of the feelings of others, we can become better people and create a more harmonious society.

title: November, 1806
explanation: Yet another year passes, and with it comes another devastating defeat. This time, it is an entire Empire that has fallen, leaving us feeling isolated and vulnerable. We are the only ones left to fight against the enemy. However, it is a good thing, for it teaches us that we must rely on ourselves for protection from now on.

stanza:
That by our own right hands it must be wrought;
That we must stand unpropped, or be laid low.
O dastard whom such foretaste doth not cheer!
We shall exult, if they who rule the land
Be men who hold its many blessings dear,
Wise, upright, valiant; not a servile band,
Who are to judge of danger which they fear,
And honour which they do not understand.
title: November, 1806
explanation: We must take responsibility for our own fate and not rely on others for support, or we will fail. Those who are not excited by the prospect of this challenge are cowards. We will be happy if those in power are men who value the country's many blessings and possess wisdom, integrity, and bravery. We do not want a group of submissive individuals who are afraid of danger and do not comprehend honor to judge our future.

stanza:
IN due observance of an ancient rite,
The rude Biscayans, when their children lie
Dead in the sinless time of infancy,
Attire the peaceful corse in vestments white;
title: In Due Observance Of An Ancient Rite
explanation: The Biscayans have a tradition where they dress their deceased infants in white clothing as a sign of respect. This custom is carried out when the child dies at a young age and has not yet committed any sins.

stanza:
And, in like sign of cloudless triumph bright,
They bind the unoffending creature's brows
With happy garlands of the pure white rose:
Then do a festal company unite
In choral song; and, while the uplifted cross
Of Jesus goes before, the child is borne
Uncovered to his grave: 'tis closed,--her loss
The Mother 'then' mourns, as she needs must mourn;
But soon, through Christian faith, is grief subdued;
And joy returns, to brighten fortitude.
title: In Due Observance Of An Ancient Rite
explanation: In a joyous celebration, the innocent child is adorned with beautiful white roses and carried to their final resting place while a choir sings and a cross leads the way. The mother mourns the loss of her child, but finds solace in her Christian faith and eventually regains her joy and strength.

stanza:
His simple truths did Andrew glean
Beside the babbling rills;
A careful student he had been
Among the woods and hills.
One winter's night, when through the trees
The wind was roaring, on his knees
His youngest born did Andrew hold:
And while the rest, a ruddy quire,
Were seated round their blazing fire,
This Tale the Shepherd told.
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: Andrew had gained wisdom from the streams and nature surrounding him, becoming a diligent student of the woods and hills. On a stormy winter night, he held his youngest child close while his other children gathered around the fire. It was then that Andrew shared a tale as a shepherd.

stanza:
"I saw a crag, a lofty stone
As ever tempest beat!
Out of its head an Oak had grown,
A Broom out of its feet.
The time was March, a cheerful noon--
The thaw-wind, with the breath of June,
Breathed gently from the warm south-west:
When, in a voice sedate with age,
This Oak, a giant and a sage,
His neighbour thus addressed:--
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: One sunny day in March, amidst the beating of a tempest, I came across a tall and majestic crag. From its head, an oak tree had grown and a broom sprouted from its feet. The thaw-wind blew gently from the warm south-west, bringing with it the breath of June. Then, the wise and elderly oak spoke to its neighboring crag in a calm voice, sharing its knowledge and wisdom.

stanza:
"'Eight weary weeks, through rock and clay,
Along this mountain's edge,
The Frost hath wrought both night and day,
Wedge driving after wedge.
Look up! and think, above your head
What trouble, surely, will be bred;
Last night I heard a crash--'tis true,
The splinters took another road--
I see them yonder--what a load
For such a Thing as you!
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: For eight weeks, the speaker has been working tirelessly along the mountain's edge, using wedges to break apart the rock and clay. The constant work has been affected by the Frost, who has worked day and night to make the task more difficult. The speaker warns the listener to be mindful of the potential dangers, as the mountain above them could cause trouble. The speaker heard a crash the night before, and the splinters from the falling rock are visible nearby. The sheer weight of the debris is a reminder that the task at hand is not to be taken lightly.

title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: The speaker addresses a woman who is preparing to dress up, reminding her of a dangerous incident that had occurred three years ago. A large rock had fallen from a cliff and was headed towards the woman, but the speaker managed to catch it and it is still hanging above her head to this day. The speaker's words suggest that the woman should be grateful for her life and not take her safety for granted.

stanza:
"'If breeze or bird to this rough steep
Your kind's first seed did bear;
The breeze had better been asleep,
The bird caught in a snare:
For you and your green twigs decoy
The little witless shepherd-boy
To come and slumber in your bower;
And, trust me, on some sultry noon,
Both you and he, Heaven knows how soon!
Will perish in one hour.
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: This excerpt is warning about the dangers of the rough steep, where green twigs decoy shepherd-boys to slumber in their bower. The writer suggests that if the breeze or bird had brought the first seed to this place, it would have been better if they had not, as the shepherd-boys are lured to their deaths. The consequences of falling asleep in this place could be perilous, as both the tree and the boy would perish in one hour on a hot day. This passage is a cautionary tale about the dangers of being seduced by beautiful things that may ultimately bring about one's demise.

stanza:
"'From me this friendly warning take'--
The Broom began to doze,
And thus, to keep herself awake,
Did gently interpose:
'My thanks for your discourse are due;
That more than what you say is true,
I know, and I have known it long;
Frail is the bond by which we hold
Our being, whether young or old,
Wise, foolish, weak, or strong.
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: The Broom starts to doze off but interjects to thank the speaker for their warning. The Broom acknowledges that the speaker's words are true and that they have known it for a while. They believe that the bond that holds our existence together is fragile, regardless of age or strength.

stanza:
"'Disasters, do the best we can,
Will reach both great and small;
And he is oft the wisest man,
Who is not wise at all.
For me, why should I wish to roam?
This spot is my paternal home,
It is my pleasant heritage;
My father many a happy year,
Spread here his careless blossoms, here
Attained a good old age.
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: Disasters can affect everyone, regardless of their status. The smartest person may not have all the answers. The speaker sees no reason to leave their home, which is rich in family history and memories of their father's contented life.

stanza:
"'Even such as his may be my lot.
What cause have I to haunt
My heart with terrors? Am I not
In truth a favoured plant!
On me such bounty Summer pours,
That I am covered o'er with flowers;
And, when the Frost is in the sky,
My branches are so fresh and gay
That you might look at me and say,
This Plant can never die.
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: The speaker reflects on their life and realizes that their situation may be similar to the person they are thinking about. They question why they should be fearful when they are in fact blessed with abundance. They are like a favored plant receiving the generosity of summer, flourishing with beautiful flowers. Even in the winter when frost is present, they remain fresh and lively, as if they cannot die. The speaker contemplates their good fortune and lack of reason to worry.

stanza:
"'The butterfly, all green and gold,
To me hath often flown,
Here in my blossoms to behold
Wings lovely as his own.
When grass is chill with rain or dew,
Beneath my shade, the mother-ewe
Lies with her infant lamb; I see
The love they to each other make,
And the sweet joy which they partake,
It is a joy to me.'
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: The speaker describes the beauty of a butterfly with green and gold wings that often visits their blossoms. They also observe the love between a mother ewe and her lamb, finding joy in their sweet interactions. The speaker takes pleasure in witnessing the wonders of nature that surround them.

title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: She spoke with a carefree and joyous tone, her spirits lifted. The Broom plant could have continued to listen to her words without end, even until the night stars began their ascent. However, the sound of two ravens singing their love song in the oak tree's branches interrupted her speech, bringing a happy melody to the air. At that moment, two young bees arrived on the breeze, settling in her verdant bower to rest or hum along."

stanza:
"One night, my Children! from the north
There came a furious blast;
At break of day I ventured forth,
And near the cliff I passed.
The storm had fallen upon the Oak,
And struck him with a mighty stroke,
And whirled, and whirled him far away;
And, in one hospitable cleft,
The little careless Broom was left
To live for many a day."
title: Oak And The Broom, The: A Pastoral Poem
explanation: During a stormy night, a fierce wind blew in from the north, causing great destruction. The next morning, the speaker ventured outside and witnessed the aftermath of the storm. An oak tree had been struck by lightning and was carried away by the wind. In its place, a small broom plant had survived the storm and was left to grow in a sheltered crevice. Despite the devastation caused by the storm, the speaker notes the resilience of nature and the ability of even the smallest plants to persevere.

stanza:
. The gallant Youth, who may have gained,
Or seeks, a "winsome Marrow,"
Was but an Infant in the lap
When first I looked on Yarrow;
Once more, by Newark's Castle-gate
Long left without a warder,
I stood, looked, listened, and with Thee,
Great Minstrel of the Border!
Grave thoughts ruled wide on that sweet day,
Their dignity installing
In gentle bosoms, while sere leaves
Were on the bough, or falling;
But breezes played, and sunshine gleamed-
The forest to embolden;
Reddened the fiery hues, and shot
Transparence through the golden.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: As a young man seeking love, the speaker reflects on his first encounter with the River Yarrow as a baby. He returns to the area by Newark's Castle-gate, which is now unguarded, and is joined by the Great Minstrel of the Border. The day is filled with serious thoughts and a sense of dignity, but the gentle breeze and sunshine add a sense of boldness to the forest's fiery and golden colors.

stanza:
For busy thoughts the Stream flowed on
In foamy agitation;
And slept in many a crystal pool
For quiet contemplation:
No public and no private care
The freeborn mind enthralling,
We made a day of happy hours,
Our happy days recalling.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: The Stream flowed continuously with busy thoughts, creating foamy agitation, but also stopping at crystal pools for moments of peaceful contemplation. The mind was free from any burdens, whether public or private, allowing for a day full of joyous moments and the recollection of past happy days.

stanza:
Brisk Youth appeared, the Morn of youth,
With freaks of graceful folly,-
Life's temperate Noon, her sober Eve,
Her Night not melancholy;
Past, present, future, all appeared
In harmony united,
Like guests that meet, and some from far,
By cordial love invited.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: The energetic and lively time of youth has arrived, with its charming and playful foolishness. The middle of life brings a more serious demeanor, followed by a calm and peaceful evening. The end of life is not sorrowful, as all stages of life come together in a harmonious union, like a gathering of friends brought together by genuine affection.

stanza:
And if, as Yarrow, through the woods
And down the meadow ranging,
Did meet us with unaltered face,
Though we were changed and changing;
If, then, some natural shadows spread
Our inward prospect over,
The soul's deep valley was not slow
Its brightness to recover.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: If we were to encounter someone like Yarrow, who remained unchanged even as we changed and evolved, and if our own internal struggles and challenges caused us to feel a sense of darkness, we would not remain in that state for long. Our soul's inner light would soon shine through and overcome any shadows that may have temporarily clouded our perspective.

stanza:
Eternal blessings on the Muse,
And her divine employment!
The blameless Muse, who trains her Sons
For hope and calm enjoyment;
Albeit sickness, lingering yet,
Has o'er their pillow brooded;
And Care waylays their steps-a Sprite
Not easily eluded.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: May the Muse always be blessed for her divine work of training her sons to hope and find peace, even in the face of sickness and other obstacles like Care, who is difficult to avoid.

stanza:
For thee, O Scott! compelled to change
Green Eildon-hill and Cheviot
For warm Vesuvio's vine-clad slopes;
And leave thy Tweed and Tiviot
For mild Sorrento's breezy waves;
May classic Fancy, linking
With native Fancy her fresh aid,
Preserve thy heart from sinking!
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: Scott, you must leave behind the familiar hills of Eildon and Cheviot and venture to the warm slopes of Vesuvio and the breezy waves of Sorrento. However, may your imagination, both classic and native, keep your spirits up as you embark on this journey.

stanza:
Oh! while they minister to thee,
Each vying with the other,
May Health return to mellow Age
With Strength, her venturous brother;
And Tiber, and each brook and rill
Renowned in song and story,
With unimagined beauty shine,
Nor lose one ray of glory!
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: May all those who serve you, each trying to outdo the other, bring you back to health and vitality in your old age. May your strength return, and may the rivers and streams, particularly the Tiber, that are famous in song and story, shine with even greater beauty and never lose their glory.

stanza:
For Thou, upon a hundred streams,
By tales of love and sorrow,
Of faithful love, undaunted truth
Hast shed the power of Yarrow;
And streams unknown, hills yet unseen,
Wherever they invite Thee,
At parent Nature's grateful call,
With gladness must requite Thee.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: You have touched the hearts of many through your stories of love, sadness, and unwavering truth. Your influence has spread across countless streams and even to places yet undiscovered. Everywhere you are called upon, you answer with joy and gratitude for the gift of nature. Your power is felt by all who encounter your tales, and you have left an indelible mark on the world.

stanza:
A gracious welcome shall be thine,
Such looks of love and honour
As thy own Yarrow gave to me
When first I gazed upon her;
Beheld what I had feared to see,
Unwilling to surrender
Dreams treasured up from early days,
The holy and the tender.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: You will be warmly welcomed with love and honor, just as the Yarrow greeted me when I first laid eyes on it. My initial fear of seeing what I had cherished since childhood was overcome by the beauty and tenderness of the experience.

stanza:
And what, for this frail world, were all
That mortals do or suffer,
Did no responsive harp, no pen,
Memorial tribute offer?
Yea, what were mighty Nature's self?
