Her features, could they win us,
Unhelped by the poetic voice
That hourly speaks within us?
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: Without the art of poetry to offer tribute and memorialize the actions and experiences of humankind, all that we accomplish and endure in this vulnerable world would be meaningless. Similarly, even the majesty of nature would fail to inspire us without the poetic voice that resides within us and constantly speaks to us.

stanza:
Nor deem that localized Romance
Plays false with our affections;
Unsanctifies our tears-made sport
For fanciful dejections:
Ah, no! the visions of the past
Sustain the heart in feeling
Life as she is-our changeful Life,
With friends and kindred dealing.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: Do not believe that love stories set in specific places are insincere and do not affect our emotions. They do not lessen the authenticity of our tears, shed for imaginary sorrows. The memories and stories of the past keep our hearts alive and help us navigate life's ups and downs, whether we are with our loved ones or not.

stanza:
Bear witness, Ye, whose thoughts that day
In Yarrow's groves were centred;
Who through the silent portal arch
Of mouldering Newark entered;
And clomb the winding stair that once
Too timidly was mounted
By the "last Minstrel,"(not the last!)
Ere he his Tale recounted.
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: Those who were focused on their thoughts in Yarrow's groves that day are called upon to witness. They are asked if they entered the decaying Newark through its silent portal arch and climbed the winding stair that the "last Minstrel" had once hesitantly mounted before telling his tale.

stanza:
Flow on for ever, Yarrow Stream!
Fulfil thy pensive duty,
Well pleased that future Bards should chant
For simple hearts thy beauty;
To dream-light dear while yet unseen,
Dear to the common sunshine,
And dearer still, as now I feel,
To memory's shadowy moonshine!
title: Yarrow Revisited
explanation: Yarrow Stream, may you continue flowing endlessly and carry out your solemn responsibility. It brings me great satisfaction to know that future poets will sing about your beauty for those with simple hearts to appreciate. Even though you remain hidden in the realm of dreams, you are beloved by the common light of day and even more cherished by the vague and indistinct light of recollection.

stanza:
There's George Fisher, Charles Fleming, and Reginald Shore,
Three rosy-cheeked school-boys, the highest not more
Than the height of a counsellor's bag;
To the top of GREAT HOW did it please them to climb:
And there they built up, without mortar or lime,
A Man on the peak of the crag.
title: Rural Architecture
explanation: George Fisher, Charles Fleming, and Reginald Shore, three young boys with rosy cheeks, climbed to the top of Great How where they built a man without using any mortar or lime. The highest boy was not even as tall as a counselor's bag.

title: Rural Architecture
explanation: Ralph Jones was constructed by the people of the town using stones they found lying around. The process of building and naming him was completed in one day. Ralph grew up to be a strong and healthy boy, earning him the nickname "Magog of Legberthwaite Dale" due to his remarkable bone structure.

stanza:
Just half a week after, the wind sallied forth,
And, in anger or merriment, out of the north,
Coming on with a terrible pother,
From the peak of the crag blew the giant away.
And what did these school-boys?--The very next day
They went and they built up another.
title: Rural Architecture
explanation: Within a few days, a strong wind came from the north and blew the giant away from the top of the crag, causing a commotion. The school-boys, however, did not let this discourage them and the very next day they constructed a new giant.

stanza:
--Some little I've seen of blind boisterous works
By Christian disturbers more savage than Turks,
Spirits busy to do and undo:
At remembrance whereof my blood sometimes will flag;
Then, light-hearted Boys, to the top of the crag!
And I'll build up giant with you.
title: Rural Architecture
explanation: Sometimes I have witnessed destructive acts by Christians who were more savage than Turks. It disturbs me to remember them, and my heart becomes heavy. In those moments, I seek the company of carefree boys and climb to the top of a mountain, where I can build and create without fear or worry.

stanza:
O FRIEND! I know not which way I must look
For comfort, being, as I am, opprest,
To think that now our life is only drest
For show; mean handy-work of craftsman, cook,
Or groom!--We must run glittering like a brook
In the open sunshine, or we are unblest:
The wealthiest man among us is the best:
No grandeur now in nature or in book
Delights us. Rapine, avarice, expense,
This is idolatry; and these we adore:
Plain living and high thinking are no more:
The homely beauty of the good old cause
Is gone; our peace, our fearful innocence,
And pure religion breathing household laws.
title: England I
explanation: The speaker is lost and searching for comfort because they feel oppressed by the idea that life is only about appearances and material possessions. They lament that people must constantly strive to shine and be the best, and that greed and extravagance have become the new idols. The simple joys of life and virtues like humility and deep thinking are no longer valued. The speaker mourns the loss of the traditional way of life, where people lived in peace, followed moral principles in their homes, and appreciated the beauty of nature and literature.

stanza:
WELL may'st thou halt-and gaze with brightening eye!
The lovely Cottage in the guardian nook
Hath stirred thee deeply; with its own dear brook,
Its own small pasture, almost its own sky!
But covet not the Abode;-forbear to sigh,
As many do, repining while they look;
title: Admonition
explanation: You may feel a strong emotional pull towards the charming Cottage nestled in its own little haven with a babbling brook, a small pasture, and a seemingly endless sky. However, resist the temptation to long for it as others do, as it is not yours to covet.

stanza:
Intruders-who would tear from Nature's book
This precious leaf, with harsh impiety.
Think what the home must be if it were thine,
Even thine, though few thy wants!-Roof, window, door,
The very flowers are sacred to the Poor,
The roses to the porch which they entwine:
Yea, all, that now enchants thee, from the day
On which it should be touched, would melt away.
title: Admonition
explanation: Those who would take this precious leaf from nature are intruders who show disrespect. Consider how you would feel if your own home was invaded, even if you have few needs. The roof, windows, doors, and even flowers are sacred to those who are less fortunate. The roses that entwine the porch are especially important. Everything that brings joy and enchantment would disappear the moment it is touched by these intruders.

stanza:
I know an aged Man constrained to dwell
In a large house of public charity,
Where he abides, as in a Prisoner's cell,
With numbers near, alas! no company.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: An elderly man is living in a large public charity house, but it feels like a prison cell because he is alone with many people around him.

stanza:
When he could creep about, at will, though poor
And forced to live on alms, this old Man fed
A Redbreast, one that to his cottage door
Came not, but in a lane partook his bread.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: The elderly man, despite his poverty and reliance on charity, was able to move around freely and took it upon himself to feed a robin. The bird did not come directly to his cottage, but instead would partake of the bread he left for it in a nearby lane.

stanza:
There, at the root of one particular tree,
An easy seat this worn-out Labourer found
While Robin pecked the crumbs upon his knee
Laid one by one, or scattered on the ground.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: A tired worker found a comfortable spot at the base of a tree, where he sat down while a robin bird ate crumbs from his knee, either placed there or dropped on the ground.

stanza:
Dear intercourse was theirs, day after day;
What signs of mutual gladness when they met!
Think of their common peace, their simple play,
The parting moment and its fond regret.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: They had intimate relations daily and showed signs of happiness when meeting each other. Their peaceful coexistence and uncomplicated activities were a source of mutual joy. However, when it was time to part, they expressed fond feelings of sadness.

stanza:
Months passed in love that failed not to fulfil,
In spite of season's change, its own demand,
By fluttering pinions here and busy bill;
There by caresses from a tremulous hand.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: Their love continued to thrive, unyielding to the changing seasons, as evidenced by the fluttering wings of birds and the gentle caresses from a trembling hand. Months passed in a state of fulfillment, undeterred by external factors, as their love persisted in its strength and beauty.

stanza:
Thus in the chosen spot a tie so strong
Was formed between the solitary pair,
That when his fate had housed him 'mid a throng
The Captive shunned all converse proffered there.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: The solitary pair formed a strong bond in their chosen spot, which caused the Captive to avoid any conversation when he was later housed among a crowd.

stanza:
Wife, children, kindred, they were dead and gone;
But, if no evil hap his wishes crossed,
One living Stay was left, and on that one
Some recompence for all that he had lost.
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: The man had lost his wife, children, and relatives, but he still had one remaining source of comfort. As long as nothing unfortunate happened to him, this one thing could make up for all that he had previously lost.

stanza:
Oh that the good old Man had power to prove,
By message sent through air or visible token,
That still he loves the Bird, and still must love;
That friendship lasts though fellowship is broken!
title: I Know An Old Man Constrained To Dwell
explanation: The speaker expresses a wish that an elderly man could somehow communicate to a bird, whether through a message delivered through the air or through some other visible sign, that he still loves it and will always love it. The speaker feels that the man's love for the bird endures despite the fact that they are no longer together, and that true friendship can survive even when physical companionship is no longer possible.

stanza:
.   It is not to be thought of that the Flood
Of British freedom, which, to the open sea
Of the world's praise, from dark antiquity
Hath flowed, "with pomp of waters, unwithstood,"
Roused though it be full often to a mood
Which spurns the check of salutary bands,
That this most famous Stream in bogs and sands
Should perish; and to evil and to good
Be lost for ever. In our halls is hung
Armoury of the invincible Knights of old:
We must be free or die, who speak the tongue
That Shakespeare spake; the faith and morals hold
Which Milton held.--In every thing we are sprung
Of Earth's first blood, have titles manifold.
title: It Is Not To Be Thought Of
explanation: The speaker declares that it is unimaginable that the long-standing legacy of British freedom, which has been celebrated throughout history, would be lost or destroyed. The speaker asserts that the British people, who have inherited the traditions of the great knights and writers of the past, must uphold the principles of freedom and honor that have been passed down to them. The speaker emphasizes that the British people are descended from the very first inhabitants of the Earth and have a multitude of reasons to cherish their heritage. Ultimately, the speaker declares that the British people must remain committed to their faith and morals, and must be willing to fight for their freedom or face the possibility of their legacy being lost forever.

stanza:
WHERE be the temples which, in Britain's Isle,
For his paternal Gods, the Trojan raised?
Gone like a morning dream, or like a pile
Of clouds that in cerulean ether blazed!
Ere Julius landed on her white-cliffed shore,
They sank, delivered o'er
To fatal dissolution; and, I ween,
No vestige then was left that such had ever been.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The speaker laments the disappearance of the temples that the Trojan built in Britain's Isle to honor his paternal Gods. These temples have disappeared like a dream that fades away or like a pile of clouds that disappears in the sky. Even before Julius Caesar arrived in Britain, the temples had already vanished due to fatal dissolution, leaving no trace that they ever existed.

stanza:
Nathless, a British record (long concealed
In old Armorica, whose secret springs
No Gothic conqueror ever drank) revealed
The marvellous current of forgotten things;
How Brutus came, by oracles impelled,
And Albion's giants quelled,
A brood whom no civility could melt,
'Who never tasted grace, and goodness ne'er had felt.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Despite this, a British record was discovered in Armorica, which had long kept its secrets hidden and was never conquered by the Goths. This record revealed the incredible history of forgotten things, including the story of how Brutus was compelled by oracles to come and conquer the giants of Albion. These giants were an uncivilized people who had never experienced grace or goodness.

title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: With the help of brave Corineus, he conquered and eliminated the unbearable race from the land that had been polluted for too long. He replaced the old ways with refined arts and customs, resulting in flourishing crops, cities, strong fortresses, and luxurious homes. This led to lasting friendships and faithful love, providing a stable and comforting environment.

stanza:
O, happy Britain! region all too fair
For self-delighting fancy to endure
That silence only should inhabit there,
Wild beasts, or uncouth savages impure!
But, intermingled with the generous seed,
Grew many a poisonous weed;
Thus fares it still with all that takes its birth
From human care, or grows upon the breast of earth.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The speaker expresses joy for Britain, a beautiful land that seems too perfect to be left uninhabited by anything other than wild animals or uncivilized people. However, the speaker notes that alongside the good things that grow there, there are also poisonous plants. This is a reflection of the fact that anything that comes from human care or grows on the earth will have both good and bad aspects.

stanza:
Hence, and how soon! that war of vengeance waged
By Guendolen against her faithless lord;
Till she, in jealous fury unassuaged
Had slain his paramour with ruthless sword:
Then, into Severn hideously defiled,
She flung her blameless child,
Sabrina,-vowing that the stream should bear
That name through every age, her hatred to declare.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Guendolen sought revenge against her unfaithful husband, which led to her killing his lover in a jealous rage. She then threw her innocent child, Sabrina, into the Severn River, defiling it and vowing that the river would bear her name to express her hatred for her husband.

stanza:
So speaks the Chronicle, and tells of Lear
By his ungrateful daughters turned adrift.
Ye lightnings, hear his voice!-they cannot hear,
Nor can the winds restore his simple gift.
But One there is, a Child of nature meek,
Who comes her Sire to seek;
And he, recovering sense, upon her breast
Leans smilingly, and sinks into a perfect rest.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The Chronicle recounts the story of Lear, who was abandoned by his ungrateful daughters. Despite calling out to the elements, lightning and winds cannot help him. However, his meek child, who is in tune with nature, comes to seek him out. Lear finds solace in her embrace and peacefully rests.

title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: In this passage, the reader is introduced to a variety of literary themes and characters, including Spenser's fairy tales, Milton's youthful interests, Merlin's clever plans, and the legendary feats of King Arthur and his knights. The passage also alludes to Arthur's eventual return to the world, wielding his sword for future battles and lifting his country's fame to new heights.

stanza:
What wonder, then, if in such ample field
Of old tradition, one particular flower
Doth seemingly in vain its fragrance yield,
And bloom unnoticed even to this late hour?
Now, gentle Muses, your assistance grant,
While I this flower transplant
Into a garden stored with Poesy;
Where flowers and herbs unite, and haply some weeds be,
That, wanting not wild grace, are from all mischief free!
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: It's no surprise that in a vast array of old traditions, one flower goes unnoticed despite its fragrance. The speaker calls on the Muses to help transplant this flower into a poetic garden, where it can thrive among other flowers and herbs, even if some of them are considered weeds. The garden is a place where wild grace can exist without harm.

title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Gorbonian, a wise and just king, was highly respected and loved during his time as ruler in Britain. His leadership brought prosperity to the country, surpassing that of its neighboring nations. He rewarded and honored those who were deserving, while standing up against oppressors. Gorbonian also showed reverence to the gods, resulting in the growth of fields, temples, towns, and cities.

stanza:
He died, whom Artegal succeeds-his son;
But how unworthy of that sire was he!
A hopeful reign, auspiciously begun,
Was darkened soon by foul iniquity.
From crime to crime he mounted, till at length
The nobles leagued their strength
With a vexed people, and the tyrant chased;
And, on the vacant throne, his worthier Brother placed.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Artegal succeeded his father after his death, but he was not worthy of his father's legacy. His reign started with promise but was soon overshadowed by his immoral behavior. He committed one crime after another, causing the nobles and people to band together and overthrow him, replacing him with his more deserving brother on the throne.

stanza:
From realm to realm the humbled Exile went,
Suppliant for aid his kingdom to regain;
In many a court, and many a warrior's tent,
He urged his persevering suit in vain.
Him, in whose wretched heart ambition failed,
Dire poverty assailed;
And, tired with slights his pride no more could brook,
He towards his native country cast a longing look.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The Exile traveled from place to place, seeking help in his quest to reclaim his kingdom. Despite his persistent efforts in various courts and among many warriors, his pleas went unanswered. He had lost his ambition and was now facing dire poverty. The constant rejection had shattered his pride, and he longed to return to his homeland.

stanza:
Fair blew the wished-for wind-the voyage sped;
He landed; and, by many dangers scared,
'Poorly provided, poorly followed,'
To Calaterium's forest he repaired.
How changed from him who, born to highest place,
Had swayed the royal mace,
Flattered and feared, despised yet deified,
In Troynovant, his seat by silver Thames's side!
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The long-awaited wind blew favorably and the voyage progressed smoothly. After facing many dangers, he landed on shore but was poorly equipped and had few followers with him. He made his way to Calaterium's forest, a stark contrast to his previous life of luxury and power as someone who had held the royal mace and was both flattered and feared in Troynovant by the River Thames.

stanza:
From that wild region where the crownless King
Lay in concealment with his scanty train,
Supporting life by water from the spring,
And such chance food as outlaws can obtain,
Unto the few whom he esteems his friends
A messenger he sends;
And from their secret loyalty requires
Shelter and daily bread,-the sum of his desires.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: In a remote area where a King without a crown was hiding with only a small group of followers, they relied on water from a spring and whatever food they could find. The King sent a messenger to those he considered his loyal friends and appealed for their help in providing shelter and sustenance. All he desired was a safe haven and enough food to survive.

stanza:
While he the issue waits, at early morn
Wandering by stealth abroad, he chanced to hear
A startling outcry made by hound and horn,
From which the tusky wild boar flies in fear;
And, scouring toward him o'er the grassy plain,
Behold the hunter train!
He bids his little company advance
With seeming unconcern and steady countenance.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Early in the morning, while waiting for the issue, he wandered around secretly and unexpectedly heard a loud commotion caused by the hounds and horns. It turned out to be a hunting party chasing after a wild boar, which quickly ran away in fear. As they approached him, he instructed his small group to move forward calmly and confidently.

stanza:
The royal Elidure, who leads the chase,
Hath checked his foaming courser:-can it be!
Methinks that I should recognise that face,
Though much disguised by long adversity!
He gazed rejoicing, and again he gazed,
Confounded and amazed-
'It is the king, my brother!' and, by sound
Of his own voice confirmed, he leaps upon the ground.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Elidure, a royal figure, has stopped his horse during a hunt and is surprised to see a face he thinks he recognizes despite it being altered by hardships. He looks on in joy and disbelief, convinced that it is his brother, the king. To confirm his suspicion, Elidure speaks out loud and, upon hearing his own voice, jumps off his horse.

stanza:
Long, strict, and tender was the embrace he gave,
Feebly returned by daunted Artegal;
Whose natural affection doubts enslave,
And apprehensions dark and criminal.
Loth to restrain the moving interview,
The attendant lords withdrew;
And, while they stood upon the plain apart,
Thus Elidure, by words, relieved his struggling heart.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Elidure gave Artegal a long, strict, and tender embrace which was timidly returned due to Artegal's doubts and apprehensions. The other lords present withdrew from the scene, allowing Elidure to ease the burden on his heart by expressing himself through words.

stanza:
By heavenly Powers conducted, we have met;
-O Brother! to my knowledge lost so long,
But neither lost to love, nor to regret,
Nor to my wishes lost;-forgive the wrong,
(Such it may seem) if I thy crown have borne,
Thy royal mantle worn:
I was their natural guardian; and 'tis just
That now I should restore what hath been held in trust.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Led by divine forces, we have finally reunited, my long-lost brother. Although I may have taken on the role of wearing the crown and royal mantle that rightfully belongs to you, please forgive me for any wrongdoing, as my intentions were to protect and preserve what was entrusted to me. It is only fair that I now return to you what has rightfully been yours all along. Our bond of love and regret has never faltered, and I am grateful for this blessed reunion.

stanza:
A while the astonished Artegal stood mute,
Then thus exclaimed: 'To me, of titles shorn,
And stripped of power! me, feeble, destitute,
To me a kingdom! spare the bitter scorn:
If justice ruled the breast of foreign kings,
Then, on the wide-spread wings
Of war, had I returned to claim my right;
This will I here avow, not dreading thy despite.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Artegal was shocked and speechless when offered a kingdom despite being stripped of titles and power. He felt feeble and destitute, and couldn't believe that he was being offered such a position. He remarked that if justice prevailed among foreign kings, he would have returned to claim his right through war. He boldly declared that he would not fear any opposition and avowed his intentions.

stanza:
I do not blame thee,' Elidure replied;
'But, if my looks did with my words agree,
I should at once be trusted, not defied,
And thou from all disquietude be free.
May the unsullied Goddess of the chase,
Who to this blessed place
At this blest moment led me, if I speak
With insincere intent, on me her vengeance wreak!
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Elidure reassured the other person that he did not blame them. However, he wished that his body language matched his words so that he could be trusted instead of being doubted. He then invoked the goddess of the hunt, who had led him to that place, to punish him if he spoke falsely.

stanza:
Were this same spear, which in my hand I grasp.
The British sceptre, here would I to thee
The symbol yield; and would undo this clasp,
If it confined the robe of sovereignty.
Odious to me the pomp of regal court,
And joyless sylvan sport,
While thou art roving, wretched and forlorn,
Thy couch the dewy earth, thy roof the forest thorn!'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: If the spear that is currently in my hand were the British sceptre, I would gladly give it to you as a symbol of my loyalty. I would even remove the clasp that holds the royal robe if it meant showing my support to you. I find the luxurious lifestyle of the royal court distasteful, and I don't enjoy hunting in the woods without you by my side, especially since you're currently living in misery and despair, sleeping on the damp ground and finding shelter under thorny bushes.

stanza:
Then Artegal thus spake: 'I only sought,
Within this realm a place of safe retreat;
Beware of rousing an ambitious thought;
Beware of kindling hopes, for me unmeet!
Thou art reputed wise, but in my mind
Art pitiably blind:
Full soon this generous purpose thou may'st rue,
When that which has been done no wishes can undo.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Artegal warns that he only sought a safe haven in this realm and cautions against arousing any ambitious thoughts or hopes that he cannot fulfill. He acknowledges the wisdom of the person he is speaking to but believes they are blind to the potential consequences of their actions. He warns that once something is done, it cannot be undone and that they may regret their actions in the future.

stanza:
Who, when a crown is fixed upon his head,
Would balance claim with claim, and right with right?
But thou-I know not how inspired, how led-
Wouldst change the course of things in all men's sight!
And this for one who cannot imitate
Thy virtue, who may hate:
For, if, by such strange sacrifice restored,
He reign, thou still must be his king, and sovereign lord;
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: When someone is crowned, they usually don't consider sharing power or fairness, but you seem to possess a unique inspiration that would alter the norm. You aim to change the way things are perceived by everyone, even for those who cannot follow your example. If this change were to occur, the individual who benefits from it would still be subordinate to you as their king and ruler.

stanza:
Lifted in magnanimity above
Aught that my feeble nature could perform,
Or even conceive; surpassing me in love
Far as in power the eagle doth the worm.
I, Brother! only should be king in name,
And govern to my shame;
A shadow in a hated land, while all
Of glad or willing service to thy share would fall.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: I am unable to achieve or even imagine the level of greatness and love that you possess. You surpass me so greatly, it's like the difference between an eagle and a worm. If I were to become king, it would be only in title as I would be a mere shadow in a despised land. Everyone would gladly and willingly serve you instead.

stanza:
Believe it not,' said Elidure; 'respect
Awaits on virtuous life, and ever most
Attends on goodness with dominion decked,
Which stands the universal empire's boast;
This can thy own experience testify:
Nor shall thy foes deny
That, in the gracious opening of thy reign,
Our father's spirit seemed in thee to breathe again.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Elidure asserts that it is true that a virtuous life is respected and that goodness is rewarded with power and influence, which is the pride of the entire world. He suggests that the king himself can attest to this fact based on his own experiences. Elidure also suggests that even the king's enemies would agree that at the start of his reign, he embodied the spirit of their father.

stanza:
And what if o'er thy bright unbosoming
Clouds of disgrace and envious fortune past!
Have we not seen the glories of the spring
By veil of noontide darkness overcast?
The frith that glittered like a warrior's shield,
The sky, the gay green field,
Are vanished; gladness ceases in the groves,
And trepidation strikes the blackened mountain-coves.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: What if, despite the clouds of shame and jealousy that have overshadowed you, you have overcome them and emerged even brighter? Haven't we witnessed the beauty of spring obscured by the darkness of midday? The sparkling waters and lush green fields that once shone like a warrior's shield have disappeared, and joy has vanished from the groves, replaced by fear in the shadowed mountain coves.

stanza:
But is that gloom dissolved? how passing clear
Seems the wide world, far brighter than before!
Even so thy latent worth will re-appear,
Gladdening the people's heart from shore to shore;
For youthful faults ripe virtues shall atone;
Re-seated on thy throne,
Proof shalt thou furnish that misfortune, pain,
And sorrow, have confirmed thy native right to reign.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Has the darkness lifted? The world now appears brighter than ever before. Similarly, your hidden value will resurface and bring joy to people everywhere. Your youthful mistakes will be redeemed by your virtues. You will reclaim your position of power and prove that your experiences of misfortune, pain, and sorrow have only strengthened your rightful place as a leader.

stanza:
But, not to overlook what thou may'st know,
Thy enemies are neither weak nor few;
And circumspect must be our course, and slow
Or from my purpose ruin may ensue.
Dismiss thy followers;-let them calmly wait
Such change in thy estate
As I already have in thought devised;
And which, with caution due, may soon be realised.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: Don't forget that your enemies are strong and numerous, so we need to be careful and take our time to avoid failure. Send away your followers and let them wait for the changes that I have planned, which can be achieved with caution.

stanza:
The Story tells what courses were pursued,
Until king Elidure, with full consent
Of all his peers, before the multitude,
Rose,-and, to consummate this just intent,
Did place upon his brother's head the crown,
Relinquished by his own;
Then to his people cried, 'Receive your lord,
Gorbonian's first-born son, your rightful king restored!'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The story recounts the actions taken leading up to King Elidure's decision to place the crown on his brother's head in front of the people, with the full support of his peers. He relinquished his own claim to the throne and declared his brother, Gorbonian's first-born son, the rightful king.

stanza:
The people answered with a loud acclaim:
Yet more;-heart-smitten by the heroic deed,
The reinstated Artegal became
Earth's noblest penitent; from bondage freed
Of vice-thenceforth unable to subvert
Or shake his high desert.
Long did he reign; and, when he died, the tear
Of universal grief bedewed his honoured bier.
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: The crowd cheered loudly in response: they were deeply moved by the heroic act, and Artegal was reinstated as the most noble and virtuous person on Earth. He had been freed from the grip of vice, and his high worth and character could not be shaken. He ruled for a long time, and when he eventually passed away, everyone mourned his loss and shed tears for him.

stanza:
Thus was a Brother by a Brother saved;
With whom a crown (temptation that hath set
Discord in hearts of men till they have braved
Their nearest kin with deadly purpose met)
'Gainst duty weighed, and faithful love, did seem
A thing of no esteem;
And, from this triumph of affection pure,
He bore the lasting name of 'pious Elidure.'
title: Artegal And Elidure
explanation: One Brother saved another from succumbing to temptation and betraying their duty and love, which had caused discord and even violence between close relatives. The temptation of a crown was deemed insignificant in comparison to the triumph of pure affection, and the Brother who resisted it earned the name of "pious Elidure."

stanza:
WHY art thou silent! Is thy love a plant
Of such weak fibre that the treacherous air
Of absence withers what was once so fair?
Is there no debt to pay, no boon to grant?
Yet have my thoughts for thee been vigilant--
Bound to thy service with unceasing care,
The mind's least generous wish a mendicant
For nought but what thy happiness could spare.
title: Speak!
explanation: Why are you not speaking? Is your love fragile enough that the unfaithful air of distance can ruin what was once beautiful? Do you owe me nothing, have nothing to offer? Despite this, my thoughts have always been focused on you, serving you with unwavering loyalty. I ask for nothing in return except for your happiness.

stanza:
Speak--though this soft warm heart, once free to hold
A thousand tender pleasures, thine and mine,
Be left more desolate, more dreary cold
Than a forsaken bird's-nest filled with snow
'Mid its own bush of leafless eglantine--
Speak, that my torturing doubts their end may know!
title: Speak!
explanation: Despite the emptiness and loneliness that now consumes my once joyous and affectionate heart, I implore you to speak to me. Even if the words you utter may bring forth more pain, I would rather know the truth and put an end to the tormenting doubts that plague my mind. My heart is like an abandoned bird's nest, surrounded by the barren branches of a leafless eglantine bush, filled with snow and forsaken. So please, speak to me, and bring me the closure I desperately seek.

stanza:
IT is not to be thought of that the flood
Of British freedom, which, to the open sea
Of the world's praise, from dark antiquity
Hath flow'd, 'with pomp of waters, unwithstood,'
Roused though it be full often to a mood
Which spurns the check of salutary bands,--
That this most famous stream in bogs and sands
Should perish; and to evil and to good
Be lost for ever. In our halls is hung
Armoury of the invincible Knights of old:
We must be free or die, who speak the tongue
That Shakespeare spake; the faith and morals hold
Which Milton held.--In everything we are sprung
Of Earth's first blood, have titles manifold.
title: England Iv
explanation: The speaker rejects the idea that the long-standing tradition of British freedom and its reputation will vanish. The speaker acknowledges that the British people may at times rebel against authority, but this does not mean that their freedom will be lost forever. The speaker invokes the legacy of famous knights and writers like Shakespeare and Milton, and emphasizes that the British people must preserve their language, faith, and morals. The speaker concludes by asserting that the British people are rooted in the earliest history of Earth and have many reasons to be proud of their heritage.

stanza:
Glide gently, thus for ever glide,
O Thames! that other bards may see
As lovely visions by thy side
As now, fair river! come to me.
O glide, fair stream! for ever so,
Thy quiet soul on all bestowing,
Till all our minds for ever flow
As thy deep waters now are flowing.
title: Remembrance Of Collins
explanation: The speaker in this poem is addressing the River Thames, asking it to continue to flow gently and peacefully so that other poets can also be inspired by its beauty. The speaker is in awe of the river and hopes that it will continue to spread a sense of calm to everyone who encounters it. The speaker wishes for everyone's minds to be as serene and tranquil as the river's deep waters.

stanza:
Vain thought!--Yet be as now thou art,
That in thy waters may be seen
The image of a poet's heart,
How bright, how solemn, how serene!
Such as did once the Poet bless,
Who murmuring here a later ditty,
Could find no refuge from distress
But in the milder grief of pity.
title: Remembrance Of Collins
explanation: The speaker reflects on a vain thought, but asks that it remain as it is so that it may reflect the image of a poet's heart. The image is described as bright, solemn, and serene. The speaker alludes to a poet who found solace in this place and could only express his distress through the gentler emotion of pity.

stanza:
Now let us, as we float along,
For 'him' suspend the dashing oar;
And pray that never child of song
May know that Poet's sorrows more.
How calm! how still! the only sound,
The dripping of the oar suspended!
--The evening darkness gathers round
By virtue's holiest Powers attended.
title: Remembrance Of Collins
explanation: As we glide silently, let us pause and cease rowing for the sake of the poet. May no other writer ever experience the same pain and sadness. The only noise we hear is the water dripping from the still oar, and the peacefulness of the evening is accompanied by the power of virtue.

stanza:
GREAT men have been among us; hands that penn'd
And tongues that utter'd wisdom--better none:
The later Sidney, Marvel, Harrington,
Young Vane, and others who call'd Milton friend.
title: England Iii
explanation: We have had great men among us who possessed the ability to write and speak wisely, and none were better than those such as Sidney, Marvel, Harrington, Young Vane, and others who were friends with Milton.

stanza:
These moralists could act and comprehend:
They knew how genuine glory was put on;
Taught us how rightfully a nation shone
In splendour: what strength was, that would not bend
But in magnanimous meekness. France, 'tis strange,
Hath brought forth no such souls as we had then.
title: England Iii
explanation: The moralists of the past were capable of action and understanding. They taught us how to achieve true greatness, how a nation should shine with dignity and how strength should be displayed through magnanimous meekness. It is strange that France has not produced similar individuals with such admirable qualities.

stanza:
Perpetual emptiness! unceasing change!
No single volume paramount, no code,
No master spirit, no determined road;
But equally a want of books and men!
title: England Iii
explanation: The speaker describes a perpetual emptiness and unceasing change, where there is no singular book, code, master spirit, or determined road that is most important. Instead, there is equally a lack of both books and people.

stanza:
It is the first mild day of March:
Each minute sweeter than before
The redbreast sings from the tall larch
That stands beside our door.
title: To My Sister
explanation: The beginning of March brings a pleasant change in weather, with each passing moment becoming more enjoyable than the last. A red-breasted bird perched on a tall larch tree by our doorstep sings a sweet melody, symbolizing the arrival of spring.

stanza:
There is a blessing in the air,
Which seems a sense of joy to yield
To the bare trees, and mountains bare,
And grass in the green field.
title: To My Sister
explanation: The atmosphere is filled with a positive energy that brings happiness to the empty trees, the bare mountains, and the green grass in the fields. This blessing seems to create a sense of joy and pleasure throughout the natural world.

stanza:
My sister! ('tis a wish of mine)
Now that our morning meal is done,
Make haste, your morning task resign;
Come forth and feel the sun.
title: To My Sister
explanation: I wish my sister would join me now that we have finished breakfast. I want her to stop what she's doing and come outside to enjoy the sun.

stanza:
Edward will come with you;--and, pray,
Put on with speed your woodland dress;
And bring no book: for this one day
We'll give to idleness.
title: To My Sister
explanation: Edward will accompany you, so please dress quickly in your forest attire and leave your book behind. We will dedicate this day to laziness.

stanza:
No joyless forms shall regulate
Our living calendar:
We from to-day, my Friend, will date
The opening of the year.
title: To My Sister
explanation: We won't let boring traditions control our lives. Instead, my friend, let's start the year fresh from today.

stanza:
Love, now a universal birth,
From heart to heart is stealing,
From earth to man, from man to earth:
--It is the hour of feeling.
title: To My Sister
explanation: Love has become a common experience that is shared between people and is constantly being exchanged between humans and the world around them. This is a time when emotions are heightened and love can be felt deeply.

stanza:
One moment now may give us more
Than years of toiling reason:
Our minds shall drink at every pore
The spirit of the season.
title: To My Sister
explanation: In a single moment, we may gain more insight than years of logical thinking. This moment allows us to fully embrace the spirit of the season and absorb its essence entirely. Our minds will be open to receiving this experience and will allow us to fully immerse ourselves in it.

stanza:
Some silent laws our hearts will make,
Which they shall long obey:
We for the year to come may take
Our temper from to-day.
title: To My Sister
explanation: Our hearts will establish unspoken rules that we will adhere to for a long time. We can use our current disposition as a guide for how we will behave in the upcoming year.

stanza:
And from the blessed power that rolls
About, below, above,
We'll frame the measure of our souls:
They shall be tuned to love.
title: To My Sister
explanation: We will make our souls resonate with love by drawing inspiration from the divine power that permeates everything around us.

stanza:
Then come, my Sister! come, I pray,
With speed put on your woodland dress;
And bring no book: for this one day
We'll give to idleness.
title: To My Sister
explanation: Let's go, my sister! Please get dressed quickly in your forest attire and don't bring any books as today we will dedicate to being lazy.

stanza:
WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like stars in heaven, and joyously it showed;
Some lying fast at anchor in the road,
Some veering up and down, one knew not why.
title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled
explanation: The sea was filled with ships scattered across its expanse, resembling stars in the sky, and exhibited a sense of happiness. Some vessels were stationary, securely anchored in the harbor, while others swayed back and forth, their movements inexplicable.

stanza:
A goodly vessel did I then espy
Come like a giant from a haven broad;
And lustily along the bay she strode,
Her tackling rich, and of apparel high.
title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled
explanation: I saw a large ship emerge from a wide harbor and confidently sail along the bay with its luxurious equipment and attire.

stanza:
The ship was nought to me, nor I to her,
Yet I pursued her with a lover's look;
This ship to all the rest did I prefer:
When will she turn, and whither? She will brook
No tarrying; where she comes the winds must stir:
On went she, and due north her journey took.
title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled
explanation: I had no emotional attachment to the ship, nor did it have any to me, but I watched it with the passion of a lover. Out of all the ships, this one was my favorite. I wondered when it would change its direction and where it was headed. The ship was determined to keep moving and would not wait for anyone or anything. It continued on its journey, heading north.

stanza:
A plague on your languages, German and Norse!
Let me have the song of the kettle;
And the tongs and the poker, instead of that horse
That gallops away with such fury and force
On this dreary dull plate of black metal.
title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: The speaker expresses their disdain for the German and Norse languages and instead desires to hear the comforting sounds of everyday household objects such as the kettle, tongs, and poker. They compare the harshness of the foreign languages to the frantic galloping of a horse on a plain of black metal, emphasizing their preference for the soothing and familiar sounds of their own language.

stanza:
See that Fly,--a disconsolate creature! perhaps
A child of the field or the grove;
And, sorrow for him! the dull treacherous heat
Has seduced the poor fool from his winter retreat,
And he creeps to the edge of my stove.
title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: Observing the fly, the speaker feels sorry for the disheartened creature, which could be a native of the field or the grove. The dull and deceitful heat of the season has led the fly astray from its winter abode, and it now crawls towards the edge of the speaker's stove.

stanza:
Alas! how he fumbles about the domains
Which this comfortless oven environ!
He cannot find out in what track he must crawl,
Now back to the tiles, then in search of the wall,
And now on the brink of the iron.
title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: He is struggling in the vast and uncomfortable surroundings of the oven. He is unable to determine the right path to crawl, as he moves back and forth between the tiles and the walls, and almost falls into the hot iron.

title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: The speaker describes a traveler who is standing still, seemingly lost and confused. The traveler has tried his best to find his way by extending his feelers in all directions, but he cannot find any direction to follow. The speaker uses a metaphor of a traveler to describe someone who is lost and unable to find their way, despite their best efforts. The traveler is presented as a sympathetic figure who is struggling to find his path, but cannot do so without guidance.

title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: The butterfly is in a dire situation as its legs, thighs and feet are sinking into something unknown. It has lost both its eyesight and hearing, leaving it in a state of confusion. Its blood is constantly fluctuating between life and death, causing it to freeze and thaw at the same time. Additionally, the butterfly's wings, which were once beautiful and blue, have become stuck to its sides due to the freezing temperatures.

stanza:
No brother, no mate has he near him--while I
Can draw warmth from the cheek of my Love;
As blest and as glad, in this desolate gloom,
As if green summer grass were the floor of my room,
And woodbines were hanging above.
title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: The speaker notes that they are alone without any siblings or friends nearby, but they can find comfort and happiness in the presence of their beloved. Despite the darkness around them, the speaker feels as content as they would in a bright and sunny room with green grass and flowers.

stanza:
Yet, God is my witness, thou small helpless Thing!
Thy life I would gladly sustain
Till summer come up from the south, and with crowds
Of thy brethren a march thou should'st sound through the clouds,
And back to the forests again!
title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: I swear to God that I would do anything to ensure your survival, little helpless creature. I will care for you until the warm summer months arrive, and you can join your fellow birds in a joyous flight through the sky and back to the safety of the forest.

stanza:
.  These times strike monied worldlings with dismay:
Even rich men, brave by nature, taint the air
With words of apprehension and despair:
While tens of thousands, thinking on the affray,
Men unto whom sufficient for the day
And minds not stinted or untilled are given,
Sound, healthy, children of the God of heaven,
Are cheerful as the rising sun in May.
title: October, 1803
explanation: The current situation is causing great concern and distress among wealthy individuals, who despite their brave and confident nature, cannot help but express their fears and worries. Meanwhile, there are tens of thousands of people who are content with having just enough to get by each day, possessing sound minds and healthy bodies, and are children of God. These individuals are as cheerful as the sun in May, and do not seem to be affected by the same concerns as the wealthy.

stanza:
What do we gather hence but firmer faith
That every gift of noble origin
Is breathed upon by Hope's perpetual breath;
That virtue and the faculties within
Are vital,--and that riches are akin
To fear, to change, to cowardice, and death?
title: October, 1803
explanation: The speaker suggests that the constant presence of hope is necessary for every noble gift to thrive. They argue that virtues and internal abilities are essential and that wealth is associated with fear, change, cowardice, and death. The overall message is the importance of hope in the pursuit of noble endeavors and the dangers of relying solely on material possessions.

title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker wishes for their body to die before they see another day. They had a dream about the northern lights and stars, which seemed to be in conflict in the sky. Although they witnessed this in their dream, the flashes of light still linger in their eyes while they are still alive. The speaker repeats their wish for their body to pass away before they experience another day.

title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker's fire has gone out, but it didn't suffer, and now the ashes are frozen. The speaker is still alive, but without the fire, they feel no joy or desire for the things that used to bring them pleasure. They used to wish to live for warmth, food, and fire, but now they're content to lay there alone, unafraid of death.

stanza:
Alas! ye might have dragged me on
Another day, a single one!
Too soon I yielded to despair;
Why did ye listen to my prayer
When ye were gone my limb were stronger;
And oh, how grievously I rue,
That, afterward, a little longer,
My friends, I did not follow you!
For strong and without pain I lay,
Dear friends, when ye were gone away.
title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker laments that their friends did not force them to keep going for just one more day, as they gave up too easily and feel regret for not continuing on. They reflect on how they felt stronger after their friends left and wish they had followed them, as they were in a good physical state without pain.

stanza:
My Child! they gave thee to another,
A woman who was not thy mother.
When from my arms my Babe they took,
On me how strangely did he look !
Through his whole body something ran,
A most strange working did I see;
---As if he strove to be a man,
That he might pull the sledge for me:
And then he stretched his arm, how wild!
Oh mercy! like a helpless child.
title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker is addressing their child who was given to another woman who is not their biological mother. The speaker vividly describes the moment their child was taken from their arms and the strange look in their eyes. The child's body seemed to be going through something intense, as if they were trying to become a grown man to help pull a sledge for the speaker. However, the child also exhibited vulnerability by stretching out their arm in a wild and helpless manner.

title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker expresses deep affection for someone they refer to as their "little joy" and "little pride." They reveal that they were close to death and would have passed away within two days. The speaker asks their loved ones not to mourn them because they feel that they would have died alongside their loved one. The speaker addresses the wind, wishing they could send a message through it to their friends who left too soon. The speaker laments not having the chance to say everything they wanted to say before their impending death.

title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: I will accompany you through the snow, even though you move with great weight and slowness. Despite my exhaustion and discomfort, I will return to see your tent once more. My fire is extinguished, and the water beside it has turned to snow. Tonight, a wolf has taken my food, leaving me isolated and hungry. Since I am forever alone, there is no reason for me to be afraid of death.

stanza:
Young as I am, my course is run,
I shall not see another sun;
I cannot lift my limb to know
If they have any life or no.
My poor forsaken child, if I
For once could have thee close to me,
With happy heart I then would die,
And my last thought would happy be;
But thou, dear Babe, art far away,
Nor shall I see another day.
title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: Despite my youth, my life has come to an end and I will not live to see another sunrise. I am too weak to move and cannot tell if my limbs have any sensation. If only I could hold my abandoned child close to me before I pass, my heart would be content and my final moments would be filled with joy. Unfortunately, my dear baby is too far away and I know that I will not live to witness another day.

stanza:
A BARKING sound the Shepherd hears,
A cry as of a dog or fox;
He halts--and searches with his eyes
Among the scattered rocks:
And now at distance can discern
A stirring in a brake of fern;
And instantly a dog is seen,
Glancing through that covert green.
title: Fidelity
explanation: The Shepherd hears a barking noise that sounds like a dog or fox and stops to look around. He sees movement in a patch of ferns and soon spots a dog darting through the greenery.

title: Fidelity
explanation: The Shepherd notices a dog that does not belong to the mountain breed, and its movements are untamed and introverted. The dog's cry is unusual, and there is no one else around. The Shepherd is perplexed as to why the dog is in this location since there is no apparent reason for it to be there.

stanza:
It was a cove, a huge recess,
That keeps, till June, December's snow;
A lofty precipice in front,
A silent tarn below!
Far in the bosom of Helvellyn,
Remote from public road or dwelling,
Pathway, or cultivated land;
From trace of human foot or hand.
title: Fidelity
explanation: The location being described is a large cove that holds the snow from December until June. It is surrounded by a tall cliff and has a quiet lake at the bottom. This cove is located deep within Helvellyn and is far away from any roads, houses, or farmland. No human presence can be seen or felt in this remote area.

title: Fidelity
explanation: In this poem, the speaker describes the natural beauty of a tarn, or small mountain lake. The jumping fish and echoing calls of ravens create a sense of solitude and quietness. The arrival of a rainbow, clouds, mists, sunbeams, and wind add to the natural symphony of the tarn. The wind tries to rush past the mountains, but cannot break through their imposing barrier. Overall, the poem highlights the power and majesty of nature in this serene and beautiful setting.

stanza:
Not free from boding thoughts, a while
The Shepherd stood; then makes his way
O'er rocks and stones, following the Dog
As quickly as he may;
Nor far had gone before he found
A human skeleton on the ground;
The appalled Discoverer with a sigh
Looks round, to learn the history.
title: Fidelity
explanation: The shepherd, burdened with troubling thoughts, paused for a moment before following his dog over rough terrain. Soon, he stumbled upon a human skeleton lying on the ground, causing him to gasp in shock. He searched the area, hoping to uncover the story behind this macabre discovery.

stanza:
From those abrupt and perilous rocks
The Man had fallen, that place of fear!
At length upon the Shepherd's mind
It breaks, and all is clear:
He instantly recalled the name,
And who he was, and whence he came;
Remembered, too, the very day
On which the Traveller passed this way.
title: Fidelity
explanation: A man fell from dangerous rocks, causing fear in the area. The Shepherd eventually remembered who the fallen man was, where he came from, and the day he passed through.

stanza:
But hear a wonder, for whose sake
This lamentable tale I tell!
A lasting monument of words
This wonder merits well.
The Dog, which still was hovering nigh,
Repeating the same timid cry,
This Dog, had been through three months' space
A dweller in that savage place.
title: Fidelity
explanation: Listen to this incredible story that I'm about to tell you. It deserves to be remembered forever. There was a dog that had been living in the wild for three months and was still hovering nearby, repeating the same timid cry. This fact alone is amazing and worth noting.

stanza:
Yes, proof was plain that, since the day
When this ill-fated Traveller died,
The Dog had watched about the spot,
Or by his master's side:
How nourished here through such long time
He knows, who gave that love sublime;
And gave that strength of feeling, great
Above all human estimate!
title: Fidelity
explanation: Evidence shows that since the day the unfortunate traveler passed away, his dog has been keeping watch over his master's resting place. The one who provided the dog with such love and nourishment for such a long time understands the depth of emotion that the dog is experiencing, which is beyond what humans can comprehend.

stanza:
The sun has long been set,
The stars are out by twos and threes,
The little birds are piping yet
Among the bushes and the trees;
title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: The sun has already disappeared below the horizon, leaving behind a sky filled with a few stars, which have appeared in pairs and threes. The small birds are still singing and making noise, hidden in the shrubs and trees.

stanza:
There's a cuckoo, and one or two thrushes,
And a far-off wind that rushes,
And a sound of water that gushes,
And the cuckoo's sovereign cry
Fills all the hollow of the sky.
title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: The sky is filled with the sounds of nature, including a cuckoo and a couple of thrushes. The wind rushes in the distance and water gushes, creating a peaceful atmosphere. The cuckoo's distinctive call echoes throughout the sky, dominating the soundscape.

stanza:
Who would go `parading'
In London, `and masquerading',
On such a night of June
With that beautiful soft half-moon,
And all these innocent blisses?
On such a night as this is!
title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: On a June night with a beautiful half-moon, who would want to parade and masquerade in London? This night is too innocent and blissful to engage in such activities.

stanza:
Up with me! up with me into the clouds!
For thy song, Lark, is strong;
Up with me, up with me into the clouds!
Singing, singing,
With clouds and sky about thee ringing,
Lift me, guide me till I find
That spot which seems so to thy mind!
title: To A Sky-Lark
explanation: Let's rise into the clouds together, Lark, because your song is powerful. Sing with me as we ascend and the clouds and sky surround us. Lead me to the place that you envision, and I will follow.

stanza:
I have walked through wildernesses dreary
And to-day my heart is weary;
Had I now the wings of a Faery,
Up to thee would I fly.
There is madness about thee, and joy divine
In that song of thine;
Lift me, guide me high and high
To thy banqueting-place in the sky.
title: To A Sky-Lark
explanation: I have traversed desolate landscapes and now feel exhausted. If I possessed the magical wings of a fairy, I would soar up to you. Your presence exudes both madness and heavenly bliss in your beautiful song. Please lift me up and guide me towards your celestial banquet hall in the sky.

stanza:
Joyous as morning
Thou art laughing and scorning;
Thou hast a nest for thy love and thy rest,
And, though little troubled with sloth,
Drunken Lark! thou would'st be loth
To be such a traveller as I.
Happy, happy Liver,
With a soul as strong as a mountain river
Pouring out praise to the Almighty Giver,
Joy and jollity be with us both!
title: To A Sky-Lark
explanation: The speaker admires the lark, who is joyful and carefree, with a comfortable home and a strong work ethic. The lark is contrasted with the speaker, who is envious of the lark's life and wishes they could be as content as the bird. The speaker praises the liver, which is also strong and joyful, and celebrates the beauty and generosity of the creator. The speaker wishes for joy and happiness to be shared between the lark and themselves.

stanza:
Alas! my journey, rugged and uneven,
Through prickly moors or dusty ways must wind;
But hearing thee, or others of thy kind,
As full of gladness and as free of heaven,
I, with my fate contented, will plod on,
And hope for higher raptures, when life's day is done.
title: To A Sky-Lark
explanation: My journey will be tough and uncertain, filled with obstacles and challenges, whether it be through harsh terrain or dusty paths. However, the sound of your voice, or others like you, fills me with joy and reminds me of the freedom of heaven. With this knowledge, I am content with my fate and will continue on, hopeful for even greater happiness in the afterlife.

stanza:
With how sad steps, O Moon, thou climb'st the sky,
"How silently, and with how wan a face!"
Where art thou? Thou so often seen on high
Running among the clouds a Wood-nymph's race!
Unhappy Nuns, whose common breath's a sigh
Which they would stifle, move at such a pace!
The northern Wind, to call thee to the chase,
Must blow to-night his bugle horn. Had I
The power of Merlin, Goddess! this should be:
And all the stars, fast as the clouds were riven,
Should sally forth, to keep thee company,
Hurrying and sparkling through the clear blue heaven.
But, Cynthia! should to thee the palm be given,
Queen both for beauty and for majesty.
title: With How Sad Steps, O Moon, Thou Climb'st The Sky
explanation: The speaker addresses the moon, commenting on how sad and pale it looks as it rises in the sky. The moon is often seen racing through the clouds like a wood-nymph, but now it seems to be moving slowly and silently. The speaker imagines that unhappy nuns would move at the same pace, constantly sighing. The only way to make the moon move faster would be for the northern wind to blow its bugle horn. If the speaker had the power of Merlin, they would bring forth all the stars to keep the moon company, hurrying and sparkling through the clear blue sky. Ultimately, the speaker declares that the moon is the queen of beauty and majesty.

stanza:
.   A trouble, not of clouds, or weeping rain,
Nor of the setting sun's pathetic light
Engendered, hangs o'er Eildon's triple height:
Spirits of Power, assembled there, complain
For kindred Power departing from their sight;
title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: The Eildon hills are shrouded in a sense of unease, not caused by natural phenomena, but by the departure of powerful spirits. These spirits have gathered at the triple peak to mourn the loss of one of their own.

stanza:
While Tweed, best pleased in chanting a blithe strain,
Saddens his voice again, and yet again.
Lift up your hearts, ye Mourners! for the might
Of the whole world's good wishes with him goes;
title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: Tweed is singing a happy tune, but his voice repeatedly becomes sad. He encourages mourners to lift up their hearts because the entire world is sending their positive thoughts and wishes to the person they are grieving for.

stanza:
Blessings and prayers in nobler retinue
Than sceptred king or laurelled conqueror knows,
Follow this wondrous Potentate. Be true,
Ye winds of ocean, and the midland sea,
Wafting your Charge to soft Parthenope!
title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: The wondrous Potentate is followed by blessings and prayers that are more noble than those received by kings or conquerors. The winds of the ocean and midland sea are urged to be faithful in carrying this Potentate to the city of Parthenope.

title: The Forsaken
explanation: Others find the peace they seek, even after enduring the heaviest storms. Even the guiltiest of minds are granted amnesty for their past. The speaker longs for their sentence to be reversed and only wishes to know the worst, feeling as if their heart will burst with the weight of uncertainty.

stanza:
O weary struggle! silent year
Tell seemingly no doubtful tale;
And yet they leave it short, and fear
And hopes are strong and will prevail.
My calmest faith escapes not pain;
And, feeling that the hope in vain,
I think that he will come again.
title: The Forsaken
explanation: The struggle is exhausting and the passing year appears to offer no clear indication of what is to come. Despite this uncertainty, there is a sense of determination and optimism that prevails. Even in my most peaceful moments, I am still plagued by feelings of discomfort and doubt. However, I cannot help but hold onto the hope that he will return.

stanza:
ONCE did she hold the gorgeous East in fee;
And was the safeguard of the West: the worth
Of Venice did not fall below her birth,
Venice, the eldest Child of Liberty.
title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: She was once in control of the East and protected the West. Venice was as valuable as her birthright and was the first child of liberty.

title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: The City was pure and open, uncorrupted by deceit or violence. When she joined with another, it had to be the unending Sea.

stanza:
And what if she had seen those glories fade,
Those titles vanish, and that strength decay;
Yet shall some tribute of regret be paid
When her long life hath reach'd its final day:
Men are we, and must grieve when even the Shade
Of that which once was great is pass'd away.
title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: What if the woman had witnessed her former glories, titles, and strength deteriorate over time? Despite this, when her life eventually comes to an end, some form of sorrow will be expressed. As humans, we naturally feel sadness when something that was once great is no longer present, even if it is just a shadow of its former self.

stanza:
While from the purpling east departs
The star that led the dawn,
Blithe Flora from her couch upstarts,
For May is on the lawn.
A quickening hope, a freshening glee,
Foreran the expected Power,
Whose first-drawn breath, from bush and tree,
Shakes off that pearly shower.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: As the star that guided the dawn disappears from the sky, Flora wakes up excitedly because May has arrived. There is a sense of renewed hope and happiness in the air, as the expected Power emerges and its breath causes a shower of dew to fall from the trees and bushes.

title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The beauty of nature is enhanced by the presence of a feminine force that brings balance to the seasons and adds radiance to the daytime. The sound of chirping birds and buzzing bees creates a joyful atmosphere, while the gentle hum of the breeze adds to the overall sense of contentment. This force is celebrated for its ability to inspire and uplift, bringing a sense of peace and harmony to all who experience it.

stanza:
Time was, blest Power! when youth and maids
At peep of dawn would rise,
And wander forth, in forest glades
Thy birth to solemnize.
Though mute the song---to grace the rite
Untouched the hawthorn bough,
Thy Spirit triumphs o'er the slight;
Man changes, but not Thou!
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: In the past, there was a time when young people woke up early in the morning to celebrate your birth by going into the forest. Even though they didn't sing or decorate the hawthorn branches, your presence was still felt and revered. While people change over time, you remain constant and powerful.

stanza:
Thy feathered Lieges bill and wings
In love's disport employ;
Warmed by thy influence, creeping things
Awake to silent joy:
Queen art thou still for each gay plant
Where the slim wild deer roves;
And served in depths where fishes haunt
Their own mysterious groves.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Your birds play with their bills and wings because of love, and even the creeping creatures that are usually silent awaken with joy because of your warmth. You are still the queen of every beautiful plant and are served in the depths where fishes have their own secret places.

stanza:
Cloud-piercing peak, and trackless heath,
Instinctive homage pay;
Nor wants the dim-lit cave a wreath
To honor thee, sweet May!
Where cities fanned by thy brisk airs
Behold a smokeless sky,
Their puniest flower-pot-nursling dares
To open a bright eye.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The majestic mountains and vast plains pay tribute to the arrival of spring, as do the humblest of caves adorned with wreaths in your honor, beloved May. Even in the bustling cities, where the clear sky is a result of your refreshing winds, the tiniest of flowers dare to bloom under your guidance.

stanza:
And if, on this thy natal morn,
The pole, from which thy name
Hath not departed, stands forlorn
Of song and dance and game;
Still from the village-green a vow
Aspires to thee addrest,
Wherever peace is on the brow,
Or love within the breast.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: On your birthday, if the pole that bears your name is devoid of celebrations and merriment, there will still be a pledge made in your honor from the village-green. This vow will be directed towards you, wherever there is tranquility or love.

stanza:
Yes! where Love nestles thou canst teach
The soul to love the more;
Hearts also shall thy lessons reach
That never loved before.
Stript is the haughty one of pride,
The bashful freed from fear,
While rising, like the ocean-tide,
In flow the joyous year.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Love has the ability to teach and inspire the soul to love even more deeply. Its lessons are not limited to those who have experienced love before, as even the most guarded of hearts can be opened by its power. Pride is stripped away and fear is overcome as the joy of love flows like an ocean tide.

stanza:
Hush, feeble lyre! weak words refuse
The service to prolong!
To yon exulting thrush the Muse
Entrusts the imperfect song;
His voice shall chant, in accents clear,
Throughout the live-long day,
Till the first silver star appear,
The sovereignty of May.
title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Be silent, weak instrument! Do not attempt to continue the inadequate song. Let the talented thrush take over and sing with clarity all day until the first star of the night appears, proclaiming the reign of May.

stanza:
.  With an incident in which he was concerned
In the sweet shire of Cardigan,
Not far from pleasant Ivor-hall,
An old Man dwells, a little man,--
'Tis said he once was tall.
For five-and-thirty years he lived
A running huntsman merry;
And still the centre of his cheek
Is red as a ripe cherry.
No man like him the horn could sound,
And hill and valley rang with glee
When Echo bandied, round and round
The halloo of Simon Lee.
In those proud days, he little cared
For husbandry or tillage;
To blither tasks did Simon rouse
The sleepers of the village.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: The poem describes an old man named Simon Lee who lives in the shire of Cardigan. He was once a tall and merry huntsman who was known for his ability to sound the horn. However, he now lives a humble life and is no longer able to hunt due to his old age. Despite this, his cheeks remain rosy and he is remembered fondly by the villagers for his cheerful nature. In his younger days, Simon Lee was not interested in farming and instead preferred to wake up the villagers with his lively spirit.

stanza:
He all the country could outrun,
Could leave both man and horse behind;
And often, ere the chase was done,
He reeled, and was stone-blind.
And still there's something in the world
At which his heart rejoices;
For when the chiming hounds are out,
He dearly loves their voices!
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: He was able to outrun anybody and anything in the country, including horses. However, his love for the chase often caused him to become blind and dizzy. Despite this, he finds joy in the sound of the chiming hounds when they are out on a hunt.

stanza:
But, oh the heavy change!--bereft
Of health, strength, friends, and kindred, see!
Old Simon to the world is left
In liveried poverty.
His Master's dead--and no one now
Dwells in the Hall of Ivor;
Men, dogs, and horses, all are dead;
He is the sole survivor.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: Simon has undergone a great transformation, losing his health, strength, friends, and family. He is now left alone in the world, living in poverty while wearing a liveried uniform. His master has passed away, and the once lively Hall of Ivor is now empty, with all its inhabitants - men, dogs, and horses - gone. Simon is the only one left, the sole survivor of a bygone era.

stanza:
And he is lean and he is sick;
His body, dwindled and awry,
Rests upon ankles swoln and thick;
His legs are thin and dry.
One prop he has, and only one,
His wife, an aged woman,
Lives with him, near the waterfall,
Upon the village Common.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: He is thin and unwell, with a body that has become twisted and diminished. His ankles are bloated and his legs are gaunt and dehydrated. He relies on his wife, an elderly woman, as his sole support. The couple lives close to the waterfall on the village Common.

stanza:
Beside their moss-grown hut of clay,
Not twenty paces from the door,
A scrap of land they have, but they
Are poorest of the poor.
This scrap of land he from the heath
Enclosed when he was stronger;
But what to them avails the land
Which he can till no longer?
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: The couple living in the moss-covered clay hut only have a small plot of land located a short distance from their doorstep, yet they are considered to be the most impoverished individuals in the area. The man had previously enclosed the land from the nearby heath when he was in better physical condition, but now that he is unable to cultivate it, the land serves no practical purpose for them.

stanza:
Oft, working by her Husband's side,
Ruth does what Simon cannot do;
For she, with scanty cause for pride,
Is stouter of the two.
And, though you with your utmost skill
From labour could not wean them,
'Tis little, very little--all
That they can do between them.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: Ruth works alongside her husband, Simon, and is often able to do tasks that he cannot. Despite having little reason to be proud, Ruth is stronger than Simon. However, even with their combined efforts, they are only able to accomplish very little and are unable to be weaned from their labor.

stanza:
Few months of life has he in store
As he to you will tell,
For still, the more he works, the more
Do his weak ankles swell.
My gentle Reader, I perceive,
How patiently you've waited,
And now I fear that you expect
Some tale will be related.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: The speaker indicates that he has only a few months left to live, and he shares with the reader that despite his efforts, his weak ankles continue to swell. The speaker acknowledges the reader's patience and suggests that the reader may be anticipating a story.

stanza:
O Reader! had you in your mind
Such stores as silent thought can bring,
O gentle Reader! you would find
A tale in every thing.
What more I have to say is short,
And you must kindly take it:
It is no tale; but, should you think,
Perhaps a tale you'll make it.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: Dear reader, if you were to contemplate the wealth of ideas that can be discovered through introspection, you would be amazed at the stories that abound in every aspect of life. I have little else to add, but I implore you to consider my words with an open mind. Although what I present is not a fully-formed tale, it may yet inspire you to create one of your own.

stanza:
One summer-day I chanced to see
This old Man doing all he could
To unearth the root of an old tree,
A stump of rotten wood.
The mattock tottered in his hand;
So vain was his endeavour,
That at the root of the old tree
He might have worked for ever.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: On a summer day, I witnessed an old man trying to dig out the root of a decaying tree stump. He struggled with the mattock in his hand and despite his efforts, he was unable to uncover the root. His attempts were in vain and it seemed as though he could have worked at it forever without any success.

stanza:
"You're overtasked, good Simon Lee,
Give me your tool," to him I said;
And at the word right gladly he
Received my proffered aid.
I struck, and with a single blow
The tangled root I severed,
At which the poor old Man so long
And vainly had endeavoured.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: The speaker, addressing Simon Lee, recognizes that the old man is overburdened with work and offers to help him by taking his tool. Simon Lee accepts the offer with gratitude. The speaker then uses the tool to quickly and easily sever a tangled root that Simon Lee had been struggling with for a long time. The old man is relieved and grateful, and the speaker moves on, having made a small but meaningful difference in Simon Lee's life.

stanza:
The tears into his eyes were brought,
And thanks and praises seemed to run
So fast out of his heart, I thought
They never would have done.
--I've heard of hearts unkind, kind deeds
With coldness still returning;
Alas! the gratitude of men
Hath oftener left me mourning.
title: Simon Lee: The Old Huntsman
explanation: The man was moved to tears and overflowing with thanks and praise, which seemed to pour out of his heart endlessly. The speaker reflects on the rarity of such genuine gratitude, having experienced more instances of unkindness and ingratitude in their own life. The poem highlights the power and beauty of expressing gratitude and the sadness that can come from not receiving it in return.

title: Alas! What Boots The Long Laborious Quest
