explanation: He stands against the wall, making noise without stopping, fueled by the energy his hat brings him as people of all ages and economic backgrounds offer him gifts. Even the youngest and poorest give what they can, with a boy who only has a penny to his name offering it up to the man.

stanza:
O blest are the hearers, and proud be the hand
Of the pleasure it spreads through so thankful a band;
I am glad for him, blind as he is!--all the while
If they speak 'tis to praise, and they praise with a smile.
title: Power Of Music
explanation: How fortunate are those who listen to this speaker and how proud he is to bring pleasure to such a grateful audience. Even though he cannot see, the speaker is pleased for the praise he receives from his listeners, who speak only to compliment him with smiles.

stanza:
That tall Man, a giant in bulk and in height,
Not an inch of his body is free from delight;
Can he keep himself still, if he would? oh, not he!
The music stirs in him like wind through a tree.
title: Power Of Music
explanation: The man described is both physically and emotionally large. He is constantly moved by music, which seems to flow through him like wind through a tree. Despite his size, he cannot keep still when he hears music. Every inch of his body is engaged in the pleasure it brings him.

stanza:
Mark that Cripple who leans on his crutch; like a tower
That long has leaned forward, leans hour after hour!--
That Mother, whose spirit in fetters is bound,
While she dandles the Babe in her arms to the sound.
title: Power Of Music
explanation: Observe the disabled person who relies on their crutch, appearing as a leaning tower that has been in that position for a prolonged time. Witness the mother who feels trapped and unable to move freely as she comforts her child while listening to music.

stanza:
Now, coaches and chariots! roar on like a stream;
Here are twenty souls happy as souls in a dream:
They are deaf to your murmurs--they care not for you,
Nor what ye are flying, nor what ye pursue!
title: Power Of Music
explanation: Move forward, coaches and chariots, with the sound of rushing water! There are twenty joyful individuals here, as content as those in a state of blissful slumber. They are unresponsive to your grumblings and are unconcerned with your destination or purpose!

stanza:
EVEN as a dragon's eye that feels the stress
Of a bedimming sleep, or as a lamp
Suddenly glaring through sepulchral damp,
So burns yon Taper 'mid a black recess
Of mountains, silent, dreary, motionless:
The lake below reflects it not; the sky,
Muffled in clouds, affords no company
To mitigate and cheer its loneliness.
title: Even As A Dragons Eye That Feels The Stress
explanation: The Taper, burning brightly in the midst of a dark and desolate mountain range, is reminiscent of a dragon's eye struggling to stay awake or a lamp suddenly shining through a misty graveyard. Despite its solitary location, the Taper burns fiercely, with no reflection in the still lake below and no companionship from the cloudy sky above. Its isolation is palpable, yet it perseveres, casting its light into the darkness without faltering.

stanza:
Yet, round the body of that joyless Thing
Which sends so far its melancholy light,
Perhaps are seated in domestic ring
A gay society with faces bright,
Conversing, reading, laughing;--or they sing,
While hearts and voices in the song unite.
title: Even As A Dragons Eye That Feels The Stress
explanation: Despite the melancholic light emitted by the joyless entity, there may be a cheerful gathering of people in close proximity to it, engaged in activities such as conversation, reading, laughter, or singing in unison with one another.

stanza:
O now that the genius of Bewick were mine,
And the skill which he learned on the banks of the Tyne.
Then the Muses might deal with me just as they chose,
For I'd take my last leave both of verse and of prose.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: If only I possessed the artistic talent of the renowned engraver Thomas Bewick, who honed his skills on the banks of the Tyne river, then I would leave it up to the Muses to guide my creative output. In fact, I would bid farewell to both poetry and prose, confident that my artistic abilities would be sufficient to express myself in other ways.

stanza:
What feats would I work with my magical hand!
Book-learning and books should be banished the land:
And, for hunger and thirst and such troublesome calls,
Every ale-house should then have a feast on its walls.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: I wish to perform incredible things with my enchanted hand. I believe that education and books should be eliminated from society. Additionally, I would like to see every tavern provide a feast for those who are hungry or thirsty.

stanza:
The traveller would hang his wet clothes on a chair;
Let them smoke, let them burn, not a straw would he care!
For the Prodigal Son, Joseph's Dream and his sheaves,
Oh, what would they be to my tale of two Thieves?
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: The traveller was not concerned about hanging his wet clothes on a chair and letting them smoke or burn. He was indifferent to the biblical stories of the Prodigal Son, Joseph's Dream, and his sheaves, as they were irrelevant to his tale of two thieves.

stanza:
The One, yet unbreeched, is not three birthdays old,
His Grandsire that age more than thirty times told;
There are ninety good seasons of fair and foul weather
Between them, and both go a-pilfering together.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: The One, who has not yet worn pants, is not even three years old, while his grandfather is over thirty times his age. Despite the vast difference in their ages, the two of them engage in thievery together, and there are ninety seasons of good and bad weather that have passed between them.

stanza:
With chips is the carpenter strewing his floor?
Is a cart-load of turf at an old woman's door?
Old Daniel his hand to the treasure will slide!
And his Grandson's as busy at work by his side.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: The carpenter is spreading chips on the floor, while an old woman receives a cartful of turf at her door. Old Daniel is reaching for his treasure with his hand, and his grandson is working diligently beside him.

stanza:
Old Daniel begins; he stops short--and his eye,
Through the lost look of dotage, is cunning and sly:
'Tis a look which at this time is hardly his own,
But tells a plain tale of the days that are flown.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: Daniel, an elderly man, starts to speak but abruptly pauses. Despite his aged appearance, his eyes reveal a shrewd and sly quality, which is not characteristic of his current state of mind but rather indicates his past experiences.

stanza:
He once had a heart which was moved by the wires
Of manifold pleasures and many desires:
And what if he cherished his purse? 'Twas no more
Than treading a path trod by thousands before.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: At one point in time, he had a heart that was easily swayed by various pleasures and desires. It's not a big deal that he cared about his money because many people before him have done the same thing.

stanza:
Twas a path trod by thousands; but Daniel is one
Who went something farther than others have gone,
And now with old Daniel you see how it fares;
You see to what end he has brought his grey hairs.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: Daniel walked along a well-traveled path taken by many before him. However, he went further than anyone else had gone before. Now, as we observe Daniel in his old age, we can see the results of his journey. We can see where his efforts have led him and what he has achieved in his lifetime.

stanza:
The pair sally forth hand in hand: ere the sun
Has peered o'er the beeches, their work is begun:
And yet, into whatever sin they may fall,
This child but half knows it, and that, not at all.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: The two people start their work together while holding hands before the sun rises over the trees. Even if they commit a sin, one of them only has a partial understanding of it and the other has no understanding at all.

stanza:
They hunt through the streets with deliberate tread,
And each, in his turn, becomes leader or led;
And, wherever they carry their plots and their wiles,
Every face in the village is dimpled with smiles.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: The people move through the streets with purposeful steps, taking turns leading and following each other. They scheme and connive, bringing joy to every face in the village.

title: The Two Thieves
explanation: They wander without being monitored by either the wealthy or the poor. This is because the elderly father has a daughter who is willing to fix any harm that is caused. Furthermore, she is able to provide three times the amount of assistance if it was requested.

stanza:
Old Man! whom so oft I with pity have eyed,
I love thee, and love the sweet Boy at thy side:
Long yet may'st thou live! for a teacher we see
That lifts up the veil of our nature in thee.
title: The Two Thieves
explanation: I have often felt pity for the old man, but I also love him and the young boy who is always with him. I hope he lives a long time because he is a great teacher who helps us understand ourselves better.

stanza:
Tis said, that some have died for love:
And here and there a churchyard grave is found
In the cold north's unhallowed ground,
Because the wretched man himself had slain,
His love was such a grievous pain.
And there is one whom I five years have known;
He dwells alone
Upon Helvellyn's side:
He loved--the pretty Barbara died;
And thus he makes his moan:
Three years had Barbara in her grave been laid
When thus his moan he made:
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: It is often said that love can be so overwhelming that it drives people to their death. There are even graves in the northern regions that bear witness to such tragic endings. People who loved so intensely that they could not bear to live without their beloved. One such person I know has been living alone on the side of Helvellyn for five years now. He loved Barbara, who unfortunately passed away. He still mourns her loss and has been doing so for the past three years.

stanza:
"Oh, move, thou Cottage, from behind that oak!
Or let the aged tree uprooted lie,
That in some other way yon smoke
May mount into the sky!
The clouds pass on; they from the heavens depart.
I look--the sky is empty space;
I know not what I trace;
But when I cease to look, my hand is on my heart.
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker is asking for the cottage to be moved or for the oak tree to be uprooted so that the smoke can rise into the sky unobstructed. They observe the passing clouds and feel a sense of emptiness when they look at the sky, but they feel a physical response in their heart when they stop looking.

stanza:
"Oh! what a weight is in these shades! Ye leaves,
That murmur once so dear, when will it cease?
Your sound my heart of rest bereaves,
It robs my heart of peace.
Thou Thrush, that singest loud--and loud and free,
Into yon row of willows flit,
Upon that alder sit;
Or sing another song, or choose another tree.
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker expresses their burdened state of mind and the disturbance caused by the sound of rustling leaves and the loud singing of a thrush. They long for peace and quiet and wish for the leaves to stop making noise. The speaker even suggests the thrush to choose another tree or sing another song to alleviate their distress.

stanza:
"Roll back, sweet Rill! back to thy mountain-bounds,
And there for ever be thy waters chained!
For thou dost haunt the air with sounds
That cannot be sustained;
If still beneath that pine-tree's ragged bough
Headlong yon waterfall must come,
Oh let it then be dumb!
Be anything, sweet Rill, but that which thou art now.
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker addresses a small stream, asking it to retreat back to its mountain source and remain there permanently. The reason for this request is that the sound of the stream is too overwhelming and cannot be sustained. Even the sound of the nearby waterfall is too much for the speaker to bear. The speaker implores the stream to be anything else but its current noisy self.

stanza:
"Thou Eglantine, so bright with sunny showers,
Proud as a rainbow spanning half the vale,
Thou one fair shrub, oh! shed thy flowers,
And stir not in the gale.
For thus to see thee nodding in the air,
To see thy arch thus stretch and bend,
Thus rise and thus descend,--
Disturbs me till the sight is more than I can dear."
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: Oh Eglantine, your beauty is so radiant after a sunny rain shower, and your proud presence spans half the valley like a rainbow. You are a beautiful shrub, but please do not sway in the wind and drop your flowers. It disturbs me to see you nodding and bending, rising and falling, as it becomes overwhelming to bear witness to.

stanza:
The Man who makes this feverish complaint
Is one of giant stature, who could dance
Equipped from head to foot in iron mail.
Ah gentle Love! if ever thought was thine
To store up kindred hours for me, thy face
Turn from me, gentle Love! nor let me walk
Within the sound of Emma's voice, nor know
Such happiness as I have known to-day.
title: Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: A man of great size, dressed in heavy armor, is feverishly complaining. He begs for love to turn away from him and never let him hear the voice of Emma again or experience the same happiness he has felt today.

stanza:
Let thy wheel-barrow alone--
Wherefore, Sexton, piling still
In thy bone-house bone on bone?
'Tis already like a hill
In a field of battle made,
Where three thousand skulls are laid;
These died in peace each with the other,--
Father, sister, friend, and brother.
title: To A Sexton
explanation: Stop adding more bones to the bone-house, Sexton. It's already piled high like a hill on a battlefield where three thousand skulls lay. These bones belonged to people who died peacefully alongside their family, friends, and loved ones.

stanza:
Mark the spot to which I point!
From this platform, eight feet square,
Take not even a finger-joint:
Andrew's whole fire-side is there.
Here, alone, before thine eyes,
Simon's sickly daughter lies,
From weakness now, and pain defended,
Whom he twenty winters tended.
title: To A Sexton
explanation: I am directing your attention to a specific location which is an eight feet square platform. Please do not move any part of your body, not even a finger. What I am indicating is the entire household of Andrew. The sickly daughter of Simon is lying there in front of you, who has been taken care of by her father for twenty years due to her illness and suffering.

stanza:
Look but at the gardener's pride--
How he glories, when he sees
Roses, lilies, side by side,
Violets in families!
By the heart of Man, his tears,
By his hopes and by his fears,
Thou, too heedless, art the Warden
Of a far superior garden.
title: To A Sexton
explanation: The speaker draws attention to the gardener's sense of pride when he sees the different flowers growing harmoniously in his garden. This pride is contrasted with the carelessness of the person being addressed, who is the "Warden" of a much more important garden - the world of humanity. The speaker suggests that this person is not paying enough attention to the needs and potential of humanity, as represented by the gardener's care for his plants. The heart of man, with all its emotions and aspirations, is the focus of this superior garden, and the speaker is urging the listener to take more responsibility for its cultivation.

stanza:
Thus then, each to other dear,
Let them all in quiet lie,
Andrew there, and Susan here,
Neighbours in mortality.
And, should I live through sun and rain
Seven widowed years without my Jane,
O Sexton, do not then remove her,
Let one grave hold the Loved and Lover!
title: To A Sexton
explanation: The speaker wishes for Andrew and Susan, who were dear to each other in life, to rest peacefully beside each other in death. If the speaker were to outlive their own beloved Jane for seven years, they implore the sexton not to disturb her grave and instead allow for the loved and lover to be buried in the same plot.

stanza:
BEAUMONT! it was thy wish that I should rear
A seemly Cottage in this sunny Dell,
On favoured ground, thy gift, where I might dwell
In neighbourhood with One to me most dear,
That undivided we from year to year
Might work in our high Calling-a bright hope
To which our fancies, mingling, gave free scope
Till checked by some necessities severe.
title: At Applewaite, Near Keswick 1804
explanation: Beaumont had requested that the speaker build a charming cottage in a sunny dell, which was gifted to him by Beaumont, in order for him to live close to someone very important to him. The plan was to work together in their shared profession with the hope of being undivided from each other every year. This plan was exciting and their imaginations ran wild, but it was limited by some harsh realities.

stanza:
And should these slacken, honoured BEAUMONT! still
Even then we may perhaps in vain implore
Leave of our fate thy wishes to fulfil.
Whether this boon be granted us or not,
Old Skiddaw will look down upon the Spot
With pride, the Muses love it evermore.
title: At Applewaite, Near Keswick 1804
explanation: Even if our hopes are not fulfilled, dear BEAUMONT, and the circumstances do not improve, we may still be unable to escape our fate. Nevertheless, even if we are unsuccessful in our endeavors, the beautiful Skiddaw mountain will continue to overlook the area with pride, and the Muses will always cherish it.

stanza:
NOT 'mid the world's vain objects that enslave
The free-born Soul--that World whose vaunted skill
In selfish interest perverts the will,
Whose factions lead astray the wise and brave--
Not there; but in dark wood and rocky cave,
And hollow vale which foaming torrents fill
With omnipresent murmur as they rave
Down their steep beds, that never shall be still:
Here, mighty Nature! in this school sublime
I weigh the hopes and fears of suffering Spain;
title: Composed While The Author Was Engaged In Writing A Tract Occasioned By The Convention Of Cintra
explanation: The free spirit of man is not captivated by the superficiality of the world, a world that is corrupted by selfishness, misleading the wise and brave. The true essence of the soul is found in the depths of the forest, the rugged terrain, and the roaring rivers that never cease to flow. It is here where nature reigns supreme, and where the author contemplates the struggles and aspirations of Spain.

stanza:
For her consult the auguries of time,
And through the human heart explore my way;
And look and listen--gathering, whence I may,
Triumph, and thoughts no bondage can restrain.
title: Composed While The Author Was Engaged In Writing A Tract Occasioned By The Convention Of Cintra
explanation: She should seek guidance from the signs of the times and gain insight into my path by delving into the depths of human emotions. By observing and listening carefully, she can discover sources of success and unbridled ideas.

stanza:
.   Mother! whose virgin bosom was uncrost
With the least shade of thought to sin allied.
Woman! above all women glorified,
Our tainted nature's solitary boast;
title: The Virgin
explanation: The speaker addresses the Virgin Mary, praising her for her pure and sinless nature. He declares her as the most glorified woman of all, as she is the only one who can boast of being untainted by sin, despite being human.

title: The Virgin
explanation: More pure than foam on the ocean's surface and brighter than the sunrise in the east, scattered with imagined roses, and even purer than the moon before it begins to wane in the sky's blue horizon.

stanza:
Thy image falls to earth. Yet some, I ween,
Not unforgiven the suppliant knee might bend,
As to a visible Power, in which did blend
All that was mixed and reconciled in thee
Of mother's love with maiden purity,
Of high with low, celestial with terrene!
title: The Virgin
explanation: Your likeness tumbles to the ground, but perhaps some could still kneel before you and seek forgiveness from a divine force that embodies the mixture of maternal affection and virginal innocence, as well as the combination of heavenly and earthly qualities that were present in you.

stanza:
I THOUGHT of Thee, my partner and my guide,
As being pass'd away.--Vain sympathies!
For, backward, Duddon! as I cast my eyes,
I see what was, and is, and will abide;
title: Valedictory Sonnet To The River Duddon
explanation: I was thinking about you, my companion and guide, as if you were no longer with me. But such thoughts are pointless, as I look back at the Duddon River and see that what was there before is still there now and will continue to be so.

title: Valedictory Sonnet To The River Duddon
explanation: The stream continues to flow endlessly, while the form of humanity endures, but our capabilities and achievements will eventually fade away. However, if we leave something meaningful behind that can make an impact in the future, that is enough. As we approach death, we can find solace in the love, hope, and faith within us, knowing that we are capable of greatness beyond our understanding.

stanza:
I MET Louisa in the shade,
And, having seen that lovely Maid,
Why should I fear to say
That, nymph-like, she is fleet and strong,
And down the rocks can leap along
Like rivulets in May?
title: Louisa: After Accompanying Her On A Mountain Excursion
explanation: I encountered Louisa in a shaded area and upon seeing her, I feel compelled to express that she possesses a nimble and robust quality reminiscent of a nymph. She is able to jump down rocks with ease, akin to the flowing movements of a May rivulet.

title: Louisa: After Accompanying Her On A Mountain Excursion
explanation: She adores her fireplace and cozy abode, but she also enjoys trekking across the moors in harsh and inclement weather. Even when she struggles against the gusts of wind, the speaker wishes they could kiss the raindrops that glisten on her companion's face.

stanza:
Take all that's mine 'beneath the moon,'
If I with her but half a noon
May sit beneath the walls
Of some old cave, or mossy nook,
When up she winds along the brook
To hunt the waterfalls.
title: Louisa: After Accompanying Her On A Mountain Excursion
explanation: I am willing to give up everything I own as long as I can spend just a few hours with her sitting by the walls of an old cave or a mossy nook. I will be content watching her hike up along the river to hunt for waterfalls.

stanza:
FAIR Star of evening, Splendour of the west,
Star of my Country!--on the horizon's brink
Thou hangest, stooping, as might seem, to sink
On England's bosom; yet well pleased to rest,
Meanwhile, and be to her a glorious crest
Conspicuous to the Nations. Thou, I think,
Should'st be my Country's emblem; and should'st wink,
Bright Star! with laughter on her banners, drest
In thy fresh beauty. There! that dusky spot
Beneath thee, that is England; there she lies.
title: Composed By The Sea-Side, Near Calais, August 1802
explanation: The evening star shines brightly in the western sky, appearing to hang on the horizon as if about to descend onto England's bosom. It is a glorious crest for the nation, and could be a fitting emblem for the country. Its fresh beauty would make it a perfect addition to the banners of England, and it shines with laughter on them. The dusky spot beneath the star is none other than England, lying there in all its glory.

stanza:
Blessings be on you both! one hope, one lot,
One life, one glory!--I, with many a fear
For my dear Country, many heartfelt sighs,
Among men who do not love her, linger here.
title: Composed By The Sea-Side, Near Calais, August 1802
explanation: May both of you be blessed with the same hope, destiny, life, and glory. As for me, I remain here among those who do not love our dear country, with many fears and heartfelt sighs for its future.

stanza:
YES, it was the mountain Echo,
Solitary, clear, profound,
Answering to the shouting Cuckoo,
Giving to her sound for sound!
title: Yes, It Was The Mountain Echo
explanation: The mountain Echo responded to the Cuckoo's call with clarity and depth, matching her sound with each shout. The Echo stood alone, but its presence was felt as it echoed back the Cuckoo's cries.

stanza:
Unsolicited reply
To a babbling wanderer sent;
Like her ordinary cry,
Like--but oh, how different!
title: Yes, It Was The Mountain Echo
explanation: The speaker responds to a wandering person's rambling words without being asked. The response is compared to the person's usual chatter, but is described as being distinctly different.

stanza:
Hears not also mortal Life?
Hear not we, unthinking Creatures!
Slaves of folly, love, or strife--
Voices of two different natures?
title: Yes, It Was The Mountain Echo
explanation: Do not mortal beings also hear life? Are we, the thoughtless creatures, not listening to the voices of two distinct natures? Are we not slaves to foolishness, love, and conflict?

stanza:
Have not 'we' too?--yes, we have
Answers, and we know not whence;
Echoes from beyond the grave,
Recognised intelligence!
title: Yes, It Was The Mountain Echo
explanation: We have also experienced the inexplicable, just like those who have passed away. We have heard responses that we can't explain and have recognised a type of intelligence that seems to come from beyond the grave.

stanza:
Such rebounds our inward ear
Catches sometimes from afar--
Listen, ponder, hold them dear;
For of God,--of God they are.
title: Yes, It Was The Mountain Echo
explanation: Sometimes our inner ear captures distant echoes, and we should take the time to listen, reflect, and cherish them because they are messages from God.

stanza:
THE fields which with covetous spirit we sold,
Those beautiful fields, the delight of the day,
Would have brought us more good than a burthen of gold,
Could we but have been as contented as they.
title: Repentance
explanation: We sold our fields, which were beautiful and the source of our daily happiness, with a greedy mindset. If only we had been as content as the fields themselves, they would have brought us more benefits than a load of gold.

stanza:
When the troublesome Tempter beset us, said I,
'Let him come, with his purse proudly grasped in his hand;
But, Allan, be true to me, Allan,--we'll die
Before he shall go with an inch of the land!'
title: Repentance
explanation: I said that when the Tempter comes to trouble us, we should let him come with his money in hand. However, we need to remain true to each other and fight until death before allowing him to take even an inch of our land.

title: Repentance
explanation: We lived there happily, like birds in their nests, and were free like bees in a garden. We had complete control over the land and the nearby stream provided a soothing background sound.

stanza:
But now we are strangers, go early or late;
And often, like one overburthened with sin,
With my hand on the latch of the half-opened gate,
I look at the fields, but I cannot go in!
title: Repentance
explanation: We are now strangers, and it doesn't matter if we leave early or late. Often, I feel so burdened with sin that I can't even enter the fields, despite standing with my hand on the gate that's half-opened.

stanza:
When I walk by the hedge on a bright summer's day,
Or sit in the shade of my grandfather's tree,
A stern face it puts on, as if ready to say,
'What ails you, that you must come creeping to me!'
title: Repentance
explanation: On a sunny summer day, as I stroll past the hedge or relax beneath my grandfather's tree, the surroundings seem to take on a serious expression, almost as if they're questioning why I'm approaching them with such hesitation.

title: Repentance
explanation: We had everything we needed with the pastures surrounding us, so we couldn't feel unhappy. If we ever faced any challenges, we knew we had comfort nearby. However, we disregarded all the blessings, comfort, and wealth we possessed and lost our birthright.

stanza:
Oh, ill-judging sire of an innocent son
Who must now be a wanderer! but peace to that strain!
Think of evening's repose when our labour was done,
The sabbath's return; and its leisure's soft chain!
title: Repentance
explanation: You, a foolish father, have caused your innocent son to become a wanderer. However, let us find peace in these words. Remember the peaceful evenings after a long day's work, the return of the Sabbath, and the relaxation that comes with it.

stanza:
And in sickness, if night had been sparing of sleep,
How cheerful, at sunrise, the hill where I stood,
Looking down on the kine, and our treasure of sheep
That besprinkled the field; 'twas like youth in my blood!
title: Repentance
explanation: Even in times of sickness, if I had managed to get some rest at night, I would feel cheerful standing on the hill at sunrise. From there, I could see our cows and sheep grazing in the field, and it would make me feel young again.

stanza:
Now I cleave to the house, and am dull as a snail;
And, oftentimes, hear the church-bell with a sigh,
That follows the thought--We've no land in the vale,
Save six feet of earth where our forefathers lie!
title: Repentance
explanation: I feel attached to my house and have become slow and uninteresting like a snail. Often, when I hear the church bell ringing, I let out a sigh and think about the fact that my family has no land in the valley except for the six feet of earth where our ancestors are buried.

stanza:
DEAR native regions, I foretell,
From what I feel at this farewell,
That, wheresoe'er my steps may tend,
And whensoe'er my course shall end,
If in that hour a single tie
Survive of local sympathy,
My soul will cast the backward view,
The longing look alone on you.
title: Extract From The Conclusion Of A Poem Composed In Anticipation Of Leaving School
explanation: As I bid farewell to my homeland, I have a strong feeling that no matter where my journey takes me, and even at the end of my life, if any connection to my home remains, my heart will always yearn for it. The memories and emotions of my native regions hold a special place in my soul, and I will forever look back upon them with a sense of longing.

stanza:
Thus, while the Sun sinks down to rest
Far in the regions of the west,
Though to the vale no parting beam
Be given, not one memorial gleam,
A lingering light he fondly throws
On the dear hills where first he rose.
title: Extract From The Conclusion Of A Poem Composed In Anticipation Of Leaving School
explanation: As the Sun sets in the west, it may not leave any indication of its departure in the valley, however, it still casts a warm glow on the hills where it first emerged, before bidding farewell for the day.

stanza:
The God of Love-'ah, benedicite!'
How mighty and how great a Lord is he!
For he of low hearts can make high, of high
He can make low, and unto death bring nigh;
And hard-hearts he can make them kind and free.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The God of Love is praised as a powerful and mighty lord who has the ability to transform people's hearts and bring them to the brink of death. He can uplift those who are low in spirit and humble those who are prideful. He is also able to soften the hearts of those who are hard-hearted, making them kind and free.

stanza:
Within a little time, as hath been found,
He can make sick folk whole and fresh and sound:
Them who are whole in body and in mind,
He can make sick,-bind can he and unbind
All that he will have bound, or have unbound.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: In a short period, it has been discovered that he has the ability to heal the sick and restore their health. He can also cause those who are healthy in body and mind to become ill, and has the power to bind and unbind whatever he desires.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I cannot fully describe his power with my words; he can turn wise men into fools, accomplish whatever he desires, make those with immoral habits change their ways, and cause even the proudest hearts to tremble in fear.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: In summary, he has complete control over everything he desires and no one would dare to oppose him. He can choose to bring about humility or suffering to anyone he wishes, as well as bring joy or sorrow with equal ease. However, his greatest power is demonstrated on the evening of May.

stanza:
For every true heart, gentle heart and free,
That with him is, or thinketh so to be,
Now against May shall have some stirring-whether
To joy, or be it to some mourning; never
At other time, methinks, in like degree.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: During the month of May, those who have pure, kind, and liberated hearts will experience some kind of emotional reaction, whether it be happiness or sorrow. This stirring within them is unique to this time of year and does not happen to the same extent during any other month.

stanza:
For now when they may hear the small birds' song,
And see the budding leaves the branches throng,
This unto their remembrance doth bring
All kinds of pleasure mixed with sorrowing;
And longing of sweet thoughts that ever long.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: At this moment, when people can hear the melodious chirping of small birds and witness the sprouting leaves covering the tree branches, it evokes a mixture of pleasure and sorrowful memories, reminding them of the longing for sweet thoughts that never seem to fade away.

stanza:
And of that longing heaviness doth come,
Whence oft great sickness grows of heart and home:
Sick are they all for lack of their desire;
And thus in May their hearts are set on fire,
So that they burn forth in great martyrdom.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The feeling of longing can become heavy and lead to sickness of the heart and home. When people are deprived of their desires, they become sick. In the month of May, their hearts are set on fire and they experience great suffering, like martyrs.

stanza:
In sooth, I speak from feeling, what though now
Old am I, and to genial pleasure slow;
Yet have I felt of sickness through the May,
Both hot and cold, and heart-aches every day,-
How hard, alas! to bear, I only know.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I speak from personal experience, although I am old and not easily amused. I have suffered from sickness during the month of May, experiencing both hot and cold symptoms as well as daily heartaches. It has been a difficult burden for me to carry.

stanza:
Such shaking doth the fever in me keep
Through all this May that I have little sleep;
And also 'tis not likely unto me,
That any living heart should sleepy be
In which Love's dart its fiery point doth steep.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The speaker is experiencing a fever that causes them to shake and lose sleep during the month of May. They believe that it is unlikely for anyone to be able to sleep when they are consumed by the passion of love.

stanza:
But tossing lately on a sleepless bed,
I of a token thought which Lovers heed;
How among them it was a common tale,
That it was good to hear the Nightingale,
Ere the vile Cuckoo's note be uttered.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The speaker, unable to sleep, reflects on the advice commonly given among lovers to listen to the Nightingale's song before the Cuckoo's call is heard. This is seen as a positive omen or token for lovers, and is valued as such.

stanza:
And then I thought anon as it was day,
I gladly would go somewhere to essay
If I perchance a Nightingale might hear,
For yet had I heard none, of all that year,
And it was then the third night of the May.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: As daylight approached, I decided to venture out in search of a Nightingale's song. It was the third night of May and I had yet to hear one that year. I was eager to listen to its sweet melody and hoped to come across one during my excursion.

stanza:
And soon as I a glimpse of day espied,
No longer would I in my bed abide,
But straightway to a wood that was hard by,
Forth did I go, alone and fearlessly,
And held the pathway down by a brookside;
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: As soon as I saw the first light of day, I got out of bed and headed to a nearby forest without hesitation. I walked alone and fearlessly along a path beside a brook.

stanza:
Till to a lawn I came all white and green,
I in so fair a one had never been.
The ground was green, with daisy powdered over;
Tall were the flowers, the grove a lofty cover,
All green and white; and nothing else was seen.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I arrived at a beautiful lawn that was both white and green, unlike anything I had ever seen before. The ground was covered in green grass with daisies sprinkled throughout. The flowers were tall and the grove provided a high canopy. Everything in sight was either green or white.

stanza:
There sate I down among the fair fresh flowers,
And saw the birds come tripping from their bowers,
Where they had rested them all night; and they,
Who were so joyful at the light of day,
Began to honour May with all their powers.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I sat among the beautiful flowers and watched as the birds emerged from their nests where they had slept all night. The birds were full of joy as they welcomed the light of day and started to celebrate the arrival of May with all their might.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: They were well aware of the service they performed routinely, and there were numerous beautiful musical notes. Some sang loudly, as if they were lamenting, while others used a different tone. Some sang with all their might.

stanza:
They pruned themselves, and made themselves right gay,
Dancing and leaping light upon the spray;
And ever two and two together were,
The same as they had chosen for the year,
Upon Saint Valentine's returning day.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: On Saint Valentine's Day, the birds pruned themselves and appeared cheerful, dancing and leaping on the branches. They paired up in twos, just as they had done the previous year, and stayed close together.

stanza:
Meanwhile the stream, whose bank I sate upon,
Was making such a noise as it ran on
Accordant to the sweet Birds' harmony;
Methought that it was the best melody
Which ever to man's ear a passage won.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: As I sat on the bank of a stream, I noticed that it was making a pleasant noise that matched the sweet melody of the birds. I felt that this was the most beautiful music that anyone could ever hear.

stanza:
And for delight, but how I never wot,
I in a slumber and a swoon was caught,
Not all asleep and yet not waking wholly;
And as I lay, the Cuckoo, bird unholy,
Broke silence, or I heard him in my thought.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I fell into a state of unconsciousness and confusion, not quite asleep but not fully awake either. During this time, I heard the sound of the Cuckoo bird, although I'm not sure if it was a physical sound or just in my mind. I can't explain why, but this experience brought me joy.

stanza:
And that was right upon a tree fast by,
And who was then ill satisfied but I?
Now, God, quoth I, that died upon the rood,
From thee and thy base throat, keep all that's good,
Full little joy have I now of thy cry.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I was standing next to a tree and feeling very unhappy. I thought about God who died on the cross and asked him to keep all good things away from the person who was bothering me because I didn't want to hear their voice. Their cries brought me no happiness.

stanza:
And, as I with the Cuckoo thus 'gan chide,
In the next bush that was me fast beside,
I heard the lusty Nightingale so sing,
That her clear voice made a loud rioting,
Echoing thorough all the green wood wide.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: As I scolded the Cuckoo, I heard the Nightingale singing loudly in the bush next to me. Her voice echoed throughout the forest, filling the air with beautiful sound.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Oh, dear Nightingale, you have arrived later than expected, but you bring joy to my heart. The Cuckoo has been singing before you, and I do not like her song. She has done me wrong, and I do not wish her well.

stanza:
But hear you now a wondrous thing, I pray;
As long as in that swooning-fit I lay,
Methought I wist right well what these birds meant,
And had good knowing both of their intent,
And of their speech, and all that they would say.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I have a remarkable tale to tell you. While I was in a state of unconsciousness, I had a vivid understanding of the birds' communication. I comprehended their purpose and every word they spoke.

stanza:
The Nightingale thus in my hearing spake:-
Good Cuckoo, seek some other bush or brake,
And, prithee, let us that can sing dwell here;
For every wight eschews thy song to hear,
Such uncouth singing verily dost thou make.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Nightingale spoke to the Cuckoo, asking it to find another place to sing because its unusual singing style was not appreciated by anyone. The Nightingale requested that those who could sing well be allowed to stay in that spot.

stanza:
What! quoth she then, what is't that ails thee now?
It seems to me I sing as well as thou;
For mine's a song that is both true and plain,-
Although I cannot quaver so in vain
As thou dost in thy throat, I wot not how.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The woman wonders why the man seems unsatisfied with her singing, as she believes her song is just as good as his. While she cannot sing with the same trills and embellishments as he can, she believes her song is honest and straightforward. She questions why he is so critical of her singing, as she believes she is doing the best she can.

stanza:
All men may understanding have of me,
But, Nightingale, so may they not of thee;
For thou hast many a foolish and quaint cry:-
Thou say'st OSEE, OSEE, then how may I
Have knowledge, I thee pray, what this may be?
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: While anyone can comprehend my language, the Nightingale's peculiar cries, such as "OSEE, OSEE," are not easily understood. The speaker is curious about the meaning of the bird's cry and wonders if anyone can enlighten him on its significance.

stanza:
Ah, fool! quoth she, wist thou not what it is?
Oft as I say OSEE, OSEE, I wis,
Then mean I, that I should be wonderous fain
That shamefully they one and all were slain,
Whoever against Love mean aught amiss.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: She called him a fool and asked if he did not understand what she meant. When she says "OSEE, OSEE," she means that she wishes those who go against Love would be ashamed and killed.

stanza:
And also would I that they all were dead,
Who do not think in love their life to lead;
For who is loth the God of Love to obey,
Is only fit to die, I dare well say,
And for that cause OSEE I cry; take heed!
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I wish that those who do not believe in leading a life of love were no longer alive. Anyone who refuses to follow the God of Love is only deserving of death. I urge everyone to take heed of this warning, just as the prophet Hosea did.

stanza:
Ay, quoth the Cuckoo, that is a quaint law,
That all must love or die; but I withdraw,
And take my leave of all such company,
For mine intent it neither is to die,
Nor ever while I live Love's yoke to draw.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Cuckoo finds it odd that there is a law dictating that one must love or face death. The Cuckoo decides to distance itself from such a concept and all those who follow it. The Cuckoo has no intention of succumbing to love or being tied down by it while it is still alive.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: People who love all types of folk tend to have the most internal turmoil and struggle the most, while receiving the least amount of good fortune. It is pointless to deny this truth.

stanza:
What! quoth she, thou art all out of thy mind,
That in thy churlishness a cause canst find
To speak of Love's true Servants in this mood;
For in this world no service is so good
To every wight that gentle is of kind.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: She exclaimed in disbelief, saying that he was completely irrational to have a reason to speak of Love's genuine followers in such a negative manner. She argued that there was no better service in the world than that of Love, which was beneficial to every person of a kind and gentle nature.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: All goodness, worth, gentleness, and honor originate from this source. Worship, contentment, and true heart's pleasure also stem from it, as well as complete trust, immeasurable joy, and lively cheerfulness.

stanza:
And bounty, lowliness, and courtesy,
And seemliness, and faithful company,
And dread of shame that will not do amiss;
For he that faithfully Love's servant is,
Rather than be disgraced, would chuse to die.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: To be a faithful servant of love, one must possess qualities such as generosity, humility, politeness, and a trustworthy circle of companions. One must also have a fear of shame and would rather die than be dishonored.

stanza:
And that the very truth it is which I
Now say-in such belief I'll live and die;
And Cuckoo, do thou so, by my advice.
Then, quoth she, let me never hope for bliss,
If with that counsel I do e'er comply.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I firmly believe in the truth I just spoke and will stand by it until the end. I advise you, Cuckoo, to do the same. However, she responds that she will never follow that advice if it means sacrificing her happiness.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Nightingale is praised for its beautiful singing, but its words about love are not entirely accurate. Love in young people is often simply a strong passion, while in old age it can become an obsession. The more one loves, the more it can damage them.

stanza:
For thereof come all contraries to gladness!
Thence sickness comes, and overwhelming sadness,
Mistrust and jealousy, despite, debate,
Dishonour, shame, envy importunate,
Pride, anger, mischief, poverty, and madness.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: All negative emotions, including sickness, sadness, mistrust, jealousy, debate, dishonor, shame, envy, pride, anger, mischief, poverty, and madness, stem from the same source, which is contrary to happiness.

stanza:
Loving is aye an office of despair,
And one thing is therein which is not fair;
For whoso gets of love a little bliss,
Unless it alway stay with him, I wis
He may full soon go with an old man's hair.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Being in love can often lead to feelings of hopelessness and disappointment, as there is an unfair aspect to it. Even if someone experiences a small amount of happiness in love, if it is not a continuous feeling, they may find themselves aging and feeling older much faster than they expected.

stanza:
And, therefore, Nightingale! do thou keep nigh,
For trust me well, in spite of thy quaint cry,
If long time from thy mate thou be, or far,
Thou'lt be as others that forsaken are;
Then shalt thou raise a clamour as do I.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The speaker urges the nightingale to stay close by, as being separated from one's mate or being far away can lead to feeling abandoned and making a loud noise in desperation, just like the nightingale's cry.

stanza:
Fie, quoth she, on thy name, Bird ill beseen!
The God of Love afflict thee with all teen,
For thou art worse than mad a thousand fold;
For many a one hath virtues manifold,
Who had been nought, if Love had never been.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: She exclaimed disdainfully towards the bird, saying that its name is not fitting for its appearance. She wished for the God of Love to punish the bird with great sorrow, as it is worse than a thousand times insane. The reason for this is that many people possess numerous virtues that they would not have had if love had not existed.

stanza:
For evermore his servants Love amendeth,
And he from every blemish them defendeth;
And maketh them to burn, as in a fire,
In loyalty, and worshipful desire,
And, when it likes him, joy enough them sendeth.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: His servants are constantly being improved by Love, and he protects them from any flaws. Love ignites within them a fierce loyalty and desire to worship, and when Love is pleased, he sends them ample joy.

stanza:
Thou Nightingale! the Cuckoo said, be still,
For Love no reason hath but his own will;-
For to th' untrue he oft gives ease and joy;
True lovers doth so bitterly annoy,
He lets them perish through that grievous ill.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Cuckoo tells the Nightingale to stop singing because love is unpredictable and sometimes brings joy to those who are unfaithful while causing great pain to true lovers, ultimately leading to their demise. Love acts according to its own will and does not follow any logical reasoning, which is why it can be both a source of comfort and torment.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I could never become a master like him because he is blind and cannot see, therefore unaware of when he causes harm or provides healing. Truth rarely prevails in this court because of his unpredictable nature.

stanza:
Then of the Nightingale did I take note,
How from her inmost heart a sigh she brought,
And said, Alas! that ever I was born,
Not one word have I now, I am so forlorn,-
And with that word, she into tears burst out.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I observed the Nightingale closely and noticed that she let out a deep sigh from her heart. She exclaimed with sadness that she wishes she was never born because she feels utterly alone and unable to speak. The Nightingale then burst into tears after uttering these words.

stanza:
Alas, alas! my very heart will break,
Quoth she, to hear this churlish bird thus speak
Of Love, and of his holy services;
Now, God of Love; thou help me in some wise,
That vengeance on this Cuckoo I may wreak.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: She exclaimed with great sorrow that her heart would shatter upon hearing the rude bird speak about Love and his sacred duties. She prayed to God of Love for help in seeking revenge against the Cuckoo.

stanza:
And so methought I started up anon,
And to the brook I ran and got a stone,
Which at the Cuckoo hardily I cast,
And he for dread did fly away full fast;
And glad, in sooth, was I when he was gone.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I suddenly woke up and quickly went to the stream to get a stone. I threw the stone at the cuckoo bird who flew away in fear. I was happy to see the bird leave.

stanza:
And as he flew, the Cuckoo, ever and aye,
Kept crying 'Farewell!-farewell, Popinjay!'
As if in scornful mockery of me;
And on I hunted him from tree to tree,
Till he was far, all out of sight, away.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Cuckoo taunted the speaker as it flew away, repeatedly crying "Farewell!-farewell, Popinjay!" The speaker pursued the bird from tree to tree until it was no longer visible.

stanza:
Then straightway came the Nightingale to me,
And said, Forsooth, my friend, do I thank thee,
That thou wert near to rescue me; and now,
Unto the God of Love I make a vow,
That all this May I will thy songstress be.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Nightingale approached me immediately and expressed gratitude for rescuing her. She then vowed to be my singer for the entire month of May and gave thanks to the God of Love.

stanza:
Well satisfied, I thanked her, and she said,
By this mishap no longer be dismayed,
Though thou the Cuckoo heard, ere thou heard'st me;
Yet if I live it shall amended be,
When next May comes, if I am not afraid.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I expressed my gratitude to her and she assured me not to worry about missing the call of the cuckoo before hearing her. She promised that the situation would be rectified in the future and that I need not be afraid come next May.

stanza:
And one thing will I counsel thee also,
The Cuckoo trust not thou, nor his Love's saw;
All that she said is an outrageous lie.
Nay, nothing shall me bring thereto, quoth I,
For Love, and it hath done me mighty woe.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: I advise you not to trust the Cuckoo or her words about love as they are all lies. I refuse to believe anything she says because love has caused me great pain.

stanza:
Yea, hath it? use, quoth she, this medicine;
This May-time, every day before thou dine,
Go look on the fresh daisy; then say I,
Although for pain thou may'st be like to die,
Thou wilt be eased, and less wilt droop and pine.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The woman suggests using a medicine and advises to look at a fresh daisy every day before eating during May. She believes that even if one is experiencing pain, they will feel some relief and will not be as sad or weak.

stanza:
And mind always that thou be good and true,
And I will sing one song, of many new,
For love of thee, as loud as I may cry;
And then did she begin this song full high,
'Beshrew all them that are in love untrue.'
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Always be good and honest, and I will sing a new song for you that shows my love as loudly as I can. She then sang a song condemning those who are not true in love.

stanza:
And soon as she had sung it to the end,
Now farewell, quoth she, for I hence must wend;
And, God of Love, that can right well and may,
Send unto thee as mickle joy this day,
As ever he to Lover yet did send.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: As soon as she finished singing, she said goodbye and had to leave. She asked the God of Love to send as much joy to the listener as he ever had to a lover.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Nightingale is bidding farewell to the speaker. He prays that she will always be blessed and continue to experience love. He also asks for protection from the Cuckoo and her deceitful nature, as she is known to be a dishonest bird.

stanza:
Forth then she flew, the gentle Nightingale,
To all the Birds that lodged within that dale,
And gathered each and all into one place;
And them besought to hear her doleful case,
And thus it was that she began her tale.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Nightingale quickly flew to gather all the birds in the dale and begged them to listen to her sad story. She began to tell them her tale.

stanza:
The Cuckoo-'tis not well that I should hide
How she and I did each the other chide,
And without ceasing, since it was daylight;
And now I pray you all to do me right
Of that false Bird whom Love can not abide.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The speaker expresses a desire to reveal the conflict that occurred between themselves and the cuckoo bird, as they continuously quarreled with each other throughout the day. The speaker asks for justice to be served against the deceitful bird that is not loved by anyone.

title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: A bird spoke up and everyone agreed that this matter required serious consideration. They were all birds gathered together, but the Cuckoo was not present. Therefore, they decided to hold a formal meeting or parliament to discuss the issue.

stanza:
And thereat shall the Eagle be our Lord,
And other Peers whose names are on record;
A summons to the Cuckoo shall be sent,
And judgment there be given; or that intent
Failing, we finally shall make accord.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: The Eagle and other notable individuals will be our leaders. The Cuckoo will be summoned for judgment, and if that fails, we will make peace.

stanza:
And all this shall be done, without a nay,
The morrow after Saint Valentine's day,
Under a maple that is well beseen,
Before the chamber-window of the Queen,
At Woodstock, on the meadow green and gay.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: This will happen without objection on the day after Valentine's Day under a beautiful maple tree, in front of the Queen's chamber window, on the green and lively meadow at Woodstock.

stanza:
She thanked them; and then her leave she took,
And flew into a hawthorn by that brook;
And there she sate and sung-upon that tree-
'For term of life Love shall have hold of me'-
So loudly, that I with that song awoke.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: She expressed gratitude to them, bid farewell and flew into a hawthorn tree by the brook. She perched on a branch and sang a song declaring her commitment to love for the rest of her life. Her singing was so loud that it woke the speaker from his sleep.

stanza:
Unlearned Book and rude, as well I know,
For beauty thou hast none, nor eloquence,
Who did on thee the hardiness bestow
To appear before my Lady? but a sense
Thou surely hast of her benevolence,
Whereof her hourly bearing proof doth give;
For of all good she is the best alive.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: This book is unsophisticated and lacks beauty or eloquence. Why would it dare to present itself to my Lady? However, it must have a sense of her kindness since her actions constantly prove her to be the best person alive.

stanza:
Alas, poor Book! for thy unworthiness,
To show to her some pleasant meanings writ
In winning words, since through her gentiless,
Thee she accepts as for her service fit!
Oh! it repents me I have neither wit
Nor leisure unto thee more worth to give;
For of all good she is the best alive.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Oh dear Book, I am sorry that you are not deserving enough to convey pleasant ideas to her through your enchanting words. She accepts you as a useful tool, but I regret that I am unable to provide you with more valuable content due to my lack of wit and time. She is the best person alive, and I wish I could offer her more through you.

stanza:
Beseech her meekly with all lowliness,
Though I be far from her I reverence,
To think upon my truth and stedfastness,
And to abridge my sorrow's violence,
Caused by the wish, as knows your sapience,
She of her liking proof to me would give;
For of all good she is the best alive.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Humbly plead with her, even though I am distant, to consider my loyalty and reduce the intensity of my sadness caused by hoping she would demonstrate her affection for me. You understand that if she would show me her fondness, it would bring me great joy, and she is the finest person I know.

stanza:
Pleasure's Aurora, Day of gladsomeness!
Luna by night, with heavenly influence
Illumined! root of beauty and goodnesse,
Write, and allay, by your beneficence,
My sighs breathed forth in silence,-comfort give!
Since of all good, you are the best alive.
title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: This verse is an ode to the pleasures of life, and the beauty and goodness that come with them. It invokes the celestial bodies of the sun and moon as symbols of these pleasures, and asks for comfort and solace in times of sorrow. The author acknowledges that these pleasures are the best things in life, and thanks them for their continued presence.

stanza:
O BLITHE New-comer! I have heard,
I hear thee and rejoice.
O Cuckoo! Shall I call thee Bird,
Or but a wandering Voice?
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: Oh joyful newcomer, I have heard your call and it brings me great delight. Oh Cuckoo, should I refer to you as a bird or simply a wandering voice?

stanza:
While I am lying on the grass
Thy twofold shout I hear,
From hill to hill it seems to pass,
At once far off, and near.
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: As I lay on the grass, I could hear your shout echoing through the hills, seeming to come from both far away and close by at the same time.

stanza:
Though babbling only to the Vale,
Of Sunshine and of flowers,
Thou bringest unto me a tale
Of visionary hours.
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: Although you only speak to the valley about the beauty of the sun and flowers, you bring me a story of magical moments.

stanza:
Thrice welcome, darling of the Spring!
Even yet thou art to me
No bird, but an invisible thing,
A voice, a mystery;
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: Oh how delightful it is to welcome you, beloved symbol of the season of Spring! However, to me, you are not just a bird, but an intangible entity, a voice, an enigma that is yet to be fully understood.

stanza:
The same whom in my school-boy days
I listened to; that Cry
Which made me look a thousand ways
In bush, and tree, and sky.
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: In my childhood, I listened to the same cry that made me look around in wonder at the world around me. It was a cry that drew my attention to every bush, tree, and sky.

title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: I searched for you many times, wandering through the woods and fields, but you remained elusive, a desire and a passion that I yearned for but never found.

stanza:
And I can listen to thee yet;
Can lie upon the plain
And listen, till I do beget
That golden time again.
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: I can still listen to you and lie down on the ground to listen until I am able to experience that wonderful time again.

stanza:
O blessed Bird! the earth we pace
Again appears to be
An unsubstantial, faery place;
That is fit home for Thee!
title: To The Cuckoo
explanation: Oh lucky bird! As we walk on this earth, it seems once again like a magical and dreamlike realm, a perfect habitat for you.

stanza:
WHAT need of clamorous bells, or ribands gay,
These humble nuptials to proclaim or grace?
Angels of love, look down upon the place;
Shed on the chosen vale a sun-bright day!
Yet no proud gladness would the Bride display
Even for such promise:--serious is her face,
Modest her mien; and she, whose thoughts keep pace
With gentleness, in that becoming way
Will thank you. Faultless does the Maid appear;
title: Composed On The Eve Of The Marriage Of A Friend In The Vale Of Grasmere
explanation: Why use loud bells or fancy decorations to celebrate this simple wedding? Let the angels of love bless this humble spot with a bright day. The bride is not boastful or showy, but serious and modest. She expresses gratitude in a gentle manner, true to her kind nature. The maid looks perfect, faultless in her appearance.

stanza:
No disproportion in her soul, no strife:
But, when the closer view of wedded life
Hath shown that nothing human can be clear
From frailty, for that insight may the Wife
To her indulgent Lord become more dear.
title: Composed On The Eve Of The Marriage Of A Friend In The Vale Of Grasmere
explanation: The woman's soul is free of imbalance and conflict, but as she experiences the realities of marriage and the imperfections of humanity, she may develop a deeper appreciation and affection for her husband's leniency and understanding.

stanza:
Begone, thou fond presumptuous Elf,'
Exclaimed an angry Voice,
'Nor dare to thrust thy foolish self
Between me and my choice!'
A small Cascade fresh swoln with snows
Thus threatened a poor Briar-rose,
That, all bespattered with his foam,
And dancing high and dancing low,
Was living, as a child might know,
In an unhappy home.
title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: An angry voice commanded a presumptuous elf to leave and not interfere with their decisions. The elf was dancing around a small cascade that had swollen with snow, and was threatening a poor briar-rose that was covered in foam. The rose was living in an unhappy home and the elf was warned to leave it alone.

stanza:
Dost thou presume my course to block?
Off, off! or, puny Thing!
I'll hurl thee headlong with the rock
To which thy fibres cling.'
The Flood was tyrannous and strong;
The patient Briar suffered long,
Nor did he utter groan or sigh,
Hoping the danger would be past;
But, seeing no relief, at last,
He ventured to reply.
title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: The speaker warns someone not to get in their way or they will be thrown off a rock. The flood is powerful and oppressive while the briar is patient and endures the danger silently. Eventually, the briar speaks up when there seems to be no end to the danger in sight.

stanza:
Ah!' said the Briar, 'blame me not;
Why should we dwell in strife?
We who in this sequestered spot
Once lived a happy life!
You stirred me on my rocky bed--
What pleasure through my veins you spread
The summer long, from day to day,
My leaves you freshened and bedewed;
Nor was it common gratitude
That did your cares repay.
title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: The Briar expressed its discontent with the conflict, asking not to be blamed. The Briar and the speaker had previously lived a happy life in their secluded area. The speaker had previously provided care to the Briar, and in return, the Briar had been revitalized. The Briar emphasizes that it was not merely out of gratitude that it benefited from the speaker's care.

stanza:
When spring came on with bud and bell,
Among these rocks did I
Before you hang my wreaths to tell
That gentle days were nigh!
And in the sultry summer hours,
I sheltered you with leaves and flowers;
And in my leaves--now shed and gone,
The linnet lodged, and for us two
Chanted his pretty songs, when you
Had little voice or none.
title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: I hung my wreaths among the rocks to signal the arrival of spring and the approach of gentle days. During the hot summer, I provided shelter with leaves and flowers, while the linnet nested in my foliage and sang sweet songs for us when you were unable to. Despite my leaves now being gone, I have memories of the times we shared together.

stanza:
But now proud thoughts are in your breast--
What grief is mine you see,
Ah! would you think, even yet how blest
Together we might be!
Though of both leaf and flower bereft,
Some ornaments to me are left--
Rich store of scarlet hips is mine,
With which I, in my humble way,
Would deck you many a winter day,
A happy Eglantine!'
title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: The speaker expresses their sadness over the proud thoughts of their loved one, as they believe they could still be happy together. Despite being stripped of their leaves and flowers, the speaker still possesses scarlet hips that they would use to decorate their loved one throughout the winter. The speaker refers to themselves as a happy Eglantine.

title: The Waterfall And The Eglantine
explanation: The speaker cannot recount any further words spoken by the person they were with. A loud and fast-moving stream in a rocky valley drowned out any other sounds. The briar shook and the speaker is afraid that these were the last words they will hear from their companion.

stanza:
HERE, on our native soil, we breathe once more.
The cock that crows, the smoke that curls, that sound
Of bells; those boys who in yon meadow-ground
In white-sleeved shirts are playing; and the roar
Of the waves breaking on the chalky shore;--
All, all are English. Oft have I looked round
With joy in Kent's green vales; but never found
Myself so satisfied in heart before.
title: Composed In The Valley Near Dover, On The Day Of Landing
explanation: Being back on home turf, we feel a sense of relief. The sounds of familiar things such as the cockerel's crow, the smoke rising from chimneys, the bells ringing, and the boys playing in the meadow in their white shirts, all signify that we are back in England. Even the sound of the waves crashing against the chalky shore is a reminder of our homeland. We have often admired the beauty of Kent's green fields, but this time the feeling of contentment in our hearts is stronger than ever before.

stanza:
Europe is yet in bonds; but let that pass,
Thought for another moment. Thou art free,
My Country! and 'tis joy enough and pride
For one hour's perfect bliss, to tread the grass
Of England once again, and hear and see,
With such a dear Companion at my side.
title: Composed In The Valley Near Dover, On The Day Of Landing
explanation: Although Europe is currently constrained, the speaker urges the reader to momentarily ignore this fact. The speaker then declares that their country, England, is free and this brings them immense joy and pride. They express their happiness at being able to walk on the grass of England once again and to hear and see everything with their beloved companion by their side.

stanza:
BENEATH yon eastern ridge, the craggy bound,
Rugged and high, of Charnwood's forest ground
Stand yet, but, Stranger! hidden from thy view,
The ivied Ruins of forlorn GRACE DIEU;
title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: On the eastern ridge lies the rocky boundary of Charnwood's forest ground, with the hidden ruins of Grace Dieu, covered in ivy, remaining unseen by the stranger's eye.

stanza:
Erst a religious House, which day and night
With hymns resounded, and the chanted rite:
And when those rites had ceased, the Spot gave birth
To honourable Men of various worth:
There, on the margin of a streamlet wild,
Did Francis Beaumont sport, an eager child;
title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: The location was once a religious institution where hymns were sung and rituals were performed around the clock. After the religious activities ceased, the area became a breeding ground for individuals of different backgrounds and social statuses. Francis Beaumont, as a young boy, played along the banks of a wild stream in this area.

stanza:
There, under shadow of the neighbouring rocks,
Sang youthful tales of shepherds and their flocks;
Unconscious prelude to heroic themes,
Heart-breaking tears, and melancholy dreams
Of slighted love, and scorn, and jealous rage,
With which his genius shook the buskined stage.
title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: The speaker describes a young man singing stories of shepherds and their flocks in the shadow of nearby rocks. These stories are a precursor to more intense themes of heartbreak, jealousy, and tragedy that the young man's talent will eventually bring to the stage.

stanza:
Communities are lost, and Empires die,
And things of holy use unhallowed lie;
They perish;--but the Intellect can raise,
From airy words alone, a Pile that ne'er decays.
title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: Communities and Empires crumble, and sacred objects are desecrated, leading to their destruction. However, the power of the human mind can create a lasting monument through the use of language and ideas that withstand the test of time. Such structures built in the mind can never be destroyed and serve as a testament to the strength of human intellect.

stanza:
Yet are they here the same unbroken knot
Of human Beings, in the self-same spot!
Men, women, children, yea the frame
Of the whole spectacle the same!
Only their fire seems bolder, yielding light,
Now deep and red, the colouring of night;
That on their Gipsy-faces falls,
Their bed of straw and blanket-walls.
title: Gipsies
explanation: The group of human beings remains unbroken and in the same location, including men, women, and children. The only noticeable difference is their fire, which appears bolder and gives off a deeper red light, coloring the night. This light falls on their faces and their makeshift bed of straw and blanket walls.

stanza:
--Twelve hours, twelve bounteous hours are gone, while I
Have been a traveller under open sky,
Much witnessing of change and cheer,
Yet as I left I find them here!
The weary Sun betook himself to rest;--
Then issued Vesper from the fulgent west,
Outshining like a visible God
The glorious path in which he trod.
title: Gipsies
explanation: I have spent twelve hours travelling under the open sky, witnessing many changes and cheerful moments. However, as I leave, I realize that these moments are still present. The tired sun has set and Vesper has emerged from the bright west, shining like a god and illuminating the path he walks on.

stanza:
And now, ascending, after one dark hour
And one night's diminution of her power,
Behold the mighty Moon! this way
She looks as if at them--but they
Regard not her:--oh better wrong and strife
(By nature transient) than this torpid life;
title: Gipsies
explanation: After a dark hour and a night of reduced power, the Moon now rises in all her magnificence. She appears to be looking down on the world, but the people below pay her no attention. The speaker suggests that it is better to experience wrong and conflict, which are only temporary, than to live a stagnant and uneventful life.

stanza:
Life which the very stars reprove
As on their silent tasks they move!
Yet, witness all that stirs in heaven or earth!
In scorn I speak not;--they are what their birth
And breeding suffer them to be;
Wild outcasts of society!
title: Gipsies
explanation: Life is being criticized by the stars as they carry out their duties in silence. Everything that moves in either heaven or earth bears witness to this fact. However, I do not say this in contempt; they are simply a product of their upbringing and circumstances. They are like social outcasts, wild and untamed.

stanza:
WE had a female Passenger who came
From Calais with us, spotless in array,--
A white-robed Negro, like a lady gay,
Yet downcast as a woman fearing blame;
title: September 1, 1802
explanation: On our journey from Calais, we were accompanied by a female passenger who was immaculately dressed. She was a black woman dressed in white, appearing as a happy lady, but her demeanor suggested that she was afraid of being judged.

stanza:
Meek, destitute, as seemed, of hope or aim
She sate, from notice turning not away,
But on all proffered intercourse did lay
A weight of languid speech, or to the same
No sign of answer made by word or face:
Yet still her eyes retained their tropic fire,
That, burning independent of the mind,
Joined with the lustre of her rich attire
To mock the Outcast.--O ye Heavens, be kind!
And feel, thou Earth, for this afflicted Race!
title: September 1, 1802
explanation: The woman appeared meek and destitute, lacking hope or purpose. She sat without turning away from any offered interaction, but responded with a heavy, lethargic speech or no response at all. Despite this, her eyes still burned with a fierce passion, independent of her mind, and shone brightly with the richness of her clothing. The speaker calls upon the heavens and the earth to have compassion and kindness towards this suffering group of people.

stanza:
CALM is all nature as a resting wheel.
The kine are couched upon the dewy grass;
The horse alone, seen dimly as I pass,
Is cropping audibly his later meal:
Dark is the ground; a slumber seems to steal
O'er vale, and mountain, and the starless sky.
title: Written In Very Early Youth
explanation: Everything in nature is peaceful and still, like a wheel that has stopped moving. Cows are resting on the damp grass, while the only sound audible is the horse munching on his food. The ground is dark and a sense of sleepiness seems to have taken over the valleys, mountains and even the sky, which is devoid of stars.

stanza:
Now, in this blank of things, a harmony,
Home-felt, and home-created, comes to heal
That grief for which the senses still supply
Fresh food; for only then, when memory
Is hushed, am I at rest. My Friends! restrain
Those busy cares that would allay my pain;
Oh! leave me to myself, nor let me feel
The officious touch that makes me droop again.
title: Written In Very Early Youth
explanation: In the midst of emptiness, a sense of comfort and peace emerges, born from the familiarity and warmth of home. This serves as a remedy for the lingering pain that is continually fueled by the senses, only subsiding when memory is silenced. The speaker implores their friends to refrain from attempting to ease their suffering through busy distractions or unwanted physical contact, as it only serves to exacerbate their distress.

stanza:
THERE 's not a nook within this solemn Pass,
But were an apt confessional for one
Taught by his summer spent, his autumn gone,
That Life is but a tale of morning grass
Wither'd at eve. From scenes of art which chase
That thought away, turn, and with watchful eyes
Feed it 'mid Nature's old felicities,
Rocks, rivers, and smooth lakes more clear than glass
Untouch'd, unbreathed upon. Thrice happy quest,
If from a golden perch of aspen spray
(October's workmanship to rival May)
The pensive warbler of the ruddy breast
That moral sweeten by a heaven-taught lay,
Lulling the year, with all its cares, to rest!
title: The Trosachs
explanation: The speaker reflects on the transience of life, seeing in the natural world an unwavering truth. They suggest that art can distract from this reality, but the natural world brings clarity. The speaker longs to find peace in nature, particularly in the beauty of rocks, rivers, and clear lakes. They hope to hear the song of a bird, which could provide a moral lesson and ease the burdens of the passing year. The poem emphasizes the importance of finding solace and truth in the natural world, particularly as a respite from the distractions of modern life.

stanza:
WHILE flowing rivers yield a blameless sport,
Shall live the name of Walton: Sage benign!
Whose pen, the mysteries of the rod and line
Unfolding, did not fruitlessly exhort
To reverend watching of each still report
That Nature utters from her rural shrine.
title: Written Upon A Blank Leaf In
explanation: The name of Walton will forever be associated with the peaceful and blameless activity of fishing in flowing rivers. He was a wise and kind scholar who shared his knowledge of fishing through his writing, encouraging others to pay attention to the quiet secrets of nature that can be heard from the countryside. His teachings were not in vain, as many have taken up his philosophy and enjoyed the tranquility of fishing.

stanza:
Meek, nobly versed in simple discipline,
He found the longest summer day too short,
To his loved pastime given by sedgy Lee,
Or down the tempting maze of Shawford brook--
Fairer than life itself, in this sweet Book,
