--Why comes not Francis? Thoughts of love
Should bear him to his Sister dear
With the fleet motion of a dove;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker wonders why Francis has not arrived yet. Francis fled from the city and could hear the death toll of the Minster-bell which announced the death of Marmaduke and Ambrose, as well as a knell for a sweet, half-opened flower, and all dying in one hour. Despite his thoughts of love for his sister, Francis has not yet arrived.

stanza:
Yea, like a heavenly messenger
Of speediest wing, should he appear.
Why comes he not?--for westward fast
Along the plain of York he past;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: It is said that a messenger with the swiftest wings of heaven should have arrived by now, but he has not appeared yet. He was last seen heading westward along the plain of York.

stanza:
Reckless of what impels or leads,
Unchecked he hurries on;--nor heeds
The sorrow, through the Villages,
Spread by triumphant cruelties
Of vengeful military force,
And punishment without remorse.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He moves forward recklessly, without consideration for what drives him or the consequences of his actions. He pays no attention to the suffering caused by the merciless military force and their brutal punishments that spread sorrow throughout the villages.

stanza:
He marked not, heard not, as he fled
All but the suffering heart was dead
For him abandoned to blank awe,
To vacancy, and horror strong:
And the first object which he saw,
With conscious sight, as he swept along--
It was the Banner in his hand!
He felt--and made a sudden stand.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He didn't notice or hear anything as he ran away. He was consumed by his suffering heart and felt empty and terrified. As he ran, the first thing he saw was the Banner in his hand, and this sudden realization made him stop in his tracks.

stanza:
He looked about like one betrayed:
What hath he done? what promise made?
Oh weak, weak moment! to what end
Can such a vain oblation tend,
And he the Bearer?--Can he go
Carrying this instrument of woe,
And find, find anywhere, a right
To excuse him in his Country's sight?
No; will not all men deem the change
A downward course, perverse and strange?
Here is it;--but how? when? must she,
The unoffending Emily,
Again this piteous object see?
Such conflict long did he maintain,
Nor liberty nor rest could gain:
His own life into danger brought
By this sad burden--even that thought,
Exciting self-suspicion strong
Swayed the brave man to his wrong.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The person being described looks around feeling betrayed and guilty, wondering what promise he made. He regrets his past actions and questions the purpose of his sacrifice. Carrying a burden of grief and guilt, he fears being judged by his country for his mistakes. He wonders if anyone will understand or accept his reasons for his actions. He struggles with his conscience, unable to find peace or freedom. The thought of the danger he has put himself in by carrying this burden only adds to his self-doubt and suspicion. Despite his bravery, he cannot escape the inner turmoil caused by his own actions.

stanza:
And how--unless it were the sense
Of all-disposing Providence,
Its will unquestionably shown--
How has the Banner clung so fast
To a palsied, and unconscious hand;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker ponders how the Banner has remained firmly attached to a hand that is paralyzed and unaware. They question whether this could be attributed to the will of a higher power, as it seems impossible otherwise.

stanza:
Clung to the hand to which it passed
Without impediment? And why,
But that Heaven's purpose might be known,
Doth now no hindrance meet his eye,
No intervention, to withstand
Fulfilment of a Father's prayer
Breathed to a Son forgiven, and blest
When all resentments were at rest,
And life in death laid the heart bare?--
Then, like a spectre sweeping by,
Rushed through his mind the prophecy
Of utter desolation made
To Emily in the yew-tree shade:
He sighed, submitting will and power
To the stern embrace of that grasping hour.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker wonders why there are no obstacles to the fulfillment of Heaven's purpose, as if it were clinging to a hand that passed without impediment. The lack of hindrance allows the Father's prayer for the Son, who was forgiven and blessed when all resentments were at rest and life was laid bare in death. The speaker's mind is then rushed by the prophecy of Emily's utter desolation in the yew-tree shade. He sighs, submitting his will and power to the embrace of that grasping hour.

stanza:
No choice is left, the deed is mine--
Dead are they, dead!--and I will go,
And, for their sakes, come weal or woe,
Will lay the Relic on the shrine.'
So forward with a steady will
He went, and traversed plain and hill;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: With no other option left, the protagonist takes responsibility for their actions and decides to carry out their plan. They acknowledge that those who were affected by their actions are now deceased and are determined to complete their mission, regardless of the outcomes. With a resolute mind, they move forward, crossing various terrains to reach their destination.

stanza:
And up the vale of Wharf his way
Pursued;--and, at the dawn of day,
Attained a summit whence his eyes
Could see the Tower of Bolton rise.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He traveled through the valley of Wharf and reached a high point at dawn where he could see the Tower of Bolton.

stanza:
There Francis for a moment's space
Made halt--but hark! a noise behind
Of horsemen at an eager pace!
He heard, and with misgiving mind.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Francis paused for a moment, but then heard the sound of horsemen approaching at a rapid pace from behind. He became anxious and worried about the source of the noise.

stanza:
--'Tis Sir George Bowes who leads the Band:
They come, by cruel Sussex sent;
Who, when the Nortons from the hand
Of death had drunk their punishment,
Bethought him, angry and ashamed,
How Francis, with the Banner claimed
As his own charge, had disappeared,
By all the standers-by revered.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Sir George Bowes is the leader of the group that was sent by Sussex to punish the Nortons. After the Nortons were punished, Sir George was angry and ashamed because Francis, who was in charge of the Banner, had disappeared and was greatly respected by those who witnessed it.

stanza:
His whole bold carriage (which had quelled
Thus far the Opposer, and repelled
All censure, enterprise so bright
That even bad men had vainly striven
Against that overcoming light)
Was then reviewed, and prompt word given,
That to what place soever fled
He should be seized, alive or dead.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker describes a man with a confident demeanor that had previously silenced his opposition and thwarted any attempts to negatively affect his endeavors. However, his character and actions were now being evaluated, and a command was given to capture him, dead or alive, regardless of where he may have fled.

stanza:
The troop of horse have gained the height
Where Francis stood in open sight.
They hem him round--'Behold the proof,'
They cried, 'the Ensign in his hand!
'He' did not arm, he walked aloof!
For why?--to save his Father's land;--
Worst Traitor of them all is he,
A Traitor dark and cowardly!'
'I am no Traitor,' Francis said,
'Though this unhappy freight I bear;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: A group of cavalry has reached the spot where Francis was standing in plain view. They surround him and claim that the evidence of his treason is the ensign in his hand. However, Francis did not arm himself and kept a distance because he wanted to protect his father's land. The cavalry accuses him of being the worst traitor who is both dark and cowardly. Francis denies the accusation and explains that he is carrying an unfortunate burden but is not a traitor.

stanza:
And must not part with. But beware;--
Err not by hasty zeal misled,
Nor do a suffering Spirit wrong,
Whose self-reproaches are too strong!'
At this he from the beaten road
Retreated towards a brake of thorn,
That like a place of vantage showed;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Be cautious and do not hastily give up something valuable. Do not be misled by impulsive actions and do not harm someone who is already suffering and blaming themselves too much. With this in mind, the speaker moved away from the main path and towards a thorny area that looked like a good hiding spot.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He stood alone, looking determined and resolute despite feeling sad and abandoned. He defended himself with a fierce expression on his face, armed with a spear that he had taken from a Soldier. He used it to protect himself and kept a watchful eye on his attackers, who were circling around him.

stanza:
But from behind with treacherous wound
A Spearman brought him to the ground.
The guardian lance, as Francis fell,
Dropped from him; but his other hand
The Banner clenched; till, from out the Band,
One, the most eager for the prize,
Rushed in; and--while, O grief to tell!
A glimmering sense still left, with eyes
Unclosed the noble Francis lay--
Seized it, as hunters seize their prey;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: A Spearman attacked Francis from behind, causing him to fall to the ground with a treacherous wound. Francis dropped his guardian lance but held onto the Banner with his other hand. One member of the group rushed in, eager to claim the prize, and seized the Banner while Francis lay there with a faint consciousness, his eyes still open. It was a sorrowful moment, akin to a hunter seizing their prey.

stanza:
But not before the warm life-blood
Had tinged more deeply, as it flowed,
The wounds the broidered Banner showed,
Thy fatal work, O Maiden, innocent as good!
Proudly the Horsemen bore away
The Standard; and where Francis lay
There was he left alone, unwept,
And for two days unnoticed slept.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The Maiden's unintentional fatal work caused the wounds on the embroidered banner to deepen as the warm life-blood flowed. The horsemen took the standard with pride, leaving Francis alone and unwept where he lay. He remained unnoticed and slept for two days.

stanza:
For at that time bewildering fear
Possessed the country, far and near;
But, on the third day, passing by
One of the Norton Tenantry
Espied the uncovered Corse; the Man
Shrunk as he recognised the face,
And to the nearest homesteads ran
And called the people to the place.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The entire country was consumed by fear during that time. However, on the third day, a member of the Norton Tenantry stumbled upon the uncovered body and recognized the face. This person immediately ran to the nearest homesteads to call for the locals to come and see.

stanza:
--How desolate is Rylstone-hall!
This was the instant thought of all;
And if the lonely Lady there
Should be; to her they cannot bear
This weight of anguish and despair.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Everyone who sees Rylstone-hall immediately feels a sense of despair and sadness, and they cannot imagine how the Lady who lives there can bear it. The hall is desolate and empty, and the thought of being alone in that place is unbearable to those who visit.

stanza:
So, when upon sad thoughts had prest
Thoughts sadder still, they deemed it best
That, if the Priest should yield assent
And no one hinder their intent,
Then, they, for Christian pity's sake,
In holy ground a grave would make;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: When they were already feeling down, they began to have even sadder thoughts. They decided that if the Priest agreed and no one stopped them, they would bury someone in a holy grave out of Christian compassion.

stanza:
And straightway buried he should be
In the Churchyard of the Priory.
Apart, some little space, was made
The grave where Francis must be laid.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Francis was to be buried immediately in the Priory Churchyard, with a separate plot of land designated for his burial.

stanza:
In no confusion or neglect
This did they,--but in pure respect
That he was born of gentle blood;
And that there was no neighbourhood
Of kindred for him in that ground:
So to the Churchyard they are bound,
Bearing the body on a bier;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: They were not confused or neglectful, but acted out of pure respect for the fact that the deceased was born into a noble family and had no relatives nearby. They carried the body on a bier to the churchyard for burial.

stanza:
And psalms they sing--a holy sound
That hill and vale with sadness hear.
But Emily hath raised her head,
And is again disquieted;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The singing of psalms, a holy sound, is heard with sadness throughout the hill and vale. However, Emily raises her head and becomes restless once again.

stanza:
She must behold!--so many gone,
Where is the solitary One?
And forth from Rylstone-hall stepped she,--
To seek her Brother forth she went,
And tremblingly her course she bent
Toward Bolton's ruined Priory.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The woman felt a strong urge to see the one who had not returned, as many others had already gone. She left her home at Rylstone-hall to search for her brother and nervously made her way towards the ruined Priory at Bolton.

stanza:
She comes, and in the vale hath heard
The funeral dirge;--she sees the knot
Of people, sees them in one spot--
And darting like a wounded bird
She reached the grave, and with her breast
Upon the ground received the rest,--
The consummation, the whole ruth
And sorrow of this final truth!
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: She arrives and hears the somber hymn in the valley, then spots a group of people gathered in one place. She rushes towards them like an injured bird and arrives at the grave where she throws herself to the ground, accepting the finality and grief of the situation.

stanza:
INMATE of a mountain-dwelling,
Thou hast clomb aloft, and gazed
From the watch-towers of Helvellyn;
Awed, delighted, and amazed!
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: You, who are imprisoned in the mountains, have climbed up high and looked out from the watchtowers of Helvellyn. You were both afraid and amazed by what you saw.

stanza:
Potent was the spell that bound thee
Not unwilling to obey;
For blue Ether's arms, flung round thee,
Stilled the pantings of dismay.
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: The spell that held you was very powerful and you didn't resist it because the embrace of the blue sky calmed your fears.

stanza:
Lo! the dwindled woods and meadows;
What a vast abyss is there!
Lo! the clouds, the solemn shadows,
And the glistenings--heavenly fair!
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: The woods and meadows have become smaller, and the surrounding area seems immense. The clouds, shadows, and glimmers are all beautiful and awe-inspiring.

stanza:
And a record of commotion
Which a thousand ridges yield;
Ridge, and gulf, and distant ocean
Gleaming like a silver shield!
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: The scene before the speaker is full of movement and noise, with numerous ridges producing a record of the commotion. The ridges, along with gulfs and a far-off ocean, shine like a silver shield.

stanza:
Maiden! now take flight;--inherit
Alps or Andes--they are thine!
With the morning's roseate Spirit,
Sweep their length of snowy line;
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: Maiden, it is time to soar and claim your inheritance of the Alps or Andes. Let the rosy spirit of morning guide you as you glide along their snow-covered peaks.

stanza:
Or survey their bright dominions
In the gorgeous colours drest
Flung from off the purple pinions,
Evening spreads throughout the west!
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: As the evening descends, the sky is adorned with radiant hues that spread across the horizon. It's a stunning display, painted across the canvas of the sky like a masterpiece. The colors are so vivid that it feels like one is surveying the magnificent kingdoms of the gods. The beauty of the sunset is truly breathtaking and a reminder of the wonders of nature.

stanza:
Thine are all the coral fountains
Warbling in each sparry vault
Of the untrodden lunar mountains;
Listen to their songs!--or halt,
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: You own all the coral fountains that sing in every crystalline cave of the unexplored mountains on the moon. Hear their melodies or stop and take notice.

title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: Satan was invited to the top of Niphates, where he went with malice in his heart. Alternatively, he could have gone to where the ark landed when the earth became green again.

stanza:
For the power of hills is on thee,
As was witnessed through thine eye
Then, when old Helvellyn won thee
To confess their majesty!
title: To---- On Her First Ascent To The Summit Of Helvellyn
explanation: You were awed by the power of hills and their majesty when you looked upon old Helvellyn. The hills hold a great power over you that you cannot deny.

stanza:
FROM Bolton's old monastic tower
The bells ring loud with gladsome power;
The sun shines bright; the fields are gay
With people in their best array
Of stole and doublet, hood and scarf,
Along the banks of crystal Wharf,
Through the Vale retired and lowly,
Trooping to that summons holy.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The bells sound joyous from Bolton's ancient monastic tower, as the sun shines down on the fields where people are gathered in their finest attire - adorned with stoles, doublets, hoods, and scarves. They follow the banks of the clear Wharf river through a humble and secluded valley, all heading towards a sacred summons.

stanza:
And, up among the moorlands, see
What sprinklings of blithe company!
Of lasses and of shepherd grooms,
That down the steep hills force their way,
Like cattle through the budded brooms;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: In the moorlands, there is a lively group of young women and shepherds that make their way down the steep hillsides, similar to cattle pushing through the budding broom.

stanza:
Path, or no path, what care they?
And thus in joyous mood they hie
To Bolton's mouldering Priory.
What would they there?--Full fifty years
That sumptuous Pile, with all its peers,
Too harshly hath been doomed to taste
The bitterness of wrong and waste:
Its courts are ravaged; but the tower
Is standing with a voice of power,
That ancient voice which wont to call
To mass or some high festival;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Regardless of whether there is a path or not, they do not care. They happily make their way to the decaying Bolton Priory. What is their purpose in going there? For fifty years, the grand structure, along with its counterparts, has been subjected to ruin and neglect. The courtyards have been plundered, but the tower still stands with a commanding presence. It possesses the ancient voice that once summoned people to mass or other significant events.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Within the heart of the broken fabric lies a protected chapel, resembling a bird's nest that is well-hidden and neatly decorated.

stanza:
And thither young and old repair,
This Sabbath-day, for praise and prayer.
Fast the churchyard fills;--anon
Look again, and they all are gone;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: People of all ages gather at the church on this Sabbath day to participate in worship and prayer. The churchyard quickly fills up with worshippers, but soon they all disappear.

stanza:
The cluster round the porch, and the folk
Who sate in the shade of the Prior's Oak!
And scarcely have they disappeared
Ere the prelusive hymn is heard:--
With one consent the people rejoice,
Filling the church with a lofty voice!
They sing a service which they feel:
For 'tis the sunrise now of zeal;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The group gathered around the porch and those sitting in the shade of the Prior's Oak have left just as the prelusive hymn begins. The people joyfully come together and fill the church with their harmonious voices. The service they sing is filled with emotion because they are now filled with enthusiasm and devotion.

stanza:
Of a pure faith the vernal prime--
In great Eliza's golden time.
A moment ends the fervent din,
And all is hushed, without and within;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: During the springtime of Queen Elizabeth I's reign, there was a period of devout faith. Suddenly, the fervent noise ceased, and everything became quiet both inside and outside.

stanza:
For though the priest, more tranquilly,
Recites the holy liturgy,
The only voice which you can hear
Is the river murmuring near.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Despite the priest calmly reciting the sacred ritual, the only audible sound is the soft murmuring of the nearby river.

stanza:
--When soft!--the dusky trees between,
And down the path through the open green,
Where is no living thing to be seen;
And through yon gateway, where is found,
Beneath the arch with ivy bound,
Free entrance to the churchyard ground--
Comes gliding in with lovely gleam,
Comes gliding in serene and slow,
Soft and silent as a dream,
A solitary Doe!
White she is as lily of June,
And beauteous as the silver moon
When out of sight the clouds are driven
And she is left alone in heaven;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: A beautiful white doe enters the scene, moving gracefully through the trees and down the open path towards the churchyard. The atmosphere is peaceful and quiet, with no other living beings in sight. The doe's movements are serene and slow, almost like a dream. Her pure white coat is as stunning as a lily in June, and she shines like the silver moon when it emerges from behind the clouds.

stanza:
Or like a ship some gentle day
In sunshine sailing far away,
A glittering ship, that hath the plain
Of ocean for her own domain.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Picture a beautiful ship sailing off into the distance on a calm, sunny day. The ship is adorned with sparkling jewels and has the vast ocean as its playground.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker urges the dead to rest in their graves and the living to focus on their religious duties and prayer. However, the speaker admits that their heart and attention are consumed by a particular delight. They suggest that spending time with this "bright Creature" is a suitable activity for the Sabbath, regardless of whether she is from the forest or the earth.

stanza:
Or a Spirit for one day given,
A pledge of grace from purest heaven.
What harmonious pensive changes
Wait upon her as she ranges
Round and through this Pile of state
Overthrown and desolate!
Now a step or two her way
Leads through space of open day,
Where the enamoured sunny light
Brightens her that was so bright;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker describes a Spirit who has been given a gift of grace from heaven for just one day. The Spirit moves through a ruined and desolate building, experiencing harmonious and reflective feelings. As she walks, she moves from darkness into a space of open daylight, which intensifies her already radiant appearance.

stanza:
Now doth a delicate shadow fall,
Falls upon her like a breath,
From some lofty arch or wall,
As she passes underneath:
Now some gloomy nook partakes
Of the glory that she makes,--
High-ribbed vault of stone, or cell,
With perfect cunning framed as well
Of stone, and ivy, and the spread
Of the elder's bushy head;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: A gentle shadow falls upon her as she walks underneath a lofty arch or wall, creating a delicate and breath-like effect. Even the gloomiest nooks bask in the glory of her presence, including high-ribbed vaults of stone or cells that are crafted with perfect skill using stone, ivy, and the elder bush.

stanza:
Some jealous and forbidding cell,
That doth the living stars repel,
And where no flower hath leave to dwell.
The presence of this wandering Doe
Fills many a damp obscure recess
With lustre of a saintly show;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: This poem describes a dreary and unwelcoming place where even the stars are kept away and no flowers can flourish. However, the presence of a wandering doe brings a sense of light and purity to the dark corners of this place, creating a saintly atmosphere.

stanza:
And, reappearing, she no less
Sheds on the flowers that round her blow
A more than sunny liveliness.
But say, among these holy places,
Which thus assiduously she paces,
Comes she with a votary's task,
Rite to perform, or boon to ask?
Fair Pilgrim! harbours she a sense
Of sorrow, or of reverence?
Can she be grieved for quire or shrine,
Crushed as if by wrath divine?
For what survives of house where God
Was worshipped, or where Man abode;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: As she reappears, she brings a joyous energy that illuminates the flowers around her. However, it's unclear why she visits these holy places. Is she here to fulfill a religious duty or to seek a blessing? The fair pilgrim's intentions remain a mystery. Does she feel sorrow or respect as she visits these sacred sites? Could she be mourning the destruction of the churches and homes where people once worshipped and lived? The poem leaves us wondering about the purpose of her visits and the emotions that compel her to continue her journey.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Does she lament the loss of grandeur or does she appreciate the gentle work of nature, which softens and conceals the scars of destruction? Is she grieving for the once splendid hearths of the noble chambers that now give way to the growth of young ash trees?

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker describes a place, possibly a dormitory, where a wild rose blooms and an altar that has been decorated with moss. They then mention a warrior carved in stone, surrounded by weeds and lying alone.

stanza:
A warrior, with his shield of pride
Cleaving humbly to his side,
And hands in resignation prest,
Palm to palm, on his tranquil breast;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The warrior stood with his shield held high, proud and strong. Yet, he remained humble, with his hands clasped together in resignation, resting peacefully on his chest.

stanza:
As little she regards the sight
As a common creature might:
If she be doomed to inward care,
Or service, it must lie elsewhere.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The woman in question does not pay much attention to her surroundings, as she does not react to them like a typical person would. She remains unaffected even if she is troubled or occupied with something else.

stanza:
--But hers are eyes serenely bright,
And on she moves--with pace how light!
Nor spares to stoop her head, and taste
The dewy turf with flowers bestrown;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Her eyes shine with a peaceful brightness as she moves forward with a light step. She doesn't hesitate to bend down and savor the moist grass covered in beautiful flowers.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: She continues on until she reaches a grassy grave, where she lies down in peace. Her descent is as calm as a tired wave settling against a ship's anchored side after the summer breeze has ceased.

stanza:
Even so, without distress, doth she
Lie down in peace, and lovingly.
The day is placid in its going,
To a lingering motion bound,
Like the crystal stream now flowing
With its softest summer sound:
So the balmy minutes pass,
While this radiant Creature lies
Couched upon the dewy grass,
Pensively with downcast eyes.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The woman in the poem is calm and peaceful as she lies down, without any worry or distress. The day is also calm and slow-moving, like a gentle stream flowing in the summer. Time passes slowly as the woman rests on the grass, lost in thought with her eyes looking downwards.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The people are raising their voices in praise, but this time it is a solemn occasion as it is their last song before departing. They exit the temple and disperse in different directions to go about their individual journeys.

stanza:
But some--a variegated band
Of middle-aged, and old, and young,
And little children by the hand
Upon their leading mothers hung--
With mute obeisance gladly paid
Turn towards the spot, where, full in view,
The white Doe, to her service true,
Her sabbath couch has made.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: A diverse group of people, including the elderly, middle-aged, and young, along with young children holding their mother's hands, respectfully turn towards a spot where a white Doe, who is loyal to serving them, has made her resting place. They show their admiration without speaking.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The mound stood alone, separated from nearby graves by a stretch of land measuring the length of two spears. It appeared to hold a sense of superiority, as if it were somehow special or distinct from the others.

stanza:
Or melancholy's sickly mood,
Still shy of human neighbourhood;
Or guilt, that humbly would express
A penitential loneliness.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The feeling of sadness or melancholy can make people avoid social interactions. Guilt may also lead to a sense of loneliness, as individuals may feel the need to express remorse and seek forgiveness on their own. These emotions can create a sense of isolation and distance from others.

stanza:
Look, there she is, my Child! draw near;
She fears not, wherefore should we fear?
She means no harm;'--but still the Boy,
To whom the words were softly said,
Hung back, and smiled, and blushed for joy,
A shame-faced blush of glowing red!
Again the Mother whispered low,
'Now you have seen the famous Doe;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: See how gentle and harmless she is. There's no need to be afraid.' The boy, however, hesitated, even though the mother's words were soothing. He smiled and blushed, feeling joy at the sight of the deer. The mother repeated her words, emphasizing the harmless nature of the animal.

stanza:
From Rylstone she hath found her way
Over the hills this sabbath day
Her work, whate'er it be, is done,
And she will depart when we are gone;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: She has made her way from Rylstone and crossed over the hills on this Sunday. Whatever work she had to do is now completed and she will leave once we have gone.

stanza:
Thus doth she keep, from year to year,
Her sabbath morning, foul or fair.'
Bright was the Creature, as in dreams
The Boy had seen her, yea, more bright;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Every year, she observed her Sabbath morning, no matter the weather, as the boy had seen her in his dreams, bright and even more radiant.

stanza:
But is she truly what she seems?
He asks with insecure delight,
Asks of himself, and doubts,--and still
The doubt returns against his will:
Though he, and all the standers-by,
Could tell a tragic history
Of facts divulged, wherein appear
Substantial motive, reason clear,
Why thus the milk-white Doe is found
Couchant beside that lonely mound;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: He questions if the Doe's appearance is genuine, feeling uncertain but intrigued. Despite being aware of the tragic events that led to the Doe's presence, he still can't shake off his doubts. The milk-white Doe's presence beside a solitary hill seems odd, but there's a clear motive behind it.

stanza:
And why she duly loves to pace
The circuit of this hallowed place.
Nor to the Child's inquiring mind
Is such perplexity confined:
For, spite of sober Truth that sees
A world of fixed remembrances
Which to this mystery belong,
If, undeceived, my skill can trace
The characters of every face,
There lack not strange delusion here,
Conjecture vague, and idle fear,
And superstitious fancies strong,
Which do the gentle Creature wrong.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker is describing a woman who enjoys walking around a sacred area and reflecting on the mysteries that surround it. The speaker notes that even children are curious about the area and that there are many uncertainties and misconceptions that surround it. The speaker believes that there are many false beliefs and irrational fears that people have about the area, but they are not based on truth.

stanza:
That bearded, staff-supported Sire--
Who in his boyhood often fed
Full cheerily on convent-bread
And heard old tales by the convent-fire,
And to his grave will go with scars,
Relics of long and distant wars--
That Old Man, studious to expound
The spectacle, is mounting high
To days of dim antiquity;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The bearded man, who leans on his staff, had a happy childhood eating convent bread and listening to stories by the fire. He carries scars from past wars and is now devoted to explaining historic events. He is delving into the ancient past with great enthusiasm.

stanza:
When Lady Aaliza mourned
Her Son, and felt in her despair
The pang of unavailing prayer;
Her Son in Wharf's abysses drowned,
The noble Boy of Egremound.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Lady Aaliza was grieving the loss of her son who had drowned in the Wharf. Despite her prayers, she felt helpless in her despair. Her son was a noble boy from Egremound.

stanza:
From which affliction--when the grace
Of God had in her heart found place--
A pious structure, fair to see
Rose up, this stately Priory!
The Lady's work;--but now laid low;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: A beautiful Priory was built by a Lady who had found God's grace in her heart. However, it now lies in ruins.

stanza:
To the grief of her soul that doth come and go,
In the beautiful form of this innocent Doe:
Which, though seemingly doomed in its breast to sustain
A softened remembrance of sorrow and pain,
Is spotless, and holy, and gentle, and bright;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The narrator is mourning the pain that comes and goes within their soul, and finds solace in the form of an innocent doe. Although the doe appears to carry a burden of sadness, it is pure, peaceful, and radiant.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The angelic figure gracefully moves across the earth, while the chantry door remains open for anyone to pass through. If one were to peer through the crack in the damaged floor, a gruesome scene would be revealed.

stanza:
A vault where the bodies are buried upright!
There, face by face, and hand by hand,
The Claphams and Mauleverers stand;
And, in his place, among son and sire,
Is John de Clapham, that fierce Esquire,
A valiant man, and a name of dread
In the ruthless wars of the White and Red;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The burial vault is where the deceased bodies are uprightly buried together. The Claphams and Mauleverers families are buried there, standing face to face and hand in hand. One of the buried people is John de Clapham, a formidable and infamous warrior who fought in the brutal White and Red wars.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The poem describes the violent death of Earl Pembroke, who was dragged out of a church and beheaded on the porch. The speaker warns readers to be cautious when looking down at the scene, as the White Doe often lingers there and investigates the gruesome sight.

stanza:
Nor can it be with good intent:
So thinks that Dame of haughty air,
Who hath a Page her book to hold,
And wears a frontlet edged with gold.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The woman with a proud demeanor believes that it is impossible to do something with good intentions. She has a page who holds her book and wears a headband with a gold edge.

stanza:
Harsh thoughts with her high mood agree--
Who counts among her ancestry
Earl Pembroke, slain so impiously!
That slender Youth, a scholar pale,
From Oxford come to his native vale,
He also hath his own conceit:
It is, thinks he, the gracious Fairy,
Who loved the Shepherd-lord to meet
In his wanderings solitary:
Wild notes she in his hearing sang,
A song of Nature's hidden powers;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker describes a woman whose high spirits align with her harsh thoughts. She is proud of her ancestry, which includes Earl Pembroke who was killed unjustly. There is also a young scholar from Oxford who believes that a fairy who loved a shepherd used to sing to him in the wilderness. The song was about the mystical powers of nature.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: She could whistle like the wind and her singing echoed through the rocks and holly bushes. It was rumored that she could take on any form she desired and often appeared to him as a beautiful lady among the trees in dense forests.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The speaker taught someone signs and showed them sights in Craven's dens and on Cumbrian heights. When the person was scared, they were a shepherd dressed in plain grey clothing.

stanza:
Nor left him at his later day.
And hence, when he, with spear and shield,
Rode full of years to Flodden-field,
His eye could see the hidden spring,
And how the current was to flow;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: He was not abandoned in his later years, and as a result, when he rode to the battle of Flodden with his spear and shield, he was able to see the concealed source and anticipated the direction of the flow of the river.

stanza:
The fatal end of Scotland's King,
And all that hopeless overthrow.
But not in wars did he delight,
'This' Clifford wished for worthier might;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Scotland's King met his tragic demise, along with the devastating downfall of the kingdom. Despite his love for peace, he was not able to defend himself against the wishes of Clifford who sought a more deserving leader.

stanza:
Nor in broad pomp, or courtly state;
Him his own thoughts did elevate,--
Most happy in the shy recess
Of Barden's lowly quietness.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: He didn't find happiness in grandeur or extravagance, but rather in his own thoughts and the peaceful seclusion of Barden's modest tranquility.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: He had the option of selecting intelligent companions from the beloved group of Bolton. They often stood on the ancient church tower together and examined the clear night sky during peaceful moments.

stanza:
Or, in their cells, with him did pry
For other lore,--by keen desire
Urged to close toil with chemic fire;
In quest belike of transmutations
Rich as the mine's most bright creations.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: They searched for knowledge together in their cells, driven by a strong desire to discover more. They worked hard with chemical experiments, perhaps hoping to find valuable transformations that could rival the brilliance of precious minerals.

stanza:
But they and their good works are fled,
And all is now disquieted--
And peace is none, for living or dead!
Ah, pensive Scholar, think not so,
But look again at the radiant Doe!
What quiet watch she seems to keep,
Alone, beside that grassy heap!
Why mention other thoughts unmeet
For vision so composed and sweet?
While stand the people in a ring,
Gazing, doubting, questioning;
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The good people and their deeds have vanished, leaving behind unrest and no peace for anyone, living or dead. However, the Scholar should not dwell on this negativity and instead observe the serene and vigilant Doe. She stands alone, peaceful, beside a grassy mound. It is inappropriate to discuss anything else in the presence of such a composed and sweet vision. Meanwhile, the people stand in a circle, observing, doubting, and questioning.

stanza:
Yea, many overcome in spite
Of recollections clear and bright;
Which yet do unto some impart
An undisturbed repose of heart.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: Despite vivid memories, many people are able to triumph over their past experiences. However, some individuals find solace in these memories and are able to find peace within their hearts.

stanza:
And all the assembly own a law
Of orderly respect and awe;
But see--they vanish one by one,
And last, the Doe herself is gone.
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: The group has a rule to behave with respect and fear, but slowly they all leave until only the Doe is left.

title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: We have been deceived for a long time by uncertain ideas, tempted by whimsical imaginings; to which you, the harp, have willingly played your melodies without hesitation.

stanza:
And now before this Pile we stand
In solitude, and utter peace:
But, Harp! thy murmurs may not cease--
A Spirit, with his angelic wings,
In soft and breeze-like visitings,
Has touched thee--and a Spirit's hand:
A voice is with us--a command
To chant, in strains of heavenly glory,
A tale of tears, a mortal story!
title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto First
explanation: We are now standing in front of a pile, feeling alone and peaceful. However, the harp continues to make noise, as if it has been touched by a spirit with angelic wings, bringing a message to tell a story of tears and mortality. We are called to sing this tale in heavenly glory.

stanza:
ON THE FINAL PASSING OF THE BILL FOR THE ABOLITION OF THE SLAVE TRADE
MARCH 1807
CLARKSON! it was an obstinate hill to climb:
How toilsome--nay, how dire--it was, by thee
Is known; by none, perhaps, so feelingly:
But thou, who, starting in thy fervent prime,
Didst first lead forth that enterprise sublime,
Hast heard the constant Voice its charge repeat,
Which, out of thy young heart's oracular seat,
First roused thee.--O true yoke-fellow of Time,
Duty's intrepid liegeman, see, the palm
Is won, and by all Nations shall be worn!
The blood-stained Writing is for ever torn;
And thou henceforth wilt have a good man's calm,
A great man's happiness; thy zeal shall find
Repose at length, firm friend of human kind!
title: To Thomas Clarkson
explanation: This poem is a tribute to Thomas Clarkson, who dedicated his life to the abolition of the slave trade. The speaker acknowledges the difficult and challenging journey that Clarkson had to undertake to achieve this goal. The poem praises Clarkson's relentless pursuit of justice and his unwavering commitment to his cause. The passing of the bill for the abolition of the slave trade is celebrated as a triumph for all nations. The poem ends with a message of hope, recognizing that Clarkson's tireless efforts have finally paid off, and he can now enjoy the peace and happiness that comes with the knowledge of having made a positive impact on the world.

stanza:
No fiction was it of the antique age:
A sky-blue stone, within this sunless cleft,
Is of the very footmarks unbereft
Which tiny Elves impressed; - on that smooth stage
Dancing with all their brilliant equipage
In secret revels - haply after theft
Of some sweet Babe - Flower stolen, and coarse Weed left
For the distracted Mother to assuage
Her grief with, as she might! - But, where, oh! where
Is traceable a vestige of the notes
That ruled those dances wild in character? -
Deep underground? Or in the upper air,
On the shrill wind of midnight? or where floats
O'er twilight fields the autumnal gossamer?
title: The Fary Chasm
explanation: This passage describes a sky-blue stone that is believed to have been danced upon by tiny elves in ancient times. The stone still bears the footprints of the elves who danced with their brilliant equipment in secret, possibly after stealing a sweet baby and leaving a weed for the distraught mother. However, there is no evidence of the music that accompanied these wild dances, whether it is buried deep underground or carried by the wind at midnight or in the autumnal fields. The passage conjures an image of a magical and mysterious world that once existed, but is now lost to time.

stanza:
CALVERT! it must not be unheard by them
Who may respect my name, that I to thee
Owed many years of early liberty.
This care was thine when sickness did condemn
Thy youth to hopeless wasting, root and stem--
That I, if frugal and severe, might stray
Where'er I liked; and finally array
My temples with the Muse's diadem.
title: To The Memory Of Raisley Calvert
explanation: Calvert is being acknowledged by the speaker for the freedom he was able to provide during the speaker's youth. Calvert took care of the speaker during a time of sickness and allowed for the speaker to roam freely, ultimately leading to the speaker's success as a writer. The speaker is grateful for Calvert's role in allowing them to pursue their passion and achieve their goals.

stanza:
Hence, if in freedom I have loved the truth;
If there be aught of pure, or good, or great,
In my past verse; or shall be, in the lays
Of higher mood, which now I meditate;--
It gladdens me, O worthy, short-lived, Youth!
To think how much of this will be thy praise.
title: To The Memory Of Raisley Calvert
explanation: If I have loved the truth in freedom, and if my past or future poems contain anything pure, good, or great, it brings me joy to know that you, worthy and brief Youth, will praise me for it.

stanza:
SPADE! with which Wilkinson hath tilled his lands,
And shaped these pleasant walks by Emont's side,
Thou art a tool of honour in my hands;
I press thee, through the yielding soil, with pride.
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: The poet praises the spade, an important tool used by Wilkinson to cultivate his land and create beautiful paths near the river Emont. He regards the spade as a symbol of honor and takes pride in using it to dig into the soft soil.

title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: You have been fortunate to know a skilled and exceptional individual who has a strong sense of reason. This person has lived a life that brings together the best of both worlds, with experience in both hard work and leisure.

stanza:
Health, meekness, ardour, quietness secure,
And industry of body and of mind;
And elegant enjoyments, that are pure
As nature is; too pure to be refined.
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: The ideal state of being is characterized by good health, humility, passion, and serenity, as well as a strong work ethic for both physical and mental pursuits. Lastly, there are refined pleasures that are as pure and natural as they can be, without any need for further refinement.

stanza:
Here often hast Thou heard the Poet sing
In concord with his river murmuring by;
Or in some silent field, while timid spring
Is yet uncheered by other minstrelsy.
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: You have frequently listened to the Poet singing in harmony with the murmur of the river, or in a quiet field during the early stages of spring when no other music is heard.

stanza:
Who shall inherit Thee when death has laid
Low in the darksome cell thine own dear lord?
That man will have a trophy, humble Spade!
A trophy nobler than a conqueror's sword.
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: After death has taken the speaker's lord to the dark tomb, who will possess them? The answer is the humble spade, which is a more noble trophy than a sword wielded by a conqueror.

stanza:
If he be one that feels, with skill to part
False praise from true, or, greater from the less,
Thee will he welcome to his hand and heart,
Thou monument of peaceful happiness!
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: If someone is capable of distinguishing between insincere and genuine compliments, as well as recognizing the difference between things of great and lesser importance, they will warmly embrace you, a symbol of tranquil joy.

stanza:
He will not dread with Thee a toilsome day--
Thee his loved servant, his inspiring mate!
And, when thou art past service, worn away,
No dull oblivious nook shall hide thy fate.
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: He will not fear a hard day with you by his side, as you are his beloved companion and source of inspiration. Even when you are no longer able to continue serving him, your fate will not be forgotten or ignored.

stanza:
His thrift thy uselessness will never scorn;
An 'heir-loom' in his cottage wilt thou be:--
High will he hang thee up, well pleased to adorn
His rustic chimney with the last of Thee!
title: To The Spade Of A Friend (An Agriculturist)
explanation: He will never disregard your thriftiness even if you are deemed useless. You will be considered an heirloom in his humble abode and he will proudly display you on his chimney as a final decoration.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: If there existed a place of sacred land where one could seek solace during times of distress and find peace to prepare for the afterlife, it would surely be a gift from God. The author describes a location where the morning light spreads across the mountainside like purple snowflakes, indicating the beauty and tranquility of such a place.

stanza:
Where with loud voice the power of water shakes
The leafy wood, or sleeps in quiet lakes.
Yet not unrecompensed the man shall roam,
Who at the call of summer quits his home,
And plods through some wide realm o'er vale and height,
Though seeking only holiday delight;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The man who leaves his home during the summer to explore different areas, even if it's just for leisure, will be rewarded. He may encounter the force of water in the form of shaking trees or calm lakes, but it will be an experience worth having.

stanza:
At least, not owning to himself an aim
To which the sage would give a prouder name.
No gains too cheaply earned his fancy cloy,
Though every passing zephyr whispers joy;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: He did not have a clear goal that would impress wise people, and he did not want to achieve anything too easily, even though every small pleasure tempted him.

stanza:
Brisk toil, alternating with ready ease,
Feeds the clear current of his sympathies.
For him sod-seats the cottage-door adorn;
And peeps the far-off spire, his evening bourn!
Dear is the forest frowning o'er his head,
And dear the velvet green-sward to his tread:
Moves there a cloud o'er mid-day's flaming eye?
Upward he looks- 'and calls it luxury:'
Kind Nature's charities his steps attend;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The man enjoys a balance of hard work and relaxation, which nourishes his empathy. He appreciates the simple pleasures in life, such as sitting on the grass outside his cottage and gazing at the distant church. The forest and soft grass beneath his feet are also dear to him. Even when a cloud covers the sun, he sees it as a luxurious sight. He is grateful for the kindness of nature, which surrounds him wherever he goes.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: He finds solace in nature, making friends with every babbling brook he comes across. He reflects on the guidance of wisdom, which brings him comfort as he travels. At midday, he invites the needy to share his simple meal in the welcoming shade of a bower.

stanza:
He views the sun uplift his golden fire,
Or sink, with heart alive like Memnon's lyre;
Blesses the moon that comes with kindly ray,
To light him shaken by his rugged way.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: He watches the sun rise and set, feeling alive and inspired like the mythical figure of Memnon's lyre. He also appreciates the moon for providing a gentle light to guide him on his difficult path.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Children are not afraid of him and sit with him at meals. He looks humble and doesn't make anyone uncomfortable. People feel comfortable and happy around him.

stanza:
While unsuspended wheels the village dance,
The maidens eye him with enquiring glance,
Much wondering by what fit of crazing care,
Or desperate love, bewildered, he came there.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: As the wheels of the unsuspended village dance, the maidens watch with curious eyes, questioning why the man has come and wondering if he is either insane or madly in love.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The speaker reflects on a past desire that was not deemed wise by prudence but was rooted in a love for nature. They recall walking through the cornfields of France and being surrounded by tall road-elms that formed a rustling canopy above them, creating a long and winding path.

stanza:
Or where her pathways straggle as they please
By lonely farms and secret villages.
But lo! the Alps ascending white in air,
Toy with the sun and glitter from afar.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Her pathways wind through isolated farms and concealed villages, taking their own course. However, the sight of the towering Alps, rising up into the sky and gleaming in the distance, is a stunning spectacle.

stanza:
And now, emerging from the forest's gloom,
I greet thee, Chartreuse, while I mourn thy doom.
Whither is fled that Power whose frown severe
Awed sober Reason till she crouched in fear?
'That' Silence, once in deathlike fetters bound,
Chains that were loosened only by the sound
Of holy rites chanted in measured round?
- The voice of blasphemy the fane alarms,
The cloister startles at the gleam of arms.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Emerging from the darkness of the forest, I meet you, Chartreuse, with a heavy heart for your fate. Where has the power gone that once struck fear into the hearts of those who dared to challenge it? The stillness that was once bound by deathly chains only to be broken by the sacred chants of holy rites - where has it gone? Blasphemous voices now fill the temple and the sight of weapons startles the cloister.

stanza:
The thundering tube the aged angler hears,
Bent o'er the groaning flood that sweeps away his tears.
Cloud-piercing pine-trees nod their troubled heads,
Spires, rocks, and lawns a browner night o'erspreads;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The angler hears the loud sound of the rushing water as he leans over the river that carries away his sorrows. The tall pine trees sway uneasily against the backdrop of a darkening sky. The landscape transforms into darker shades of brown as the night sets in, with rocks and meadows disappearing into the darkness.

stanza:
Strong terror checks the female peasant's sighs,
And start the astonished shades at female eyes.
From Bruno's forest screams the affrighted jay,
And slow the insulted eagle wheels away.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The female peasant's sighs are silenced by intense terror, and the sight of females causes shock and surprise. The jay from Bruno's forest lets out screams of fear, while the eagle, feeling disrespected, flies away at a leisurely pace.

stanza:
A viewless flight of laughing Demons mock
The Cross, by angels planted on the aerial rock.
The 'parting Genius' sighs with hollow breath
Along the mystic streams of Life and Death.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Laughing demons are flying invisibly and mocking the cross that was planted by angels on a rock in the air. The "parting genius" is sighing with a hollow breath along the mysterious streams of life and death.

stanza:
Swelling the outcry dull, that long resounds
Portentous through her old woods' trackless bounds,
Vallombre, 'mid her falling fanes, deplores,
For ever broke, the sabbath of her bowers.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The sound of lamentation that echoes through the ancient woods of Vallombre has gradually faded away, losing its intensity. The once sacred and peaceful environment has been disrupted by the destruction of its temples, leaving its gardens desolate and forever scarred. This loss of tranquility is mourned by Vallombre, as the Sabbath of its groves has been irreparably shattered.

stanza:
More pleased, my foot the hidden margin roves
Of Como, bosomed deep in chestnut groves.
No meadows thrown between, the giddy steeps
Tower, bare or sylvan, from the narrow deeps.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: I am enjoying the feeling of pleasure as I wander along the hidden edge of Lake Como, which is surrounded by dense chestnut forests. There are no open fields or meadows to be seen, only steep hillsides that rise up from the lake's narrow depths, either covered in trees or bare and rocky.

stanza:
- To towns, whose shades of no rude noise complain,
From ringing team apart and grating wain-
To flat-roofed towns, that touch the water's bound,
Or lurk in woody sunless glens profound,
Or, from the bending rocks, obtrusive cling,
And o'er the whitened wave their shadows fling-
The pathway leads, as round the steeps it twines;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The path winds around steep slopes, leading to peaceful towns where the only sounds are gentle and natural. These towns may be flat-roofed and situated on the water's edge, or hidden in deep, shaded valleys. Some may even cling to the rocky cliffs, casting their shadows over the white-capped waves.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The stillness of the surroundings is complemented by the lush purple vines that adorn the roof. As the traveler passes by in the evening, they can glimpse the sailboat through the trees from the steps carved into the rocks. They may also observe the beautiful maidens tending to their gardens among the cliffs.

stanza:
Or stops the solemn mountain-shades to view
Stretch o'er the pictured mirror broad and blue,
And track the yellow lights from steep to steep,
As up the opposing hills they slowly creep.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The observer pauses to admire the view of the majestic mountains casting their shadows over the vast blue expanse of water. They follow the path of the yellow lights ascending the steep hills in the distance.

stanza:
Aloft, here, half a village shines, arrayed
In golden light; half hides itself in shade:
While, from amid the darkened roofs, the spire,
Restlessly flashing, seems to mount like fire:
There, all unshaded, blazing forests throw
Rich golden verdure on the lake below.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Half of the village is illuminated in golden light while the other half is obscured in shadow. The spire stands out amongst the darkened roofs as it flashes and appears to rise like fire. On the other side, the forests are unobstructed and brightly shine with golden foliage that reflects onto the lake below.

stanza:
Slow glides the sail along the illumined shore,
And steals into the shade the lazy oar;
Soft bosoms breathe around contagious sighs,
And amorous music on the water dies.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The sail moves slowly along the bright shoreline, while the oar moves lazily into the shade. There are soft sighs and amorous music on the water, which create a romantic atmosphere.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The magnificent beauty of the natural surroundings is truly a blessing to behold. Whether one is admiring the open landscapes or seeking solace in private retreats, the sight of the never-ending forest climbing up the rocky cliffs and the vast waters flowing through the valleys never tires. It is a picturesque scene that elicits feelings of joy and contentment, a true feast for the eyes.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The humble cottages that dot the shoreline, each with its own boat parked nearby; the gushing streams that emerge from the bright blue sky; and the towns that cling to the cliffs like bird nests.

stanza:
That glimmer hoar in eve's last light, descried
Dim from the twilight water's shaggy side,
Whence lutes and voices down the enchanted woods
Steal, and compose the oar-forgotten floods;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: In the evening's fading light, a shimmering frost can be seen from the rough waters' edge. The enchanted woods are filled with the sound of lutes and voices that drift along the still waters, forgotten by those who rowed upon them.

stanza:
Thy lake, that, streaked or dappled, blue or grey,
'Mid smoking woods gleams hid from morning's ray
Slow-travelling down the western hills, to enfold
Its green-tinged margin in a blaze of gold;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The lake, which can appear striped or spotted with shades of blue or grey, is hidden from the morning sun by the smoking woods. It moves slowly down the western hills and surrounds its greenish edges with a bright gold color.

stanza:
Thy glittering steeples, whence the matin bell
Calls forth the woodman from his desert cell,
And quickens the blithe sound of oars that pass
Along the steaming lake, to early mass.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The shining towers of the church ringing the morning bell, awaken the woodcutter from his isolated home and urge the cheerful sound of rowing boats crossing the misty lake, heading towards the early religious service.

stanza:
But now farewell to each and all- adieu
To every charm, and last and chief to you,
Ye lovely maidens that in noontide shade
Rest near your little plots of wheaten glade;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Goodbye to everyone, especially to you, beautiful maidens who rest in the shade of wheat fields at noon. I bid farewell to all the charms that surround me.

stanza:
To all that binds the soul in powerless trance,
Lip-dewing song, and ringlet-tossing dance;
Where sparkling eyes and breaking smiles illume
The sylvan cabin's lute-enlivened gloom.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The speaker describes an environment where the soul is held captive by various forms of entertainment such as singing, dancing, and music. This place is illuminated by bright eyes and bright smiles in a cabin surrounded by nature.

stanza:
- Alas! the very murmur of the streams
Breathes o'er the failing soul voluptuous dreams,
While Slavery, forcing the sunk mind to dwell
On joys that might disgrace the captive's cell,
Her shameless timbrel shakes on Como's marge,
And lures from bay to bay the vocal barge.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The sound of the flowing streams can evoke pleasurable thoughts in anyone, but for those enslaved, it only serves as a reminder of what they cannot have. Slavery forces the mind to focus on thoughts of joy that are only fit for a prisoner's cell. The shameless act of using music to lure people from one place to another is happening on the shores of Lake Como.

stanza:
Yet are thy softer arts with power indued
To soothe and cheer the poor man's solitude.
By silent cottage-doors, the peasant's home
Left vacant for the day, I loved to roam.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Your gentle abilities have the ability to comfort and uplift those who are lonely and impoverished. I enjoy wandering around the abandoned homes of peasants, which are often silent and empty during the day.

stanza:
But once I pierced the mazes of a wood
In which a cabin undeserted stood;
There an old man an olden measure scanned
On a rude viol touched with withered hand.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: I navigated through a complex forest until I stumbled upon a cabin that appeared to be inhabited. Inside, I discovered an elderly man playing a traditional tune on a simple, weathered violin.

stanza:
As lambs or fawns in April clustering lie
Under a hoary oak's thin canopy,
Stretched at his feet, with stedfast upward eye,
His children's children listened to the sound;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The children's children gathered around their grandfather like lambs or fawns in April under an old oak tree. They lay there, looking up at him with unwavering attention as he spoke.

stanza:
- A Hermit with his family around!
But let us hence; for fair Locarno smiles
Embowered in walnut slopes and citron isles:
Or seek at eve the banks of Tusa's stream,
Where, 'mid dim towers and woods, her waters gleam.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The speaker mentions a hermit who has his family with him but quickly moves on to suggest leaving the hermit and heading to Locarno, a beautiful area surrounded by walnut trees and citron islands. The speaker then suggests visiting the banks of the Tusa stream in the evening, where the water glimmers among the towers and woods.

stanza:
From the bright wave, in solemn gloom, retire
The dull-red steeps, and, darkening still, aspire
To where afar rich orange lustres glow
Round undistinguished clouds, and rocks, and snow:
Or, led where Via Mala's chasms confine
The indignant waters of the infant Rhine,
Hang o'er the abyss, whose else impervious gloom
His burning eyes with fearful light illume.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The bright wave retreats into solemn gloom as the dull-red steeps darken and rise towards the distant orange glow surrounding indistinguishable clouds, rocks, and snow. One can also venture to Via Mala's chasms where the furious waters of the young Rhine are confined and observe the abyss illuminated by the burning eyes with fearful light.

stanza:
The mind condemned, without reprieve, to go
O'er life's long deserts with its charge of woe,
With sad congratulation joins the train
Where beasts and men together o'er the plain
Move on- a mighty caravan of pain:
Hope, strength, and courage, social suffering brings,
Freshening the wilderness with shades and springs.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The human mind is burdened with sorrow and is forced to journey through the long, arduous paths of life. It joins the procession of suffering, along with animals and other people, as they traverse the vast expanse of pain. However, amidst the misery, there is a glimmer of hope, strength, and courage that comes from the shared experience of hardship. This collective suffering creates an oasis in the desolate wilderness, providing relief in the form of shade and springs.

stanza:
- There be whose lot far otherwise is cast:
Sole human tenant of the piny waste,
By choice or doom a gipsy wanders here,
A nursling babe her only comforter;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: There are those who have a very different fate: they are the only human inhabitant in a forested, desolate land. They may have chosen this life of wandering like a gypsy or been forced into it by circumstances beyond their control. Their only companion in this wilderness is a young child they care for and protect.

stanza:
Lo, where she sits beneath yon shaggy rock,
A cowering shape half hid in curling smoke!
When lightning among clouds and mountain-snows
Predominates, and darkness comes and goes,
And the fierce torrent, at the flashes broad
Starts, like a horse, beside the glaring road-
She seeks a covert from the battering shower
In the roofed bridge; a the bridge, ill that dread hour,
Itself all trembling at the torrent's power.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: She is sitting under a rocky area, covered by smoke and looking frightened. Lightning strikes the mountains and the clouds, causing darkness and a strong current to form. She seeks shelter under a bridge that is also trembling from the force of the water.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The Vagrant is not comforted on quiet nights devoid of stars. Even the fading moon, which hangs above a sad mountain, does not bring solace. Instead, she is consumed by darkness and sorrow, bowing her head and closing her eyes in weariness.

stanza:
Or on her fingers counts the distant clock,
Or, to the drowsy crow of midnight cock,
Listens, or quakes while from the forest's gulf
Howls near and nearer yet the famished wolf.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The woman either checks the time by counting on her fingers or listens to the crow's call at midnight. She also trembles in fear as she hears the sound of a hungry wolf getting closer and closer from the depths of the forest.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: We are now descending from the green valley of Urseren, following the fast-flowing Reuss river. The path is narrow and winding, surrounded by rocks that block out the sunlight and seem to be on the verge of collapsing.

title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The poet describes the cells that the kneeling peasant prays in, which are adorned with images that are too sacred to even look at. He also mentions the numerous death-crosses that are planted nearby, which are regularly watered with tears from the devout. Despite the danger that surrounds them, the tears silently fade away without any reaction from those who shed them.

stanza:
Fixed on the anchor left by Him who saves
Alike in whelming snows, and roaring waves.
But soon a peopled region on the sight
Opens- a little world of calm delight;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The speaker's focus is on the anchor left by Jesus Christ that provides stability in difficult situations, such as snowstorms and rough waters. However, their attention shifts towards a peaceful and welcoming land, which appears to be a small yet delightful world.

stanza:
Where mists, suspended on the expiring gale,
Spread rooflike o'er the deep secluded vale,
And beams of evening slipping in between,
Gently illuminate a sober scene:-
Here, on the brown wood-cottages they sleep,
There, over rock or sloping pasture creep.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: In a quiet valley, mist hangs in the air and the fading evening light shines through, casting a gentle glow on the surroundings. The wooden houses are nestled against the brown earth, while rocks and slopes are scattered throughout the pastures. It's a tranquil and peaceful scene.

stanza:
On as we journey, in clear view displayed,
The still vale lengthens underneath its shade
Of low-hung vapour: on the freshened mead
The green light sparkles; - the dim bowers recede.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: As we continue our journey, we can see the serene valley stretching out before us. The low-hanging mist casts a shadow over it, while the lush green meadow glistens under the bright sunlight. The dark and mysterious groves retreat into the distance, creating an atmosphere of tranquility and calmness.

stanza:
While pastoral pipes and streams the landscape lull,
And bells of passing mules that tinkle dull,
In solemn shapes before the admiring eye
Dilated hang the misty pines on high,
Huge convent domes with pinnacles and towers,
And antique castles seen through gleamy showers.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The serene countryside is accompanied by the soft sounds of pipes and streams, as well as the dull ringing of passing mule bells. The landscape is adorned with majestic sights such as misty pine trees, towering convent domes, and antique castles that can be seen through the occasional glimmer of rain. These sights leave an awe-inspiring impression on those who behold them.

stanza:
From such romantic dreams, my soul, awake!
To sterner pleasure, where, by Uri's lake
In Nature's pristine majesty outspread,
Winds neither road nor path for foot to tread:
The rocks rise naked as a wall, or stretch
Far o'er the water, hung with groves of beech;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Wake up from these dreamy romantic thoughts, my soul, and experience the harsher pleasures of Uri's lake. It is a place of pure natural beauty where there are no roads or footpaths to follow. The rocks are either bare and tall like walls or spread out far over the water, adorned with groves of beech trees.

stanza:
Aerial pines from loftier steeps ascend,
Nor stop but where creation seems to end.
Yet here and there, if mid the savage scene
Appears a scanty plot of smiling green,
Up from the lake a zigzag path will creep
To reach a small wood-hut hung boldly on the steep,
- Before those thresholds (never can they know
The face of traveller passing to and fro,)
No peasant leans upon his pole, to tell
For whom at morning tolled the funeral bell;
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: Tall pine trees rise high up in the mountains and only stop where the landscape seems to cease. However, in some places amidst the wild scenery, a small area of greenery can be seen, and a zigzagging path leads up from the lake to a wooden hut hanging bravely on the slope. No commoner ever leans on his walking stick in front of these huts, and they will never know who the traveler passing by is or why the funeral bell may toll in the morning.

stanza:
Their watch-dog ne'er his angry bark foregoes,
Touched by the beggar's moan of human woes;
The shady porch ne'er offered a cool seat
To pilgrims overcome by summer's heat.
title: Descriptive Sketches Taken During A Pedestrian Tour Among The Alps
explanation: The watchdog always barks angrily, even when a beggar pleads for help in his misery. The sheltered porch never provides a cool resting place for travelers exhausted by the heat of summer.

stanza:
Yet thither the world's business finds its way
At times, and tales unsought beguile the day,
And 'there' are those fond thoughts which Solitude,
However stern, is powerless to exclude.
